तत्स्थानमुपभोक्तव्यं अव्यक्तब्रह्मसेविनाम्।  
तन्मध्ये नगरी दिव्या साऽयोध्येति प्रकीर्तिता।  
सर्वाक्षरमयं दिव्यं योगपीठमिति स्मृतम्।  
तन्मध्येष्टदलं पद्मं उदयार्कसमप्रभम्।**

**तन्मध्ये कर्णिकायान्तु सावित्र्यां शुभदर्शने।  
ईश्वर्या सह देवेशस्तत्रासीनः परः पुमान्।  
विमलोत्कर्षिणीज्ञाताक्रिया योगा तथैव च।  
प्रह्वी सत्या तथेशाना महिष्यः परमात्मनः।  
तद्व्यूहभेदान् लोकांश्च वक्ष्यामि गिरिजे शुभे।  
प्राच्यां वैकुण्ठलोकस्य वासुदेवस्य मन्दिरम्।  
आग्नेय्यां लक्ष्म्यालोकस्तु याम्यां सङ्कर्षणालयः।  
सारस्वतन्तु नैरृत्यां प्राद्युम्नः पश्चिमे तथा।  
रतिलोकस्तु वायव्यां उदीच्यामनिरुद्धभूः।  
ऐशान्यां शान्तिलोकस्यात् प्रथमावरणं स्मृतम्।  
प्रह्लादाद्या महाद्मानो द्वितीयावरणम् स्मृतम्।  
मत्स्यकूर्मादि लोकास्तु तृतीयावरणं परम्।  
सत्याच्युतानन्तदुर्गा विष्वक्सेन गजाननाः।  
शङ्खपद्मनिधी लोकाश्चतुर्थावरणं स्मृतम्।  
ऋग्यजुः सामाथर्वणलोकादिषु महत्सु च।  
सावित्र्या विहगेशस्य धर्मस्य च मखस्य च।  
पञ्चम वरणं प्रोक्तमक्षयं सर्ववाङ्मयम्।  
शङ्खचक्रगदापद्म खठ्गशार्ङ्हलं तथा।  
मौसलञ्चतथा लोकाःसर्वे शस्त्रास्त्रसंयुताः।  
षष्ठमावरणं प्रोक्तं मन्त्रास्त्रमयमक्षरम्।  
ऐन्द्रपावकयाम्यानि नैरृतं वारुणं तथा।  
वायव्यं सौम्यमैशानं सप्तमं मुनिभिः स्मृतम्।  
साध्या मरुद्गगाश्चैव विश्वेदेवास्तथैव च।  
नित्याःसर्वे परे धाम्नि ये चान्ये च दिवौकसः।  
ते वै प्राकृतानाकेस्मिन्ननित्यास्त्रिदशेश्वराः।  
मत्स्यकूर्मादि यद्रूपं अवतारात्मकं हरेः।  
दीपादुत्पाद्यते दीपो यथावत्तद्भविष्यति।**

**अर्चावतारा देवस्य वैभवाः परमाद्मनः।  
परावस्थाः परेशस्य व्यूहाश्च विभवादयः॥**

**पद्मपुराणम्॥**

***Q No. V.***

 महापुरुष आद्मानं चतुर्द्धा कृत्वा त्रिपादेन परमव्योम्नि चासीत्। इतरेणचतुर्थेन अनिरुद्धनारायणेन विश्वान्यासन्। स च पादनारायणो जगत्स्रष्टुं प्रकृतिमजनयत्। एतेन जीवाद्मनोर्योगेन मोक्षप्रकारश्च कथित इत्यनुसन्धेयं। य इमंसृष्टियज्ञं जानाति मोक्षप्रकारञ्च सर्वमायुरेति। तं यथा यथोपासते तथैव भवति।तस्मात् ब्रह्मणः पुरुषरूपं परब्रह्मैवाहमिति भावयेत्। तद्रूपो भवति। य एवं वेद॥

**मुद्गलोपनिषत्॥**

***Q. No. VI.***

**सतो व्योमत्वमापन्नं व्योम्नःसत्तान्तु लौकिकाः।  
तार्किकाश्चावगछन्ति मायाया उचितं हि तत्।  
यद्यथा वर्तते तस्य तथात्वं भाति मानतः।  
अन्यथात्वं भ्रमेणेति न्यायोयं सार्वलौकिकः।  
एवं श्रुतिविचारात्प्राक् यथा यद्वस्तु भासते।  
विचारेण विपर्येति ततस्तच्चिंत्यतां वियत्।  
भातीति चेद्भातुनाम भूषणं मायिकस्य तत्।  
यदसद्भासमानं तन्मिथ्या स्वप्नगजादिवत्।  
बुद्धोऽपि भेदो नो चित्ते निरूढिं यातिचेत्तदा।  
अनैकाग्र्यात्संशयाद्वा रूढ्यभावोस्य ते वद।  
अप्रमत्तो भवध्यानादाद्येऽन्यस्मिन्विवेचनम्।  
कुरु प्रमाणयुक्तिभ्यां ततो रूढतमो भवेत्।  
ध्यानान्मानाद्युक्तितोपि रूढे भेदे वियत्सतोः।  
न कदाचिद्वियत्सत्यं सद्वस्तुछिद्रवन्न च।  
एवमाकाशमिथ्यात्वे सत्सत्यत्वे च वासिते।  
न्यायेनानेन वाय्वादेः सद्वस्तु प्रविविच्यताम्।  
सद्वस्तुन्येकदेशस्था माया तत्रैकदेशगम्।  
वियत्तत्राऽप्येकदेशगतो वायुः प्रकल्पितः।**

**सद्वस्तु ब्रह्मशिष्टोंशो वायुर्मिथ्या यथा वियत्।  
वासयित्वा चिरं वायोर्मिथ्यात्वं मरुतं यजेत्।  
चिन्तयेद्वह्निमप्येवं मरुतो न्यूनवर्तिनम्।  
ब्रह्माण्डावरणेष्वेषा न्यूनाधिकविचारणा।  
वायोर्दशांशतो न्यूनो वह्निर्वायौ प्रकल्पितः।  
पुराणोक्तं तारतम्यं दशांशैर्भूतपञ्चके।  
पृथक् कृतायां सत्तायां भूमिर्मिथ्यावशिष्यते।  
भूमेर्द्दशांशतो न्यूनं ब्रह्माण्डं भूमिमध्यगमू।  
ब्रह्माण्डमध्ये तिष्ठन्ति भुवनानि चतुर्दश।  
भुवनेषु वसन्तेषु प्राणिदेहा यथा तथम्।  
द्वैतावज्ञा सुस्थिता चेदद्वैते धीः स्थिरा भवेत्।  
स्थैर्ये तस्याः पुमानेष जीवन्मुक्त इतीर्यते।  
एषा ब्राह्मीस्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति।  
स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाण मृछति॥**

**पञ्चदशी॥**

***Q. No. VII.***

**शिवस्य परिपूर्णस्य परानुग्रहमन्तरा \।  
न किश्चिदपि कर्तव्यं इति साधुविनिश्चितम्।  
स्वभाव एव पर्याप्तः परानुग्रहकर्मणि।  
अन्यथा निःस्वभावेन न किमप्यनुगृह्यते।  
परं सर्वमनुग्राह्यं पशुपाशात्मकं जगत्।  
परस्यानुग्रहार्थस्तु पत्युराज्ञा समन्वयः।  
पतिराज्ञापकःसर्वं अनुगृह्णाति सर्वदा।  
तदर्थमर्थस्वीकारे परतन्त्रः कथं शिवः।  
अनुग्राह्यानपेक्षोस्ति नहि कश्चिदनुग्रहः।  
अतः स्वातन्त्र्यशब्दार्थो नानपेक्षत्व लक्षणः।  
यत्तत्पुनरनुग्राह्यं परतन्त्रं तदिष्यते।  
अनुग्रहादृते तस्य भुक्तिमुक्त्योरनन्वयात्।  
मूर्त्यात्मानोप्यनुग्राह्याः शिवाज्ञाननिवर्तनात्।**

**अज्ञानाधिष्ठितं शम्भोर्नकिञ्चिदिह विद्यते।  
येनोपलभ्यतेस्माभिः सकलेनाति निष्कलः।  
स मूर्त्यात्मा शिवस्यैव मूर्तिरित्युपचर्यते।  
न ह्यसौ निष्कलः साक्षाछिवःपरमकारणम्।  
स्वाकारेणानुभाव्येन केनाप्यनुपलक्षितः।  
प्रमाणगम्यता मात्रं तत्स्वभावोपपादकम्।  
न तावतात्रापेक्षाधीरुपलक्षणमन्तरा।  
आत्मोपलक्षणं साक्षान्मूर्तिरेव हि काचन।  
शिवस्य मूर्तिमूर्त्याद्मायतस्तस्योपलक्षणम्।  
यथा काष्ठाद्यनारूढो न वह्निरुपलभ्यते।  
एवं शिवोपि मूर्त्यात्मन्यनारूढइतिस्थितिः।  
यथाग्निमानयेत्युक्ते ज्वलत्काष्ठादृतेस्वयम्।  
नाग्निरानीयते तद्वत्पूज्यो मूर्त्यात्मना शिवः।  
अतएव हि पूजादौ मूर्त्यात्मपरिकल्पनम्।  
मूर्त्यात्मनि कृतं साक्षाच्छिवएव कृतं यतः॥**

**शिवमहापुराणम्।**

***Q. No. VIII.***

**पूजाभक्तिः कथं शून्ये साकारे कथ्यते बुधैः।  
शून्यमार्गे कथं याति आधारेण विना नरः।  
सेवारसश्च साकारे निराकारे न वै रसः।  
साकारेण निराकारो ज्ञायते स्वयमेव हि।  
हरिस्मृतिप्रसादेन रोमाञ्चिततनुर्यदा।  
नयनानन्दसलिलं मुक्तिर्दासी भवेत्तदा।  
वाण्या च यत्कृतं पापं कीर्तनात्तद्विनश्यति।  
मनसा यत्कृतं पापं स्मरणात्तद्विनश्यति।  
कर्मणा यत्कृतं पापं तत्कथन्तु विनश्यति।  
पूजादानव्रतैस्तीर्थैर्जपहोमस्त्वदर्पितैः।  
कर्माधीनं जगत्सर्वंविष्णुना निर्मितं पुरा।  
तत्कर्म केशवाधीनं रामनाम्ना विनश्यति॥**

**पद्मपुराणम्।**

***Quotation. No. I.***

 "None can afford to remain a single second without doing something. He is ever compelled by the force ofnature".

 The idea of action here includes everything done bymind and word also. This is an important maxim in ourreligious psychology which is invariably overlooked. Thefalse and presumptuous Vedantism of the stupid, immoralaud wicked, exhibits the total ignorance of this fundamentalprinciple. We have already noticed in the last Chapterthat for a successful march in the right path, there must bethe combined practice of Mano-nasa, Vasana-kshaya andVignana It requires no spectacles to see that the currentVedantism is entirely free from the items specified but thatit is often combined with strictly prohibited ones. The sheerignorance of the necessity of these items, emboldens thehypocrite to preach his so-called Vedantism and lead an ignominious life with ipmunity; and the very same ignorance onthe part of the Hindu public becomes the source, of toleration for the existence of such miscreants and even of theirveneration at times.

***Q. No. II.***

 "The Apara or secondary form of Mukti which leads tothe ultimate emancipation is obtained by Karma or actiononly. It is external by acts of word or deed and internalby meditation of Brahman as constituting everything.There is no doubt that Gnana as opposed to Karma is virtually the highest form of worship, but it cannot suit thegenerality of mankind who are sinners. All forms of worship prescribed in the Vedas and Tantras as well as thosepractised by Budhists, Jains or others, with devotional spirit,

are all beneficial to mankind and are recognised as fallingunder religious Karmas”.

 What a cosmopolitan view is here proclaimed in ourreligion, and why does any critic venture to cry it down assectarian? When a scientific necessity for worship in someform is clearly established in these passages, why is it criticised as superstitious? The critic is probably ashamed toconfess that he is a sinner as pointed out here. No one,however, dares to question his real merits, but let him satisfyhis own conscience first on this point, before he attempts tocondemn or ignore the rigorous religious maxim here enunciated.

***Q. No. III.***

 "The different Karmas leading to heaven and otherblissful states which are comparatively insignificant andtransient, are prescribed by the wise, in consideration of thedefective qualifications of mankind for the highest goal.The devotional processes are therefore divided into Karmaand Gnana dealing with the Atman as Murthis or forms andas Sabda-bramhan, for the benefit of mankind".

 The cogent reason for the secondary step adopted ishere clearly explained. The venerable Rishis are not therefore ignorant of the higher philosophical stage, nor are theyunaware of the limited qualifications of the masses. Theyknew very well the capacities of the Pandit and the critic,but only they are not known correctly by our modernauthorities.

***Q. No. IV.***

 "There are two varieties of the Lord's glory, the Bhogaand the Lila. The former is eternal and refers to the Nirguna and the three-quarter lying above the latter, which is

the remaining quarter, referring to the existing universe,treated as ephemeral in philosophy and as originating fromPrakriti. When this Lila or display of Prakriti is annihilated, the Bhoga is attained. The boundary between thesetwo regions is the Viraja river whose waters are producedby the sweat of knowledge and devotion. Beyond thisriver lies the Para-vyoma or three-quarter glory known bythe synonyms, Akshara, Parama, Dhama, Vykuntha, Saswataand Pada. Between this region and the river is calledKevals, the special region intended for those meditatingupon Avyakta-Bramhan or Bramhan in the form of infinity.In the middle of this region is the divine town calledAyodhya known as Yoga-pittha and made up of all theholy letters. In the centre of this there is a lotus of eightpetals,. the pericarp of which is Savithri in which Easwararesides with his Saktis, namely, Vimalotkarshini, Gnana,Kriya, Yoga, Prahwi, Satya and Esana. The Lokas, thevarious surrounding enclosures and the equipages in theregion of higher glory are detailed below. The eight cardinal points beginning with the East respectively contains Vaikuntha, the region of Vasudeva, then that of Lekshmi, Sankarshana, Saraswati, Pradyumna, Reti, Anirudha and Santi.This completes the first enclosure. The second enclosurecontains the lokas of Prahlada and other great devotees, thethird, those of Matsya, Kurma &c., the fourth those ofSatya, Achuta, Ananta, Durga, Vishwaksena, Ganesa, andcontains also the valuable mines known as Sankha, Padma& c. The fifth consists of the lokas of the Vedas, Savithri,Geruda, Dharma and Makha. The sixth refers to the lokasof the weapons such as chakra, sword & c. The seventh isthe region of the eight Dik-palas, Sadhyas, Maruths, Viswedevas and other Devas. The Devas in the heaven of Prakriti are not similarly eternal. The incarnations of the Lord,

×

such as Matsya, Kurma etc, are the forms of His gloriesprescribe for religious worship."

 We have here a general geography in detail. TheLord's glory is divided into two parts, one quarter below,subject to the laws of Prakriti and three quarters abovebeyond the reach of Prakriti. The boundary river separatingthe two regions is called Viraja on the other bank of whichis the town of Ayodhya. Is the Pandit here going to identify this river with the modern Sarayu in Upper India ? TheViraja however is the boundary between ephemeral andeternal existence and its waters are made up of the sweat ofdevotional emotions. The word Viraja clearly denotesSatwa, beyond Rejas and Tamas. Who compells any Panditto talk nonsense if he does not know the subject? If hedoes not create unnecessary confusion, others have bettercommon sense to find out the correct application of thesedescriptions without much difficulty. It is clearly explainedin the texts themselves, and none need fear the existence ofany occultisms placed around it. The remaini g details ofgeography given are clearly mentioned as prescribed forreligious worship. The proper scientific reasons assigned forthem could be discovered by a study of the subject as in allother worldly matters, but never by a contemptuous rejection of the subject altogether. Its importance is not a whit diminished by such irreligious vandalism, and the modernpreponderance of the materialistic tendency at the verybottom has alone to be pitied. The most useful and valuablestudy long provided for the real benefit of man is being nowneglected not only by sheer ignorance, but curiously enough,on the pretext of having discovered its worthlessness by theforce of modern civilization. It is verily one of the greatestwonders of this lucky twentieth century, if all our religiousliterature has become so transparent that modern civilization

can see through it all its serious defects, even without aglance of the same.

***Q. No. V***

 "The Atma divided itself into four parts, three partsof which reinained in the Paramom-vyoma or pure Akasa.The remaining quarter known as Anirudha originatedPrakriti for the purpose of creating the Jagat. This description of creation must be understood as explaining the wayfor emancipation by the union of Jivatma and Paramatma.In whatever form the Bramhan is worshipped, the devoteeattains that form, therefore Bramhan should be worshippedas the Purusha by meditating that the self is Bramhan".

 The creation here specified is required to be understoodas Srishti-yegna, or a process of worship for the attainmentof Salvation. Could the Pandit, critic or Theosophist pointout a single word here which refers to their India, Tibet orthe submerged islands of the Atlantic ocean? The originaltext wants us to understand the description as an Yegna orworship and the modern interpreters insist on overruling theauthors themselves by explaining it as their earthly geography. This is indeed a novel and funny method of writingcommentaries on a subject. The enlightened interepreterscould more wisely have taken to the production of valuableoriginal texts themselves, without losing their self-respectby such demeaning task. They would have been veneratedas the modern Rishis of the twentieth century far wiser thanthe useless fossils of the time-barred old world. They mighthowever have to retire to the forest before they can think ofsuch a work, and the idea of leaving this happy and progressing material world is certainly opposed to modern taste andfashion. The best method of evading all these unnecessary

difficulties is by bidding farewell to this troublesome literature under reference. By so doing, they would of course beconferring a great boon on the poor religious Hindu. Thesubject on the whole is not to their temperament or taste andtheir present interference is only a frightful assistance.

**असतां धर्मबुद्धिश्चेत्सतां सन्तापकारणम्॥**

***Q. No. VI.***

 "In the Puranas, the five subtle elements are describedin their separate individual states. The last element, theearth is said to be only one-tenth in extent as compared withwater. Fire is ten times greater than water, but is only one-tenth of air. The Akasa is ten times greater than air. Thesubtle element earth is ten times greater than the Bramhandawithin it which contains the 14 Lokas. Akasa, the greatestelement is itself nonexistent, as the eternal substance orBramhan can have no Akasa, hole or vacuum. Withoutphilosophical enquiry, this Akasa might appear as true, thatis the force of Maya; but even after its non-existence isknown, we are prone to feel otherwise at times on accountof doubts and absense of concentration of thought. Byrepeatedly reading philosophy, thinking and meditating, wewill become certain of its nonexistence. The next elementair is only one-tenth of this Akasa and is therefore equallyfalse. In this manner, comingdown to the lowest and themost insignificant cosmology of man, the immensity of theglory of Bramhan will be known. This is the way to become a Jivan-mukta".

 The above is practically the real commentary upon thePuranic descriptions of the apparent geography detailed.The Brainhanda itself is measured out as only one-tenth ofthe subtle earth, the other elements above being ten timesguester in succession. These representthe glories of Bram-

han. The modern Pandit however can measure the grandphilosophical religion of his venerable forefathers, only withhis village geography. He would be doing great good tohimself, if he only finds out first his own real position inour religious geography. He is not even a man of thisworld, much less of the one beyond. He has virtuallyreduced himself to one of the inutilities of a nation at present, and let him understand as soon as possible, that inthese days of rapid progress, standing still means immenseretrogression. Let him take the following warning in goodparts, lest his species soon become extinct.

**"If of life you keep a care  
Shake off slumber and beware".**

***Q. No. VII.***

 "That nothing could be obtained by man without theblessing of the perfect and infinite Lord, is the settled opinion of the wise. Man is ever dependent and wants theblessings of the Lord, whose real nature as Nishkala orformless is known to him only through the Sastras. TheMoorthi or form of the Lord is therefore important as it is his real sign or mark, whose worship soon leads to hisformless nature. Whenever fire is required, it is availableonly as combined with a burning piece of wood and forthat reason it is not uncared for. Similarly the Lord shouldbe worshiped in his form or moorthi'.

 The use of Upasana or worship of the glories of God ishere explained, and all propogators of iconoclasm may takenote of this passage. To approach the perfect and infiniteGod with the impure and finite mind of man, is a psycholological impossibility. To secure fire free from wood or othermaterials, is a physical impossibility. How does the modernscience propose to solve the problem? Throw the whole case into the waste-paper basket or light a match and

dispose of it in a minute. These are perhaps the easiestmetho ls of getting over the difficulty. The natural presumption here is, that either something rotten lies at the bottomof the boasted science of the modern day or something iswrong in the brain of its professor. The scientist generallydevises means to take refuge in the terminus of science, onthe plea that questions of this kind do not fall within theprovince of his professed subject. So far however he maybe reckoned as honest and honourable, but his occasionalattempts to corrodo religion by the use of his science whichhe has admitted to be inapplicable, are surely inexplicable.Science is not irreligion, and he may be prepared to meet hisown science one day dictating unpalatable lessons to himconcerning his iconoclastic theory. Ordinary miseries ofeveryday occurrence in this material world, often succeedin overthrowing the fondest theories of the scientist, moreeasily and more quickly than his own science.

**आर्ता देवान्नमस्यन्ति तपः कुर्वन्ति रोगिणः।  
निर्धनां दानमिच्छन्ति वृद्धा नारी पतिव्रता॥**

***Q. No. VIII.***

 "The wise say that it is not practicable to display ourlove towards the formless and to proceed without a hold onsomething. The Lord in some form can be served withgreat pleasure and such worship will doubtless lead to theknowledge of his formless nature. The meditation of theLord in form produces unbounded joy, and emancipation orMukti must dance attendance before the devotional ecstasy,Besides, how is man going to expiate his sins committedthrough mind, word and deed except by such worship? Bypraying to God and by praising His glories, the sins accumulated by talk would be annihilated. Mental sins would bedestroyed by meditating on his glories. Sins by acts would

be removed by perforining the various religions and ethicalduties prescribed Karma or religious action has been longordained by God for the benefit of mankind".

 The utility and necessity of idolatry in some form arehere reiterated. The devotional acts by mind, word anddeed are said to expiate the sins committed by the respectiveorgans. Even in worldly transactions, this appears to be areasonable suggestion. In all the religious instructionsoffered, the removal of sins appears as the condition precedent to the attainment of real knowledge. Accumulationof more sins is never found mentioned anywhers, although,that is more or less what is being done on the plea ofVedantisin. If the modern civilized gentleman is howeverconvinced that he has no sius to atone for, he can very wellafford to ignore these teachings as superstitious and unscientific. But to the poor sinner, they are valuable asmeans to escape from the rigorous laws of Karma.

 **8.** Most philosophical and practical reasons areassigned for the necessity of Upasana or worship in theabove quotations and various reasonable and suitablemethods are prescribed for the benefit of mankind in general.The expiation of the sum total of sins voluntarily accumulated in the various births, is an unavoidable preliminarystep which cannot be got over by tricks or humbug. Quotation IV clearly defines the geography of Ayodhya asbeyond the regions of mundane existence. Several otherfamiliar names of places, persons and objects are similarlydescribed there. More of this shall be treated in their respective sections.

 We have by this time sufficiently investigate the significance of Bharata-varsha, now known only as the continentof India; and have clearly understood that it unequivocally

refers to the process of Upasana or worship performed inaccordance with the instructions obtained from the Vedas.We may now proceed with our enquiry regarding the application of terms now understood as denoting countries, townsan l holy centres within the boan laries of Bharata-Varsha.Wehave alreaty seen what Ayodhya mans. योद्धुं न शक्यतेइत्ययोद्धया. The invulnerable or not easily attainable stage.देवानां पूः अयोद्धया इति श्रुतिः। The seat of Gods is Ayodhya.

 For the main purpose of this little essay, the situationof Ayodhya detailed above will have to be particularlyremembered, with a view to understand the capital of thesovereigns of the Surya-vamsa or solar dynasty who aresaid to have ruled over Bharata-Varsha or so-called India.The next important place for the same reason, is Kurukshetram, Hastinapura or Delhi, the capital of the sovereigns ofthe Soma-vamsaor Lunar Dynasty. Bat there is a sort ofgeographical confusion in the description of Kurukshetromand the sacred Benares. Both of them will therefore haveto be treated together.

***Quotation. Nos. I & II.***

 "Kuru the son of Samvarana and Tapati created the sacred Kurukshethrom by his tapas". "At the end of thefirst quarter of the Treta-yuga, Kuru created Kurukshethrom",

 Here are two separate Kurus, creating Kurukshethromby tapas, one in the Treta and the other in the Dwapara-

yuga. How to account for this variation of description ? If Kurukshethrom has been created in the Treta-yuga, whyshould it again be created in the Dwapara? Why shouldthe names of both Rajas be the same as well as of theplaces? Which of the quotations is right and which wrong? Probably no answer is forthcoming. It would be an inconvenient digression here to go into a detail discussion, as thesubject would be explained fully in the subsequent chapters.Suffice it to note here that the Kuru and the Kurukshethromof the Dwapara-yuga refer to Karmayoga, and those of theTreta allude to Gnana-yoga.

***Q. No. III.***

 "Kurus and Bharatas refer to the performance of religious karmas which protect people from dangers. Thiscould be gathered from the derivation of the words".

 There is the Niruktom, one of the most importantVedangas giving the definitions of terms as used in thereligious texts. But the Pundit cares a straw for the definitions or the Vedanga itself. He has his own definitions.of terms ready made long ago to confound the poor people.It would indeed be interesting to know the percentage ofPandits who have looked into this Niruktom or even heardof it.

***Q. No. IV.***

 "Kurukshetra is Avimukta. It is the abode of Bramha,a place for worship even by the gods. It is situated between Varana and Nasi. Because it removes all the sins ofthe previous births, it is called Varana. That which destroys all the sins, committed through the senses is calledNasi. The junction of the nose and the eyes where theheaven and Para-loka meet, is the position of Avimukta orKurukshethra".

 This is the Upanishadic geography of Kurukshethraexplained in the Rama-tapini-upanishad. Here, the Kurukshethra of the Mahabharata and the Rama of the Ramayana are mentioned. Where are now the grand archæological theories of the Upanishadic and the Puranic periods?The whole of this Upanishad must of course be condemnedas anachronism. But what ism shall we call the wantonmisinterpretation of a sacred religious subject without itsstudy? It must be certainly placed under vandalism andthe apparent anachronisms will then immediately vanish.

***Q. No. V.***

 "Sri-parvata is located on the head; Kedara, on thefore-head; Varanasi, between the brows; Kurukshethra onthe breast; Prayag in the heart; Chidambara inside the  
heart and Kamalalaya at the naval. Everyone is purifiedby holy baths at these centres. To seek for holy bathsoutside the body is to exchange a gem for a crystal".

 More geography is here given in another Upanishad.What criticisms would be forthcoming here? Perhaps, theauthors of these Upanishads borrowed these names of placesfrom the Pandit to compose their texts. These names however have their appropriate meanings in the Upanishads andthe Pandit has hardly anything applying to them. Howcould the Pandit establish priority to his local names ascompared with the terms used in the Upanishads? ThePandit's cart is surely before his horse and his eyes, behindhis face. And that is all.

***Q. No. VI.***

 "Kurukshetra or Samanta-panchaka lies betweenTharanda and Karandaka, Ramahreda and Machakruka.It is the northern region of Bramha's abode. My Avimukta is a cremation ground where I destroy the whole  

Auniverse in the form of Kala or time. It is the highestsituation and ranks highamong Gnanas".

 A high situation and Gnana here specified cannot possibly refer to any limited area of space on the surface of thisearth. Again a cremation ground for the wholeuniversemust be outside the universe. The Pandit is likely to bestartled at these quotations, but it is impossible to destroythese texts to secure his pleasure, which virtually procuresonly dishonor for our ancient religion.

***Q. No. VII.***

 "My abode known as Avimukta is not on the earthbut is in the sky. The liberated alone can perceive it bymind and others cannot see. It is the cremation groundwhere I destroy the whole universe in the form of Kala ortime. Because I do not quit that place at any time, it is called Avimukta. It is the greatest secret among the secrets,a knowledge of which procures emancipation. Among thevarious importantAvimuktas enumerated by the gods suchas, those between the brows, in the naval, in the heart, inthe head and in the sun, Varanasi lying between Varanaand Asi is the highest. The eternal Tatwom is situatedthere and there is no position greater than that".

 This is a repetition of the last description in greaterdetail, some of the slokas being almost the same; and yet itis a pity that critics want to establish the existence ofcontradictory passages in our ancient religious texts. Avimukta or Varanasi is explained as the cremation ground forthe destruction of the universe and as the permanent seatof the Lord. It is stated to be the seat of the eternalTatwom and the greatest secret, a knowledge of which procures emancipation. From such plain philosophical descriptions, how does the Pandit arrive at the conclusion that thewhole of it refers to a town in India? Could it not as we॥  

apply to a donkey in his house ? Avimukta is clearlyaffirmed as no object on the surface of the earth, but assomething in the higher regions which beings of his typecannot hope to see. Let him therefore understand now atleast, that he has been all this time only blabbering aboutsomething, he was not qualified even to see.

***Q. No. VIII.***

 "The Upanishad says that Asi refers to the Ida Nadiand Varana to the Pingala Nadi. Between these two liesAvimukta which is the great Sushumna Nadi. These threecombined makes up Varanasi. It is proclaimed by thelearned in the Vedas, that Hara teaches the Tharakamanthra in the ears of those who happen to quit their livesseated in the Avimukta, and thereby procures them finalemancipation".

 The three Nadis here specified must doubtless be discovered in the human system and not outside, whatever maybe their real significance or scientific worth. The Panditwho misapplies them to earthly localities, is certainly not aBramha-vadi or knower of Vedas as noticed in the quotationitself, for such Bramhavadis are said to explain themdifferently. The Pandit's irrelevant opinion must thereforebe completely rejected as unauthorised. It is sometimesgloriously questioned by the civilized Hindu himself,whether the above Nadis could be perceived in the post-mortem examinations, naturally under the presumption thatthey represent tubular vessels in the body. It is in thismanner that every technical term in the literature is mis-understood without seeking for its proper application, as ifthe Sanskrit terms used can have only one meaning asunderstood by the common folk. The Nadis specified referto the currents of life breath and indirectly to the currentsof thought which are both absent in a dead body. The

civilized gentleman probably believes that everything nearand dear to him will be found in the human body afterdeath. A curious expectation indeed. The question of theseNadis will appear again in the treatment of Time in thesubsequent portion of this chapter.

***Q. No. IX.***

 "The following are the devine cremation grounds Rudrais very fond of namely, Mahakalavana, Avimukta, Ekamra, Bhadrakala, Karavira, Kolagiri, Kasi, Prayag, Amareswara,Bharatha, Kedara and Rudra-mahalaya. Smasana, Ushara, Kshetra, Pittha and Vana, all these five combined can be found only in Mahakalapura. Where all sins are expiatedis called Kshetra. The region of the divine mothers iscalled Pittha. Whence there is no rebirth is Ushara. Thatwhich the elements are fond of is Smasana".

 The definitions of the various terms here furnished in thegarb of geographical descriptions, clearly point to the destruction of sins and to the involutionary processes of devotional acts. The Pandit evidently has no interest inany ofthese matters and therefore interprets them as the geographyof India. In his joyous mood he might one day treat thewhole subject as the History of England. He is almightyand can do or undo things as he likes. All fools can also dothe same without much effort:

***Q. No. X.***

 "All those who dię in the Bramha-nala called Kasi willobtain through my help, eternal liberation without rebirth".

 Here Kasi is explained as Bramha-nadi. The Panditmight cut off this word from the text, if he happens to seeit. It is very lucky that he has hitherto missed such words.Let him ever miss them.

***Q. No. XI.***

 "Kasi is another name for theeternal Eswara from whom the divine light ever flows. Smasana means theplace at which everything lies dead, and Maha-smasınarefers to the destruction of all the elements at the time ofthe great Prakriti Prelaya. The description alludes to theeternal Eswara who alone remains after the Prakriti is annihilated. He is called by the wise as Vishnu the husband ofLekshmi and also as Siva the husband of Parvathi".

 The complete destruction of all the elements, thematerial cause of creation, is alluded to in the idea of Kasi.All materialities should vanish before the eternal light isseen.The modern interpreters ever swimming in the oceanof materialities can seldom hope to reach the sacred Kasimentioned in our religion. They have not yet learned itsgeography and they will not allow others to study it. Thepassages quoted above are so plain and so sensible thatthere is hardly any difficulty to understand them in theirproper light. The only dangerous barrier at present is the  
ignorant and impertinent persistence of the uncivilizedPandit. His uncalled for and presumptuous interference inoffering his preposterous interpretations has doubtless beenthe real cause of all the present degeneration of the poorreligious Hindu. It is unfortunately a pitiable fact in thismaterial world that the evil work of a single mischievousperson often affects many a poor and innocent being.

**दुर्वृत्तसङ्गतिरनर्थपरम्पराया  
हेतुः सतां भवति किं वचनीयमेतत्।  
लङ्केश्वरो हरति दाशरथेःकलत्रं  
प्राप्नोति बन्धमथ दक्षिणसिन्धुराजः॥**

***Q. Nos. XII & XIII.***

 "Beetween the brows is the lotus called Augna in themiddle of which, the subtle mind is located, within which

lies the pure intellect, within which again is the light ofAtman in the form of the bright Pranava. Above this lotus isthe lotus of Gnana in two petals, the region of the full-moon.Siva in the form of Hamsa is seated inside this Mani-Dwipaor the island built of gems. On the left side of Easwara isseated the divine, eternal and blissful mother known asSidha-kali who creates the universe. The Yogis at the timeof their departure carry their life-breath to this holy centreby the force of Yoga and pass on to the divine and eternalPurusha".

 This is a Yogic description of the geography underreference. It is a scientific treatment demanding some sortof technical study to understand clearly. But for our presentpurpose, it is sufficiently plain so as to convince us of thefact that neither the Pandit nor the critic has as yet understood our religious texts in their proper light. All thecurrent interpretations and criticisms are therefore entirelyirrelevant and must be rejected. The whole subject shouldbe studied anew, if its real significance should be knownand any profitable use made of it. As it is, it is only awaste of time to deal with it, and it may even be reasonablycriticised as superstition or worse still. But let us understand clearly by the enquiries hitherto made, that it is thePandit and not the literature the fit object for all thesecriticisms.

 **9.** Numerous additional quotations could be easilycollected to show that the terms, Kasi, Varanasi, Kurukshethrom, Avimuktom, Maha-smasanom &e., all point toone and the same nervous centre known to the Yogi asAgna-chakra. It refers clearly to the spot between theeye-brows where, Agna or a little gnana or knowledge of the

Absolute is procurable. Meditation at this Chakra or centreis prescribed for practice after necessary training on fiveChakras below, which deal with the five material elementsin their pure and unmixed state. Mahat-tatwa, Satwa-budhi or pure mind is said to be located in this spot, the meditation of which in the prescribed method is described asproductive of the means of attaining higher stages still. Theimportance of this nervous centre, I dare say is being recognised in modern days in the physiological and psychological sciences. We may hopefully expect many a moderndiscovery in this sphere, to be found in our ancient literature,not only as predicted but as completely utilized for mostimportant purposes. More of this shall be detailed later on.Some more important terms like the above which throw further light on the main topic may be explained by thefollowing quotations.

***Quotation. No. I.***

 "Adhara is known as a centre in the lower extremityof the spinal column. It is the seat of the gods, vedas andof creation. To the west of this Adhara is the confluence ofthe Thriveni or three rivers, bathing where man expiateshis sins".

 The Pandit's confluence at Allahabad is not certainly thejunction of the three rivers here specified in the human body.All the three rivers will be pointed out by the Yogi hereand the significance of their names will be explained by him;but the Pandit will miss one of the rivers at Allahabad andhe has absolutely nothing to say about them except thatthey are big rivers where a large number of Hindus go and  
bathe. His explanation is doubtless overflowing with religious and scientific informations. His overboldness in talking such nonsense with an air of authority exhibits the depthof his ignorance and the worthlessness of his prolific explanations.

***Quotation. No. II.***

 "Prayaga is the seat of Bramha and it is made by theGods, by combining the three subtle elements, earth, waterand fire".

 The three rivers and their confluence are clearly explained here, but the Pandit cannot of course catch themeaning of the explanation, simply because he has never

heard of the subject in his life time. For that very reasonhe feels confident that he is qualified to interpret the contentsof the unknown text. He represents a curious and unknownspecies of human creations.

***Q. No. III.***

 "If you churn or destroy the existing cosmology by theknowledge of Bramhan, that which afterwards remainspertaining to me, is called Mathura".

 The eternal divine element that remains after the elimination of all materiality is clearly specified by Mathura. ThePandit must therefore identify the same with somethingmaterial, without the least respect or consideration for thereligious instructions conveyed by the Upanishad. He is avery religious personage indeed!.

***Q. No. IV.***

 "Mathura, the sole seat of Vishnu is a lotus of thousandpetals, and it is as large as the Vishnu-chakra in its extent.When man becomes purified by Tapas, Dhyana and otherdevotional acts, he perceives this my favourite town; othersfail to see searching for it even for ages. The residents ofMathura are greater beings than even the gods and they arevery powerful. All of them possesses four hands".

 This is another geography of Mathura. Its extent isthe same as that of the Vishnu-chakra and it is in the formof a lotus of thousand petals. Does the Pandit understandanything by this description and will he kindly show us this lotus? It is said that no irreligious person could see it.The Pandit with all his boasted qualifications, is after allonly an irreligious person unfit to perceive this Mathura.Has he at least seen any of its inhabitants during theirtravel outside, and has he found any of them possessingfour hands? Has he any idea of what these four hands

mean? Perhaps the residents of Mathura are all of themgraduates of the University of Allahabad and the four handsrefer to their wearing the University gowns. Evidently thePandit has not studied the geography of Mathura properly.The original geography itself is available for us and he maytherefore keep his commentaries to himself.

***Q. No. V***

 "The lotus from which Brahma originated came out ofPadma-sarovara which is known as Pushkara-kshetra."

 The Pandit often appears in his interpretations like theoil-monger in the Indian fable.  Does the modern Pandit still stand in need of furtherexplanations to convince him of his egregious mistake, in theinterpretations he volunteers ? **अज्ञात्वा ग्रन्थतत्वानि वादं यः कुरुते नरः।  
लोभाद्वाप्यथवा दम्भात् स पापी नरकं व्रजेत्॥**

***Q. No. VII.***

 "From that eternal entity, Radha-Krishna originatedwho after performing tapas for a thousand Yugas, divided himself into Radha and Krishna. Both of them, then separately performed tapas for a thousand Yugas, and from thebodies of both proceeded a bright light destroying darkness,from which the divine Brindavana originated. 21 Prakritisextending to 4 yojanas each, make the 84 yojanas of Brindavana. From the Prakritis of the ten senses, ten villages

originated, namely, Gokula, Varshabha, Nanda, Bhandira,Mathura, Vreja, Yamuna, Manya, Sreyaska and Gowpika. From the Prakritis of the ten elements, ten forests sprungup, namely, Brinda, Gopa, Behula, Madhusringa, Kunja,Vana, Dedhi, Mahakreda, Remya and Venupadma. Fromthe Prakriti of mind, the Govardana mountain originated".

 The religious evolutionary processes downwards fromPrakriti and Purusha, or Radha and Krishna are here explained. It may be easily noticed here that the conceptionsof these 21 items in the philosophical analysis of humancosmology, as existing in their pure and unmixed condition,are alluded to in all these descriptions. They are reckonedas the glories forming part and parcel of the Lord in Hissaguna form. They represent the highest philosophical conclusions arrived at by the most practical and scientific psychological analysis. Meditation of these highly abstract factsas displaying the glories of the Almighty, is invariablyprescribed throughout the religious literature of ours. Without clearly understanding the real import of this sacred andscientific subject, reckless criticisms are unnecessarily hurledupon it under the mistaken impression that the whole of itis idolatry. It may be, for ought we know that it is aprocess yet unknown to the Westerns, but that in itself, is noargument against its real worth. In the Western scientific division of human cosmology into mind and matter, subjectand object, the former naturally gets the predominance, andthe methods of studying both are entirely different. Themodern criticisms generally proceeding from the materialscientists against mental facts, without their proper study,cannot but be irrelevant and unscientific. The materialscientist has not the monopoly for everything in this world,and the knowledge accruing from the study of his subject  
has its own limits as that acquired from any other branch of

study. Mind is not matter and God is not man. Mindcreates and destroys matter as God creates and destroys man. The one is independent and the other is dependent. Thescientist forgets these eternal facts, when he aggressivelytrespasses upon these sacred grounds.

**ईशकार्यं जीवभोग्यं जगद्वाभ्यां समन्वितम्।  
पितृजन्या भर्तृभोग्या यथा योषित्तथेष्यताम्॥**

 The psycholical and religious processes for transition fromthe material to the spiritual sphere are here scientificallyprescribed. We have already noticed in the last chapterin detail, that in our philosophy, both mind and matter fallunder Prakriti, in which all the items are classified into twogeneral divisions, the pure and the impure. The existingmodern psychological and physical sciences resolve themselves into the impure variety. The detail heads of the purevariety are the same as those in the impure variety, but theircharacter and working are entirely different, being opposedto the meterialistic tendencies of the other. The pure itemsare alone reckoned as Tatwoms and glories of Suguna-bramhan. The impure varieties constituting the western psychology and physical sciences are treated as the products of Prakriti in its aspect as Avidya. All that pertains to this Avidya will evolve and produce never ending misery, and allthat constitutes the pure Tatwoms, involves and leads to emancipation. The existing creation, combined as it is with a largeamount of wickedness and misery, is attributed in our religious literature to the work of Prakriti as Avidya, andnever represented as the glories of God. The special Tatwoms descrided in the above passage are alone recognised asHis glories. Otherwise, the all merciful God as guaged bythe impure category, must also be pronounced to be all-cruel,allwise must be all-stupid and all-powerful must be all-weak.

Our ancient religion humble and simple as it is, is free from all these dangers of civilization.

***Q. No. VIII.***

 "Mathura where Hari incarnates, was perceived in theheart.Kasi was found between the brows, Maya in theAdhara, Kanchi, below the naval, Avanti at the naval,Dwaraka and Prayag at the throat, Ganga and Yemuna oneither side of it and Saraswathi in their midst. Gaya wasfound in the face, Prabhasa between the chin and the throat,Bedari in the head, and Poundravardhana and Nepal in theeyes".

 Descriptions of this sort furnish the necessary clues tounderstand the gist of the subject. The names of localitiesif properly understood would be found to be exclusivelyappropriate termsfor the technical facts specified. They are neither meaningless nor borrowed from the names of placesin India. The holy baths and temples, now existing in Indiawere named after the terms in the religious texts as most ofthe Hindus are given the various names of Gods. ThePandit's cart has of recent years become so troublesome thatit always gets before the horse and the Pandit goes behindit and almost misses the horse. He has virtually lost hiscontrol over both, but vainly pretends to own the cart.

***Q. No. IX.***

 "This is the philosophical exposition of Gayatri. Gayameans Prana or life and that which saves it is Gayatriknown also as Savitri".

 Here we are plainly told the real meaning of Gaya, asreferring to one's own life. The Sradhas and other religiousceremonies pertaining to this sacred Gaya, clearly allude tothe saving of one's life from sins leading to perdition. Gaya isalways pointed out to the north specifying the Gnana-marga

to be necessarily followed by man. The Pandit's idea ofGaya and Sradha is always concentrated in the bread andcake that would fill his stomach.

***Q. No. X.***

 "The wise name it Dwaraka, because it contains plentyof Dwaras, openings or door-ways. for the admission ofDharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha. The residents ofDwaraka both males and females possess four hands".

 The whole of this is inexplicable to the Panditand doubtless appears absurd and ridiculous to the irresponsible critic. What enlightenment could we hope to obtain from either under the circumstances? Absolutely none,and how long are we expected to recognise them as ourreligious guides? Dwaraka clearly refers to the purifiedheart of man ready to receive all devotional acts. The fourhands constantly mentioned allude to the exact extent orcapacity of the devotional spirit. The number of handspoints out the limits within which the devotee is qualified towork.

**सत्वं रजस्तम इति अहङ्कारश्चतुर्भुजः॥**

 'Satwa, Reja, Tama and Ahamkara make up the four hands'.A devotee who still retains his egoism must ply within thebounds of the three gunas specified. It is a particular stagein the worship of Saguna-bramhan. The Dwaraka and thefour hands are not therefore meaningless absurdities as unhesitatingly criticised.

***Q. No. XI.***

 "Where the Maya of Vishnu fails to exercise her control over man by keeping him bound by material desires, itis called Mayapura, Haridwar, Mokshadwar and Gangadwar. It is the first step in the ladder to Vykuntha.Bathing here leads to the highest region of Vishnu".

 The definition of Haridwar and its synonymous termsare sufficiently plain. The destruction of worldly desires isthe first step to the devotional path. When one has qualified himself so far, he has reached Haridwar or Mokshadwar.An irreligious and wicked dunce going by rail to Haridwarin Upper India lies certainly far away from the Gangadwarand Mokshadwar here specified. The Pandit may here beinformed if necessary, that the train which takes him toHaridwar will not carry him further to Vykuntha. Hisfaith in the religious text which he is determined to misunderstand, will only make him all the more miserable. Hislearned colleagues in the village will explain the subject tohim more fully. They readily expound that losing one'slife is going to Vykuntha, and that is certainly a surer andmore convenient process.

***Q. No. XII.***

 "The Ida Nadi, which is Siva's Sakti, Kala or power,is known as Narmada which destroys sin and procuresliberation".

 It is plainly explained here that Narmada is anothername for Ida Nadi. It is therefore its original significancein the religious literature. There must be some cogentreason for calling a particular river in India by that sacredname. That is not questioned anywhere in this essay. Whysome of the rivers and temples in India are consideredsacred to the Hindu will be shortly explained in this section.But it must be clearly understood that the text here speaksonly of the sacredness of the Ida Nadi and not that of theIndian river. A religious and pious Hindu in America orGreat Britain, wiser than the Pandit, would be quite welcome to name a river there as Narmada in honour of thisIda Nadi. The Pandit has no right to question his piety orprivilege.

***Q. No. XIII.***

 "Many divine rivers with plenty of waters have sprungfrom the divine lakes. TheAkasa or sky which is thesupport for the elements and the Gods, isitself theocean herecalled Soma. The divine holy river known as Akasa ganga,starts from thisAkasa and runs through the same. Itpasses through the regions of air and stars, playing about inall directions. Its holy waters are used by the Siddhas.Like the sun it appears and reappears every day'.

 It is a fine description of Ganga. The Akasa calledalso Soma is the subtle element known as Akasa in ourreligious philosophy. The waters of this river are said tobe available only for the Sidhas. The Pandit therefore in his present attitude towards our religious texts cannot hopeto obtain a drop of its holy waters.

***Q. No. XIV.***

 "The holy waters of the Ganga are the liquid forms ofVishnu and of Siva. Ganga is the Prakriti and the supportof Bramhandas. She represents Sudha-vidya, Sudha dharmaand the form of Para-bramhan. Siva keeps her on his headfor the sake of protecting the universe. Siva extracted theessence of the Yoga-upanishad and converted into this Gangafor the benefit of mankind".

 This supplies additional explanation on the constitutionof Ganga. It is clearly stated to be the essence of Yogarepresenting Sudha-vidya and Sudha-dharma. Our sacredGanga is therefore full of technical importance and deservesto be studied very carefully, without of course being misledby the Pandit and the Critic, who have evidently lost theirclaims to approach this Ganga of our ancient religion.

***Q. No. XV.***

 "The Agni or fire known as Samsya, Havya-vahanaand Ahavaniya in our religion, fell in love with the follow-

ing sixteen rivers; Kaveri, Krishnaveni, Narmada, Yemuna,Godavari, Vitasta, Chandrabiaga,Iravati, Vipin, Kousiki,Satadru, Sarayu, Sita, Saraswati, Hradini and Pavani".

 That a fire falling in love with a number of rivers cannot be literally interpreted, is a fact any ordinary personcan understand, except perhaps the learned Pandit. Thename of the fire is technically significant, and it is describedhere in detail as Ahavaniya. The Pandit however knows itonly as a fire lighted in a pot with paddy husk. There arethree kinds of fire mentioned in the religious literature.They are said to be located in three parts of the humanbody. Ahavaniya is in the face, Garhapathya in thestomach and Dekshinagni in the heart.

**त्रीणि स्थानानि भवन्ति मुखे आहवनीय उदरे गार्हपत्यो हृदि दक्षिणाभिः॥**

 When the specific reference of these fires and similarly ofthe rivers are ascertained by studying the texts, the passagequoted here will be full of meaning. It is a technicalsubject which neither the Pandit nor the Critic can ever hopeto understand by sheer pretension and insolence. We mighthowever for our present purpose be assured that the fire herementioned does not refer to the one burning in the Pandit'spot as it could not possibly marry a river which containswater. Fire thrown into a river would immediately beextinguished. The rivers also similarly could not refer toany running streams in India. In spite of all this, thePandit must maintain the fire as fire, and rivers as rivers inIndia. May God bless his brains.

** 10.** The descriptions of places, forests, hills andrivers in the above quotations are sufficiently explicit as towhat they do not represent. They are stated to be heavenlyand not earthly. Several of them are specified as seated in

the human body. The sources of heavenly rivers enumerated are traced to the sky and the fire. The plainness andclearness of such descriptions found, page after page, in thevarieties of ancient literature, without in the least contradicting one another, are so tempting that every line inducesone to reiterate the criticism as to the depth of ignoranceexhibited in the modern reckless interpretations. It isevident that the mistakes primarily originate from sheerignorance, and subsequent perversity, from pride and inpertinence.

 The subjoined is a quotation from Suprabheda agama.The Agamas are more directly in touch with such matters,as they always deal with more practical and ceremonialportions of religious and philosophical subjects. The passagehere, quoted completely specifies the significance and application of all the preceding descriptions. The whole of itrefers to the Upasana-marga, detailing the higher glories ofGod, apart from those connected with the earthy and transient cosmology with which the ordinary worldly-wise manis at present acquainted. It is a geography of the higherand purer sphere of existence, if geography it should be  
styled. The two geographies have nothing in common, nay,they are diametrically opposed to each other. Confoundingthe two is doubtless a sin, as it is virtually denying thehigher one, which alone is capable of giving us any safeabode. How the modern interpreters will therefore fare inthe light of these sacred passages reproduced here, I leavethe readers to think well and judge for themselves. Themost charitable view that can be taken in the matter is, thatthe task of these misinterpreters is unnecessary and unprofitable, if not uncalled for.

"Fools rush in where angels fear to tread".

**अध्वानं षड्विधं प्रोक्तंतत्त्वाध्वादि विनायक।  
तत्त्वाध्वा प्रथमं विद्धि भुवनाध्वा द्वितीयकम्।  
मन्त्राध्वावै तृतीयन्तु वर्णाध्वा वै चतुर्थकम्।  
पदाध्वा पञ्चमं ज्ञेयं कलाध्वा षष्ठमं स्मृतम्।  
षड्विधैरध्वभिर्मार्गैःसंविशेदेकमीश्वरम्।  
तत्वाध्वानं समासेन भूकटाहादिकं शृणु।  
पृथिव्यादीनि मायान्तम्अध्वानं वर्ण्यते क्रमात्।  
कालाग्नेःशतरुद्रान्तं ब्रह्माण्डमति संस्मृतम्।  
कालाग्निरुद्रदेवस्य तस्योर्ध्वे भुवनं विदुः।  
लोकालोकस्वनाम्नातुपर्वतं वृत्तरूपतः।  
लोकपाला स्थितास्तत्र सिद्धामरनिषेविताः।  
तस्यान्तर्भासते सूर्यस्त्वन्धकारस्तथापरः।  
लोकालोकस्समावृत्य गर्भोदधि समुद्रकान्।  
गर्भोदधि समावृत्य पार्थिवावरणं स्मृतम्।  
पार्थिवन्तु समावृत्य कटाहं कोटिविस्तृतम्।  
कटाहं मेरुमध्यान्तं पञ्चाशत्कोटयः स्मृताः।  
कटाहेस्य घनं कोटिःपञ्चाशत्कोटयः स्मृताः।  
भूलोकश्चसमाख्यातो भुवलोकं ततः शृणु।  
लक्षयोजनमानेन सूर्यलोकं विधीयते।  
द्वादशादित्य वसवो रुद्राश्चैकादशस्तथा।  
अश्विनौ द्वौ स्त्रयस्त्रिंशत् सञ्चरन्ति शिवेच्छया।  
मेरुप्रदक्षिणेनैव भुवलोकमिति स्मृतम्।  
तस्योपरि तु लक्षेणचन्द्रलोकं विधीयते।  
चन्द्रोर्ध्वेलक्षमात्रेण स्थितन्नक्षत्रमण्डलम्।  
लक्षद्वये बुधं विद्यात् द्विलक्षे भार्गवः स्मृतः।  
लक्षद्वये तु चाङ्गारो द्विलक्षे तु बृहस्पतिः।  
सौरिर्लक्षद्वयो प्रोक्तोमुनयो लक्षयो जने।  
अत्रिश्चैववसिष्ठश्च पुलस्त्यः पुलहः क्रतुः।  
भृग्वङ्गिरा मरीचिश्व मुनयस्सप्त कीर्तिताः।  
उपरिष्टात् ध्रवः प्रोक्तस्त्वेकलक्षप्रमाणतः।**

**चन्द्रलोकात् ध्रुवान्तश्च स्वर्लोकामति कीर्तितम्।  
दशपञ्च च लक्षाणि भूतष्पृष्ठात् ध्रुवान्तकम्।  
ततोपरि महर्लोकं द्विकोटियोजनं स्मृतम्।  
पञ्चाशीति च लक्षाणि जनलोकमिति स्मृतम्।  
अष्टकोटि तपोलोकं उपर्युपरि संस्थितम्।  
द्वादशैव तथा कोटिस्सत्यलोकं विधीयते।  
महर्लोकादि सत्यान्तं रुद्रास्तत्र निवासिनः।  
कोटिषोडशमानेन ब्रह्मलोकं विधीयते।  
कोटियोजनमानेन विष्णुलोकं प्रकीर्तितम्।  
नवकोटिप्रमाणेन रुद्रलोकमिहोच्यते।  
प्रोक्तोयं पृथिवी पश्चात् आप्यं तत्वमतः शृणु।  
ब्रह्माण्डपरितस्थाप्य दद्यात् दशगुणावृतम्।  
अमरेशं प्रभावञ्च नैमिशं पुष्करं तथा।  
आषाढीशञ्च पिण्डीशं हारभूतश्च वाकुलम्।  
प्रोष्टं गुह्याष्टकं ह्येवं जलावरणमाश्रितम्।  
ऊर्ध्वे दशगुणेनैव वह्ने रावरणं महत्।  
हरिश्चन्द्रं सुशैलञ्च जल्पेरम्रातिकेश्वरम्।  
महाकालं मध्यमञ्च केदारं भैरवं तथा।  
अतिगुह्माष्टकं ह्येवम्अग्न्यावरणमाश्रितम्।  
वाय्वावरणमूर्ध्वे तु वह्नेर्दशगुणं महत्।  
गया चैव कुरुक्षेत्रं नखलं नाखलं तथा।  
विमलञ्चाट्टहासश्च महेन्द्रं भीम एव च।  
गुह्याद्गुह्याष्टकं ह्येवम्अनिलावरणे स्थितम्।  
तदूर्ध्वन्तु भवेद्व्योम स्थितं दशगुणावृतम्।  
वस्त्रापदं रुद्रकोटि रविमुक्तं महालयम्।  
गोकर्णं भद्रकर्णञ्चसुवर्णाक्षञ्च स्थाणुकम्।  
पवित्राष्टकमेवं हि व्योमावरणमाश्रिताः।  
अतः ऊर्ध्वमहङ्कारं स्थितं दशगुणेन तु।  
खगलेन्दु करण्डञ्चोमाकोटि मण्डलेश्वरम्।  
कौञ्जरं शङ्कुकर्णञ्च स्थूलेश्वरं स्थलेश्वरम्।**

**स्थानाष्टकमिदं विद्यात् पूर्वाद्यैश्शान्तकं स्थितम्।  
श्वेतगुह्याष्टकं प्रोक्तं रक्तं चैवा जुगुप्सितम्।  
गुह्यात्गुह्याष्टकं पीतं कृष्णश्चैव पवित्रकम्।  
स्थानाष्टकं स्फटीकाभं एवं पञ्चाष्टकं स्मृतम्।  
पृथिव्यापस्तथा तेजो वायुराकाशमेव च।  
अहङ्कारस्तथा बुद्धिर्गुणमव्यक्तमेव च।  
रागत्वञ्च ततस्तस्मिन् दशपञ्चेन्द्रियाणि च।  
विद्या काल कला माया आत्मानन्तु तथैव च।  
शुद्धविद्या च सादाख्यं बिन्दुनादं तथैव च।  
द्वितीयं शक्तितत्त्वञ्चप्रथमं शक्तिमेव च।  
षट्त्रिंशत्तत्त्वमेतानि शिवतत्वोद्भवा इह।  
ब्रह्माण्डं पृथिवी ज्ञेया प्रकृत्यं जलकं स्मृतम्।  
तेजो विद्यान्तमेवं हि वायुस्सदाशिवान्तकम्।  
व्योम शक्त्यन्तमेषां वै पञ्चतत्वेषु संस्थितम्।  
एतानि पञ्चतत्त्वानि सुतत्वे तु स्थितानि तु।  
मायान्तानि च तत्त्वानि शिवतत्वमुदीरितम्।  
विद्यातत्त्वादिशक्त्यन्तं विद्यातत्त्वमिति स्मृतम्॥**

**सुप्रभेदागमम्॥**

 “The Adhwas, means or methods are of six sorts,namely, Tatwa, Bhuvana, Manthra, Varna, Pada and Kala.By these six processes, the Eswara who is single may beknown. The first one, Tatwa-adhwa begins with thesubtle element, the earth, and extends to Maya. This Prithivi or earth includes all the divine Lokas. The Bhu-lokais 50 koti yojanas in extent. Bhuva-loka extends roundthe Meru and contains the Sun's loka of Leksha yojanas.The Moon's loka is Leksha yojanas above the sun. Thestarry regions, Leksha yojanas above the moon. Budha orMercury is 2 Leksha yojanas above. Bhargava or Venus is2 Leksha yojanas above. Angara or Mars is still 2 Lekshayojanas above. Brihaspathi or Jupiter is again 2 Leksha

yojanas above. Souri or Saturn is still 2 Leksha yojanashigher. The Sapta-rishis, namely, Atri, Vasishta, Pulasthya,Pulaha, Kretu, Angira and Marichi are a Leksha yojanasabove. Dhruva or the Polar star is a Leksha yojanas higherstill. From the Moon to Dhruva is Swar-loka. AboveSwar-loka is Mahar-loka of 2 koti yojanas. Above it isJena-loka of 85 Leksha-yojanas. Then Tapo-loka of 8 kotiyojanas. Above it is Satya-loka of 12 koti yojanas. Fromthe Mahar to Satya, Rudras reside. Above these is Bramha-loka of 16 koti yojanas. Above it is Vishnu-loka of 1 kotiyojanas. Above still is Rudra-loka of 9 koti yojanas. Allthe above Lokas put together make up Prithivi-tatwom.Ten times greater in extent is Water-tatwa all round thePrithivi. The following are situated within it, namely,Ameresa, Prabhava, Nimisa, Pushkara, Ashadhisa, Pindisa,Harabhuta and Vakula. Ten times still larger is the encirclement by fire, within which lie, Harischandra, Susyla.Jelpera, Amratikeswara, Mahakala, Madhyama, Kedara andBhyrava. Ten times greater again is Air-tatwa withinwhich lie, Gaya, Kurukshethra, Nakhala, Naakhala Vimala,  
Attahasa, Mahendra and Bhima. Ten times this air isAkasa within which lie, Vastrapada, Rudrakoti, Avimukta,Mahalaya, Gokarna, Bhadra-karna, Suvarnaksha and Sthanuka. Ten times greater still is the encirclement of Aham-kara, within which lie, Khagalendu, Karanda, Umakoti,Mandaleswara Kounjara,Sankukarna,Sthuleswara and Staleswara. The following is the list of 36 Tatwas originating fromSivatatwom, the 5 subtle elements, Ahamkara, Budhi, Guna,Avyakta, Raga, 15 senses, Vidya, Kala, Maya, Atma, Sudha-vidya, Sadakhya, Bindu, Nada and 2 Saktis. Bramhandais known as Prithivi, and Prakriti is known as water. Up toVidhya is fire-tatwa, up to Sadasiva is Air-tatwa, up toSakti is Akasa-tatwa, up to Maya is Siva-tatwa and up toSakti is Vidya-tatwa".

 An ordinary lay man could easily feel here the highlytechnical smell of the subject. Most of the proper namesintroduced in the passage quoted, are entirely unknown andmeaningless to the Pandit, Critic and Theosophist, and yetthey would venture to catch some of them from the middleof the description and attempt to make some silly and shameless use of them. The treatment of the subject however, istoo plain, to deceive any one possessing common sense, byextraneous explanations. The whole of it is clearly statedas representing the 36 religious Tatwams. In the astronomical description given here the Moon is placed far abovethe Sun, but it will be invariably found so described in allthe Puranas and Itihasas without mutual contradictions.This might certainly form a fit subject for the exercise ofthe ingenious brain of the Pandit who is likely to go so far as to establish that in Puranic times, the Moon was stationedabove the sun. Volumes might be written on the contraryby the Critic on the Indian ignorance of astronomicalsubjects, until they were learnt from the Greeks, Romansor even the Red Indians. The point in question will bedeferred for subsequent treatment as these unsympatheticelucidators will hardly find anything very interesting tothem here. There are several other important matters whichmany ordinary people may take for serious scientific factsyet unknown to the Western scientist. These collateralobservations may perhaps be rejected as vain hopes emanating from superstitious beliefs; let us therefore leave themhere and proceed with the main subject.

 In the apparently geographical form of descriptiondetailed in the above passages, the general schemeis prescribed for religious meditations on the higher glories of theCreator. It should be carefully noticed and rememberedhere that the Bramhanda as described is beyond the possible

cosmological conception of ordinary man. It includes the14 Lokas explained above, but in itself extends only to atenth fraction of the sum total of earthy element. Encircling this earthy element, lies the element of water ten timesgreater in extent. Within this environment, the familiarnames, Nimisa, Pushkarom &c. are found, and are probablysignificant as Thirthas or holy baths. Similarly round theelement of water, the region of fire is described ten timesgreater in extent. Within this also several names appear,such as Harischandram, Kedarom &c., and they may besignificant as cremation grounds. Beyond fire is the environment of air, within which Gaya, Kurukshetrom &c., aredescribed as situated, and they may be significant as connected with Prana-yama or regulation of breath. Beyondair is the encirclement by sky or ether, within which Avimuktom, Mahalayam, Gokarnam &c. are mentioned, andthey may be significant as higher states still. Beyond ether  
is the encirclement of Ahamkara or Egoism ten times geeaterin extent. The whole of this geography is clearly stated.in the latter part of the quotaion as referring directly to the36 Tatwas well-known in the philosophical analysis. Virtually, all these signify the higher states of mind and intellect, developed and purified, by religious meditations, alwaysof course accompanied by the strictest practice of the highestmorals.

 The chief object aimed at in this little volume beingonly to get at the right method of interpretation and not anexhaustive treatment of even a portion of the subject, thepresent section dealing with the so-called Indian Geographymay well be closed here. But the modern ignorance andperversion exhibited in the interpretation of this religiousgeography is so great that it might be necessary and useful,to summarise the import of the passages hitherto quoted, forconstant reference.

** (1)** The religious geography has absolutely nothing todo with India or even the mother earth as a full globe. Itdeals with far more serious and subtler facts.

**ऊर्ध्व धरायाः भूर्लोकः भुवर्लोकस्ततः परः॥**

 **(2)** The Jambu-Dwipa, in the middle of the sevenislanded earth, is the devotional sphere mentioned in our religion and has no reference to any earthy or materialstuff.

**जम्बूद्वीपस्य संस्थानं यज्ञिया यत्र वैक्रियाः॥**

 **(3)** The Bharata-varsha, one of the nine divisions ofthis Jambu-Dwipa, represents the Karına-kanda or sphereof religious Karmas ordained for the pious Hindu.

 **(4)** The 14 Lokas making up the Bramhanda is onlyene-tenth of the Prithivi or earth described in the Puranas.

 **(5)** Round this Prithivi-tatwom is the Water-tatwomten times greater than the Prithivi and is said to containthe Puranic Nimisa, Pushkara etc.

 **(6)** Similarly ten times greater in extent is each of theremaining elemental Tatwoms, Ahamkara, Budhi etc. In each of these, several of the Puranic centres are mentioned.

 This is the plain description of our technical religiousgeography, dealing with the pure devine Tatwoms prescribed for religious and philosophical meditation on the realglories of God. Tatwom means 'That-ness' or that whichpertains to the real and eternal Eswara. The Pandit whounnecessarily meddles with our religious literature cannotapproach the Tatwoms without philosophical study andthought. He thus ignorantly reduces them to his villagegeography which is ordinarily dirty and unhealthy. He

has not yet secured the first Bhumi among the seven enumerated for the religious Hindu. He is not even in theBharata-varsha, which as a matter of grace, he is allowed tomention in the Samkalpa of his religious cermonies. Hemust open his eyes now, if he does not wish to sink deeperstill in degeneration. At any rate, he has no rights, legal,political, social or religious, to drag the innocent religiousHindu to the mire of his ignorance and force him to bedrowned with him. The foreign Critic, the civilized Hinduwho is his apish imitator and the Theosophical juggler, whowere all originally deceived and misled by the learnedPandit, might now honourably retire from the field carryingthe Pandit with them if they choose. It is certainly nomatter for disgrace, as all men are apt to err in this materialworld. The Pandit doubtless has however been originallythe cause of all this present confusion, and his mistakes arehere exposed with the best available evidence and authority.It is absurd to criticise the science of Arithmetic on accountof a problem mistakenly worked out by its student. Themistaken impressions regarding our religious geographyhave become current only through the ignorant interpretations of our veritable Pandit. Let him now be once for alldismissed from the council of religious advisers in India, andlet more respectable members bè substituted. Amen!

** 11.** The next point demanding enquiry is thedescription given in our ancient literature regarding Time ascalculated by Yugas and their cycles. But before commencing with this, it may be necessary to say something about

the existing and recognised Thirthas or Holy baths in India,as they still stand an inexplicable riddle, especially after theelaborate treatment of their geography in the precedingpages. It cannot but be confessed here, that, with ourpresent limited knowledge of the subject as a whole, thepassages from sacred texts reproduced above, serve, more orless, only as destructive elucidations rather than constructive.The difficulty and confusion here is nothing new. Theyhave been unconsciously caused all along, by our venerablePandits, as repeatedly observed, by misunderstanding thehigher and lower application of the intended object. TheThirthas themselves are distinctly classified as Manasa andBhowma, mental and physical, internal and external, theformer being certainly recognised as more important thanthe latter. ***Q. No. II.***

 Snana or religious bath means removal of mentalimpurity and soucha or cleanliness means controlling thesenses. Merely washing the body with water and clay isbut the worldly bath. The dirt of egoism sticking on allover the body should be washed away by the water and clay,of gnana or knowledge, and vyragya or freedom frompassion. The meditation of the Tatwas is the highest, studyof the Sastras ranks next and that of Manthras is thelast. The mania for the external holy baths is the lowest."

***Q. No. III.***

 "The internal Thirthas are more important than theexternal ones. Atma-thirtha is the highest, all the rest areuseless. Bathing in the external Thirthas with an evil mindinside, never procures purity. A pot containing toddy neverbecomes pure by any amount of washing outside".

 Thirtha generally means a remedy, means or expedient.In religion, it especially refers to all the processes of purification prescribed. The term is applied therefore to both internal and external purifications The modern mistakelies in interpreting it as dealing with the external purifications alone. From the above quotations, we have seen thatthe external processes as such, are of no avail, unless accompanied by internal purifications. The texts speak veryclearly on the point, and the modern interpreters thereforeboldly explain otherwise.

** 12.**The extreme importance of moral rectitude, charity and sincere religious devotion is established by theabove passages as opposed to hypocracy and mere externalcleanliness. In spite of the very strong language used inthese quotations, it is however a very interesting point tonote, how the idea of baths in holy centres as a religioussubstitute for, or a supplement to, the canons enunciatedabove, struck the ancients, in the interest of the lower ordersof society. ** 13**. The above passages deserve and demand themost patient and careful scrutiny; and it must be emphatically affirmed that they do not confirm or even corroboratethe current interpretations, assigning historical importanceto the Holy centres in India and connecting them with specific descriptions found in the Puranas and Itihasas, takingthem as representing places of historical incidents. In theface of the so-called geography examined already, it is unnecessary at this stage to reiterate the arguments for theconviction of any reasonable being as to the absurdity andirrelevancy of the modern views. The only point for useful enquiry here would be to trace the causes that led to thesemistakes.

 We have seen all along, that the procedure adopted inour sacred literature was to descend step by step from thehighest philosophical truths to suit the varying intellectualcapacities of man, without at the same time losing sight ofthe main goal. The Puranas and Itihasas took up theVedas and served as their commentaries, treating the purely philosophical truths, in accordance with certain definiteformulas prescribed in the Vedas themselves, and consistentlyfollowed throughout.The abstract ideas were to someextent concretised and narrated in the garb of Divine histories and geographies. The subsequent pages of this book,will it is hoped make this clearer still. In the meantime,something must be said at this stage regarding the identification of certain places in India with the names found in

the literature. For the very commencement of religiouspractice, the purification of mind and body was found anecessary preliminary step, owing to the degeneracy of manas he is at present, and the two distinct processes above detailed were formulated. As regards the means for externalpurification, the efficacy of good water, none can deny. Theinfluence of healthy forests, fresh air and enchanting scenerycombined with beautiful temples situated in the adjoininglocalities, where abundance of fresh water is procurable inthe shape of falls and running rivers, will certainly be admitted by all, as not only exhilerating to the physical bodybut also soothing and ennobling to the worry-ridden mind.This is exactly the sum and substance of the quotationsreproduced above. Any further twisting of their meaningis unwarranted by the texts and therefore unauthorised.The application of certain terms from the literature, asnames to places or persons, cannot certainly be an exeuse fortheir misinterpretation. The names of Gods invariablyfound applied to all the Hindus, will not justify their stylingthemselves as Gods in comparison with the human beingselsewhere. No more serious argument is required to establish the mistakes in the confounding of earthy spots inIndia with the ideas conveyed by certain religious andphilosophical terms, especially when their meanings are unknown and unsought for. It is equally absurd and insultingto be told that religious centres and holy baths exist only inIndia and all outside is unholy. On the contrary, if westick on to the current interpretations, the passages hithertoreproduced will clearly prove that everything outside Indiais bliss and happiness and everything within is ephemeraland miserable. The eternal and blissful region is describedas lying to the north and beyond the Himalayas. VideMaha Bharatom Santi-parva.

**उत्तरे हिमवत्पार्श्वेपुण्ये सर्वगुणान्विते।  
पुण्यः क्षेम्यश्च काम्यश्च स परो लोक उच्यते॥**

 Hundreds of cases like this may be quoted if necessaryillustrating the absurdity of the modern interpretation. Infact, the localities, their dimensions and other descriptionsgiven in the texts, seldom correspond, and are never meantto correspond, with the modern attempted identifications.The river Saraswathy mentioned in the Puranas had certainly no physical existence at all, but it is now explainedas Antar-vahiny or running underground unseen at Allahabad. The impossible junction of Kaveri in Deccan andNarbuda in Central Provinces, as also the situation of Dwaraka described as on the banks of the Jumna and within theboundaries of Indraprasta or Delhi, found mentioned in thesubjoined quotation will certainly take our Pandits by surprise.

**कावेरी नर्मदां यत्र सङ्गता लोकविश्रुता।  
तत्र स्नात्वा शुचिर्भूत्वा कुबेरस्सत्यविक्रमः॥**

**क्षेत्रं कलिन्दजातीरे मत्तुल्यास्तत्र ये मृताः।

**पद्मपुराणम्॥**

 The subsequent applications of these terms as names tocommon objects might have been for the purpose of familiarising the public with their usage and set them athinking,at least in their leisurely moments. It is no doubt aningenious method of spreading the higher philosophicaltruths among the ordinary people to give them a sort ofcurrency and permanency which could never be expected by

mere publication of books or even by preaching. The stories often utilized as models for religious and moralinstructions tend to keep them in memory as they haveactually done. The majority knows them only in thismanner, but a very limited minority might have heard thePuranas read and explained on religious and festive occasions.Somehow, a great portion of the literature has become incourse of time, the household property of every Hindufamily. The highest gratitude of every pious Hindu is therefore due to the wise and venerable sages for the great boonthus rendered. But the Pandit who stands in the way offurther progress, which the far-seeing Rishis certainly hadin view, is liable for his uncalled for interference and unprivileged forwardness in thrusting in, his misinterpretations.

 The new alien creed styled Theosophy which is generally misunderstood as supporting Hindu religion, is equallyresponsible for voluntarily propogating mistaken theories inthe land pertaining to the contents of our sacred literature.It is certainly too late now for its disciples to conceal ignorance with occultisms and secret doctrines. The mistakescommitted with regard to the point in question are exactlysteriotyped repetitions of our local Pandits, and do not even exhibit an atom of originality in them, in spite of theirstrenuous efforts to give them a scientific shape. The usualmistakes lie at the bottorn and are irremediable at the topFor the purpose of offering convincing and conclusive proofof this fact, it will suffice at this juncture to illustrate oneserious and important blunder exhibited by Theosophicalignorance of the so-called geography in our sacred literature.

 The subjoined quotation from Mrs. Besant's Sanathana Dharma, page 234, will bear ample testimony to thetruth of the above remarks, Many a repeated identificationof Bharata Varsha with India by Mrs. Besant, within he

small para itself here reproduced, is verily the oldest rottenmistake of our local wise acres.

 "In the ancient days Jivatma was prepared for entranceinto each caste through a long preliminary stage outsideIndia; then he was born into India and passed into eachcaste to receive its definite lessons; then was born away from India to practise these lessons; usually returning toIndia to the highest of them, in the final stages of hisevolution".

 It is however desirable to find out if possible whetherthere are any cogent reasons for describing in the sacredtexts, certain philosophical ideas in the form of cities, mountains and rivers and giving thern an appearance of geographical treatment. It must be clearly remembered that they areinvariably mentioned as divine and not earthly as we havealready seen. Their venerable authors are not thereforeresponsible for the modern confusion of these with terrestrialobjects. High abstract truths which will not permit ofbeing easily expressed in human language had to be somehow explained.

**चोद्यं वा व्यवहारो वा क्रियतां द्वैतभाषया।

 "There is no scope for question or answer in the languageof Adwitom. The language of Dwitom is the only availablemedium for such purpose". The material world is thereforethe last resort for their analogical illustrations. Thus,certain religious and philosophical ideas were treated asGods, especially those representing the spiritual or efficientcauses in the philosophical analysis of creation and evolution.For the same reason the transformations of Prakriti ormaterial cause or the Tatwas as they are styled, had to be

described as the region of Gods, in the form of divinecities, divine mountains and divine rivers &c. Again, themain difficulty was not completely overcome. The forms  
of Gods are yet unknown and they were represented in thebest imaginable form of man, with necessary alterations,additions and paraphernalia, the details of which shall betreated in the subsequent section III of this chapter. In thesame manner, the devine cities, hilis and rivers could onlyresemble the earthly ones, with necessary alterations in size,colour and material &c. In the Yoga sastras, the nervouscentres which form the physiological bases for the aboveTatwas were often described as mountains and Peattas orseats, and the never ending currents of Vasanas, thoughts orbreath were naturally represented as ever-coursing rivers,  
carrying with them everything they catch on their way totheir ultimate destination. We have already seen thatGanga, Yamuna and Saraswati represent, Ida, Pingala andSushumna Nadis, and that the water in the Viraja river is made up of the sweat of religious devotion.

 The current mistakes could not however have arisen fromthis unavoidable method of treatment. The subsequenterection of temples and location of Bhowmathirthas, withthe terms in question applied to them as names, have givenan opportunity for confusion of facts, virtually for puttingthe cart before the horse. Neither the cart nor the horsewas a mistaken factor, but the mistake occurred in their misplacement. As matters are now interpreted, they have cometo mean that Vishnu originated after the temple at Srirangomwas constructed and Siva after that of Benares and*not* the temples after them. The Sthala-puranas of suchplaces are also now completely misinterpreted and are exactlyabused and ill-treated like the Puranas themselves. Noneof them I dare say narrate any absurd and irrelevant storiesas now generally explained, but they very reasonably andingeniously furnish clues to the exact meanings of certaindefinite facts and formulas hitherto detailed. The Thirthasas a class invariably refer to Varana and Asi as in Benares.

 The same story is repeated with slightly altered descriptionsto suit the differences of local conditions and necessities. Theproof of all this fact is but a simple matter of unbiased andsympathetic investigation; and I must entirely leave it tothe judgment of those who are sincerely interested in thesubject. In consideration of the limited scope of this littleessay, I cannot help ending the present section here. Hadit not been for the immense amount of irremediable confusionproduced by the mistaken interpretations of this religiousand philosophical geography, I would certainly have stoppedmuch earlier.
