**SECTION II.**

**ON TIME.**

 **1**. The main divisions of Time represented in oursacred literature are; Parardhas, Kalpas, Manwantaras,Yugas and the cycle of 60 years commencing with Prabhava. A more general classification of it is into Sthula and Sukshma, gross and subtle. This latter classification will have tobe first examined, as it is the foundation for the varied descriptions given, in accordance with the usual formulas  
always followed for the purpose of expressing abstractmatters in more concrete terms. It is simply the ignoranceof these formulas that has led to the present confusions. Itmust however be admitted that such restrictions and limitations in the meanings of terms used in the treatment of anyscientific subject, are unavoidable even in the material sphere,and the necessity and plea for such a procedure is thereforegreater in the spiritual sciences. It is probable that theexistence itself of such a distinction in the calculations of

time might surprise our learned Pandits, but nevertheless, itis a bare fact in reference to the literature in question withwhich they are not perhaps sufficiently acquainted, owing tofalse dignity or for other serious reasons.

 The following quotations denote the necessary methodfor understanding some of the given descriptions whichappear as pertaining to Time.

***Quotation. No. I.***

 "The currents of breath may be controlled by the forceof mind. The breath ordinarily passes alternately throughthe left and right nostrils for three Nadikas at a time; andthe Yogi should base upon this fact, his internal calculationsof time regarding day and night, fortnight, month andAyanas".

 This Upanishad here is very clear in its postulation ofa formula for the Yogis, to calculate their own time as different from that of the ordinary man. The Pandit might particularly take note of the fact here, that the ancient Rishiswhose favourite residence was the forest, had more than onecloth to wear, but that in spite of his living in the town, hehas only one, with nothing to spare.

***Q. No. II.***

 "The Ida or current of breath through the left nostril istechnically called the Moon, and Pingala on the right isknown as the Sun. The passing of breath from the rightto the left is also technically known among philosophersas Uttarayana. The reverse is Dekshinayana. The junctionof Ida and Pingala is Amavasya or new moon. When thelife breath reaches Muladhar, it is Vishuva or the New Year'sday. Inspiration and exhalation are beginnings of months.When the life-breath passes to Kundalini through Ida, it isLunar Eclipse, and through Pingala it is Solar Eclipse. Inthese specified holy times, such as Vishuva, Ayana, Eclipse&c., if one bathes in the similarly specified centres in thebody, such as Varanasi etc, he is sure to be purified".

 The above is indeed a double bombardument upon themodern interpretations of our religious times and places. Ifthe ignorant and impudent interpreters hope to escape fromthis, more shall be soon kept ready for them.

***Q. No. III.***

 "That which creates time itself, which is the realcause of the creation and destruction of the Devas and othercreatures, is here known as time. When such time is preserved, creations and destructions vanish. Some create withthis time, others get entangled in it. There are two kindsof time, the Sthula and the Sukshma, the former is meantfor the worldly and the latter for the Yogis. The Sthulais again calculated in two ways; by the lunar rotations forman and by the solar for the Devas. The calculation fromthe Prithivi Tatwa to Siva Tatwa is known as Satwa kalaor time, pertaining to the gradual involutions of the Tatwasnamely of, Eswara, Atma, Sadasiva, Nadanta and Sakti upto Siva Tatwa. Three Sukshma breaths make one SukshmaPrana, and six such Pranas make oue Sukshma Ghatika,and sixty such Ghatikas make one Sukshma day. Furthercalculations of Pakshas, months and years go by the samemultiples ordinarily used for Sthula time. The involutionof the Devas and Bramha is calculated in Sukshma time, asalso the work of the Gnanis and Yogis".

 The divine energy that creates time itself is known asTime here. Three distinct varieties of this Time are hereelearly explained as the Sthula, the Sukshina and the Satwa.The Satwa refers to the involutions of the religious Tatwaswhich are entirely unknown factors to the modern interpreters of our sacred religion. The Sukshma is mentioned aspertaining exclusively to the Devas, Bramha, Gnanis andYogis. The modern Pandit and critic who belong to noneof these specified classes, ignorantly misapply the Sukshma

time to their own Sthula variety, which alone they haveevidently heard of hitherto. They are therefore entirelymistaken at the very foundation, and their ignorant presumption that all our religious and philosophical texts describeonly their householl affairs, certainly displays the most idiotic impertinence that one can imagine.

** 2.** It is evident from the above quotations that thecalculation of time found detailed in the sacred texts clearlyrefer to its Sukshma form and represent the functions ofthought and breath as regulated by Yogic processes. Thegeneral terms of measurement however are retained as thesame in the treatment of both Sthula and Sukshma varieties,and a sort of analogical comparison is maintained with a viewto utilise the Sthula form for the practical benefit of theless qualified classes. The concretised forms and the ritualistic ceremonies of the Karma-kanda are based upon theseanalogical formulas and are consciously prescribed for thepurpose of attaining certain definite aims in the gradualprogress of religious practice. They are certainly not theaimless outcome of the whims and caprices of our venerablesages, nor are they useless and unscientific superstitions asthey are so lightly and conveniently pronounced in moderndays. The mere fancy or even respect for material sciencecannot form an excuse for off-hand criticisms of any facts ortheories without proper scientific investigations, and suchcriticisms in themselves are no signs of originality or respectable intelligence. 'Critics all are ready made,' and no bodyneed therefore care for them. The following passages enumerate the different divisions of time as described in the texts.

अणुर्द्वौ परमाणूस्यात्रसरेणुस्त्रयः स्मृतः।  
जालार्करश्म्यवगतः खमेवानुपतन्नगात्।  
त्रसरेणुत्रिकं भुंक्ते यः कालः स त्रुटिःस्मृतः।  
शतभागस्तु वेधः स्यात्तैस्त्रिभिस्तु लवः स्मृतः।  
निमेषस्त्रिलवो ज्ञेयः आम्नातस्तेयः क्षणः।  
क्षणान् पञ्च विदुः काष्ठां लघुता दशपञ्च च।  
लघूनि वै समाम्नाता दश पञ्च च नाडिका।  
तद्वे मुहूर्तः प्रहरःषड्यामः सप्त वा नृणाम्।  
द्वादशार्धपलोन्मानं चतुर्भिश्चतुरंगुलैः।  
स्वर्णमाषैः कृतछिद्रं यावत्प्रस्थजलप्लुतम्।  
यामाश्चत्वारश्चत्वारो मर्त्सानामहनी उभे I  
पक्षः पञ्चदशाहानि शुक्लः कृष्णश्च मानद।  
तयोः समुच्चयो मासः पितॄणां तदहर्निशम्।  
द्वौतावृतुः षडयनं दक्षिणञ्चोत्तरं दिवि।  
अयने चाहनी प्राहुर्वत्सरो द्वादशस्मृतः।  
संवत्सरशतं नॄणां परमायुर्निरूपितम्।**

**ग्रहर्क्षताराचक्रस्थः परमाण्वादिना जगत्।  
संवत्सरावसानेन पर्येत्यनिमिषोविभुः I  
संवत्सरः परिवत्सर इडावत्सर एव च।  
अनुवत्सरो वत्सरथ विदुरैवं प्रभाष्यते।**

**विदुर उवाच।**

**पितृदेव मनुष्याणामायुः परमिदं स्मृतम्।  
परेषां गतिमाचक्ष्व येस्युः कल्पात् बहिर्विदः।  
भगवान् वेदकालस्य गतिं भगवतो ननु।  
विश्वं विचक्षते धीरा योगराद्धेन चक्षुषा।**

**मैत्रेय उवाच।**

**कृतं त्रेता द्वापरञ्च कलिश्चेति चतुर्युगम्।  
दिव्यैर्द्वादशभिर्वर्षैः सावधानं निरूपितम्।  
चत्वारि त्रीणि द्वे चैकं कृतादिषु यथाक्रमम्।  
संख्यातानि सहस्राणि द्विगुणानि शतानि च।  
संध्यांशयोरन्तरेण यः कालः शतसंख्ययोः।  
तमेवाहुर्युगं तज्ञा यत्र धर्मो विधीयते।  
धर्मश्चतुष्पान्मनुजान् कृते समनुवर्तते।  
स एवान्येष्वधर्मेण व्येति पादेन वर्धता।  
त्रिलोक्या युगसाहस्रं बहिराब्रह्मणो दिनम्।  
तावत्येव निशा तातयन्निमीलति विश्वसृक्।  
निशावसान आरब्धो लोककल्पोनुवर्तते।  
यावद्दिनं भगवतो मनून् भुञ्जन् चतुर्दश।  
स्वं स्वं कालं मनुर्भुङ्क्ते साधिकां ह्येकसप्ततिम्।  
मन्वन्तरेषु मनवस्तद्वंशा ऋषयः सुराः।  
भवन्ति चैव युगपत्सुरेशाश्चानु ये च तान्।  
एष दैनंदिनः सर्गोब्राह्म त्रैलोक्यवर्तनः।  
तिर्यङ् नृ पितृ देवानां सम्भवो यत्र कर्मभिः।  
मन्वन्तरेषु भगवान् बिभ्रत्सत्वं स्वमूर्तिभिः।  
मन्वादिभिरिदं विश्वमवत्युदित पौरुष।  
तमोमात्रामुपादाय प्रतिसंरुद्धविक्रमः।**

**कालेनानुगताशेष आस्ते तूष्णीं दिनास्वये।  
तमेवान्वपिधीयन्ते लोका भूरादयस्त्रयः।  
निशायामनुवृत्तायां निर्मुक्तशशिभास्करम्।  
त्रिलोक्यां दह्यमानायां शक्त्या सङ्कर्षणाग्निना।  
यान्त्यूष्मणा महर्लोकाज्जनं भृग्वादयोर्दिताः।  
तावत्त्रिभुवनं सद्यः कल्पान्तैधितसिन्धवः।  
प्लावयन्त्युत्कटाटोप चण्डवातेरितोर्मयः।  
अन्तः स तस्मिन् सलिल आस्तेऽनन्तासनो हरिः।  
योगनिद्रानिमीलाक्षः स्तूयमानो जनालयैः।  
एवं विधैरहोरात्रैः कालगत्योपलक्षितैः।  
अपक्षितमिवास्यापि परमायुर्वयः शतम्।  
यदर्धमायुषस्तस्य परार्धमभिधीयते।  
पूर्वः परार्धोऽपक्रान्तो ह्यपरोद्य प्रवर्तते।  
पूर्वस्यादौ परार्धस्य ब्राह्मो नाम महानभूत्।  
कल्पो यत्राभवत् ब्रह्मा शब्दब्रह्मेति यं विदुः।  
तस्यैवचान्ते कल्पोभूद्यंपाद्ममभिचक्षते।  
यद्धरेर्नाभिसरस आसील्लोक सरोरुहम्।  
अयन्तु कथितः कल्पो द्वितीयस्यापि भारत।  
वाराह इति विख्यातो यत्रासीत्सूकरो हरिः।  
कालोयं द्विपरार्धाख्यो निमेष उपचर्यते।  
अव्याकृतस्यानन्तस्य अनादेर्जगदात्मनः।  
कालोयं परमाण्वादि द्विपरार्धान्त ईश्वरः।  
नैवेशितुं प्रभुर्भून्न ईश्वरो धाममनिनाम्॥**

**श्रीमद्भागवतम्॥**

***Q. No. III.***

**ब्राह्ममेकमहर्विप्राः कल्प इत्युच्यते बुधैः।  
तावती रात्रिरित्युका ब्रह्मणः पण्डितोत्तमाः।  
त्रिशतैः षष्टिभिः कल्पैर्ब्रह्मणो वर्षमीरितम्।  
वर्षाणां यछतं तस्य द्विपरार्धमिहोच्यते ॥**

**स्कान्दपुराणम्॥ सूतसंहिता।**

***Quotation. No. I.***

 "Nimesha is the time taken to open and close the eyesin the normal condition. 1/4 of this is a Tuti; 2 Tutis make1 Lava; 2 Lavas make 1 Nimesha; 15 Nimeshas,. 1 Kashta;30 Kashtas, 1 Kala; 1/2 Kala, 1 Kshena; 2 Kshenas, 1 Muhurtha; 1/2 Muhurtha, 1 Ghatika by which everything ismeasured. 3¾ Ghatikas make 1 Sandhi; 2 Sandhis, 1Yama; 4 Yamas, the day time".

 The scale of time for the divisions of the day time startswith Nimesha or the twink-ling of the eye, one-fourth ofwhich is called Tuti, the lowest in the scale equal to about13 seconds. This is the scale for the ordinary calculation ofhuman time.

***Q. No. II.***

 "The ultimate Bramhan is doubtless without form, without change, without attributes. The conception of thesmallest atoms or Paramanus as originating from this Bramhan is only a deductive inference. Both the Sthula and theSukshma forms of time are thus inferred. The smallestamount of time that pervades over a Paramanu is also calledParamanu. 2 Anus make 1 Paramanu and 3 Anus 1 Tresarenu which is the smallest atom that could be perceived inthe ray of sun's light passing through a window. The timethat pervades over 3 Tresarenus is known as a Truti, 1/10of it is 1 Vedha; 3 Trutis, make 1 Lava; 3 Lavas, 1 Nimesha; 3 Nimeshas, 1 Kshena; 5 Kshenas, 1 Kashta; 15Kshenas, 1 Leghuta; 15 Leghutas, 1 Nadika; 2 Nadikas,1 Muhurta; 6 or 7 Nadikas, 1 Yama; 4 Yamas a day and4 Yamas one night. make 1 year, the day and night of the Devas. 100 years isthe longivity of man. The universe including the planets,stars &c., is thus made up of Paramanus. Samvathsara,Parivatsara, Idavatsara, Anuvatsara and Vatsara are thevarieties of the year".

 "Vidura said— You have now described to me the divisions of time pertaining to man, Pitris and Devas. Kindlytell me the nature and method of calculation of time asapplying to others, who by their Yogic knowledge keep outof its limitations as just explained.

 Mytreya said — The Yugas named Krita, Treta, Dwapara and Kali made up of 12,000 divine years apply to them.The Yugas consist of 4, 3, 2 and 1 thousand years, respectively, excluding 2000 years allowed for their mutual junctures Leaving the period for such junctions, the intervalsin which Dharma rules, is recognised by the wise as Yugas.This Dharma is complete in the Krita Yuga and diminishesby 1, 2 and 3 quarters respectively in the remaining Yugas.A thousand cycles of these four Yugas make one day forBramha, outside the first three Lokas. The same periodextends over his night. During the day time 14 Manus rulefor about 71 Chatur-yugas. each, during which Rishis andDevas are born. This is the daily creation by Bramha extending to the three Lokas. At the end of each day the threeLokas are burned down by the fire of Samkarshana andcovered by the ocean, agitated by the air. The Bhrigus andothers, at the time remove themselves from Mahar to Jenoloka. The days and nights of Bramha are thus calculatedup to 100 years as if his age is limited by that period.Half of his age is known as a Parardha. The first half ispassed which is called Bramha-kalpa when Bramha is knownas Sabda-bramhan. The second and the current half iscalled Padma-kalpa, owing to the lotus-earth that sprang

from Hari's naval and is also known as Varaha-kalpa because Hari incarnated as a boar. These two Parardhas areafter all, in reality only a Nimesha of the Lord who is beginningless, endless and formless. ***Q. No. III.***

 "The Bramha's day and night are known as Kalpas. 366such days make one year for him and a hundred years socalculated make two Parardhas."

 The above quotations themselves tell more than theordinary story now prevailing about the divisions of Time asdetailed in our ancient literature. The calculation starts withthe smallest scientific atom which is multiplied and increasedin extent up to Parardhom. The atom virtually is a pointwithout dimensions and it creates only an idea of space. Theidea of Time is generated by calculating the time required forthought to pass from one point to another; and hence it isexactly the modern philosophical explanations of space andtime as co-existence and succession. From the Anu or atomat the bottom of the scale the calculation rises to the topmostfigure the Parardom, two of which makes a hundred years'life-time of Bramah the creator. There are Manwantarasand Yugas intervening, which are made up of years.The year is practically the highest figure that can becognised by its component parts, and it does not createany confusion so far, except perhaps in the application ofAyanas and Pakshas, the half-year and half-month as daysof Gods and Pitris respectively. We must however beginfrom the top of the scale, namely, Parardhom, to discover theclues for the correct interpretations of these uncommon andunknown terms in the calculation of time mentioned in thetexts.

 In quotation 3, Vidura enquires of Mytreya regardingthe special kind of time, different from the human calculationjust explained, applicable to the working of those indifferentto worldly affairs, like the Yogis. The Yugas are then mentioned as referring to such time, in which the quantity ofDharna, is ascertained as their essential characteristics.

**तमेवाहुर्युगं तज्ञा यत्र धर्मो विधीयते।**

 The Yugas according to the root meaning naturally applyto the work of the Yogis and fall under the Sukshma varietyof time. These Yugas have been already noticed in theprevious section as found only in the Bharata-varsha, thedevotional sphere of action for the religious man. The general significance of Yugas is thus clear at least so far as toits inapplicability to the years and centuries in A. D. or B.C.The error in the current interpretation of the Yugas, willbecome more evident from the special quotations, to followon the point. The difference between the first Parardha andthe second, the Bramha-kalpa and the Padma-kalpa shall beexplained in the next section on Personalities. We mayhowever safely note here that none of the modern interpreters have yet taken the trouble to enquire what a Parardhasignifies and whether any definition for the term is furnishedin our religious literature. How are they going to excusethemselves for this culpable mistake evidently caused byignorant pride and irresponsible prejudice? If they evercared to look into the sacred texts, they would not haveventured to play with our ancient religion in the mannerthey have done. The Pandit by his ignorant and irrelevantinterpretations, has unconsciously allowed more than sufficient room for the foreign critic to attack the acknowledgedworth of the literature from all its sides. In spite of theseunfortunate mistakes from two different quarters, the facttacitly remains that the majority of the educated and un-

educated Hindus are never satisfied with the Pandit's explanations and are immensely annoyed at heart with the currentdestructive criticisms. That neither of these elucidations therefore contain anything sensible, useful or acceptable is virtually proved.

**यदि सन्ति गुणाः पुंसां विकसन्त्येव केवलम्।  
नहि कस्तूरिकामोदः शपथेन विभाव्यते॥**

 The following quotations explain the import of Parardha in the plainest language possible.

***Quotation No. I.***

**गुणसाम्ये तदा तस्मिन् पुरुषेवात्मनि स्थिते।  
प्राकृतः प्रलयो ज्ञेयो यावद्विश्व समुद्भवः।  
ब्राह्मी रात्रिरियं प्रोक्तात्वहः सृष्टिरुदाहृता I  
अहर्न विद्यते तस्य न रात्रिर्ह्युपचारतः॥**

**योयं संदृश्यते नित्यं लोके भूतक्षयस्त्विह।  
नित्यः सङ्कीर्त्यते नाम्ना मुनिभिः प्रतिसञ्चरः।  
ब्रह्मनैमित्तिको नाम कल्पान्ते यो भविष्यति।  
त्रैलोक्यस्यास्य कथितः प्रतिसर्गो मनीषिभिः।  
महदाद्यं विशेषान्तं यदा संयाति संक्षयम्।  
प्राकृतः प्रतिसर्गोयं प्रोच्यते कालचिन्तकैः।  
आत्यन्तिकस्तु कथितः प्रलयो ज्ञानसाधनः।  
वाराहोवर्तते कल्यो यस्य विस्तर ईरितः।  
असंख्यातास्तथा कल्पा ब्रह्मविष्णुशिवात्मकाः।  
कथिता हि पुराणेषु मुनिभिः कालचिन्तकैः।  
सात्विकेष्वथ कल्पेषु माहात्म्यमधिकं हरेः।  
तामसेषु हरस्योक्तं राजसेषु प्रजापतेः।  
योयं प्रवर्तते कल्पो वाराहस्सात्विको मतः॥**

**कूर्मपुराणम्।**

***Q. No. II.***

**अहस्तस्य तु या सृष्टिः प्रलयो रात्रिरुच्यते।  
अहर्न विद्यते तस्य न रात्रिरिति धारणा।**

**उपचारः प्रक्रियते लोकानां हितकाम्यया॥**

**एकं कल्पसहस्रन्तु ब्रह्मणोऽब्दः प्रकीर्तितः।  
एतदष्टसहस्रन्तु ब्रह्मणस्तद्युगं स्मृतम्।  
एकं युगसहस्रन्तु सवनं तत्प्रजापतेः।  
सवनानां सहस्रन्तु द्विगुणं त्रिवृतं तथा।  
ब्रह्मणः स्थितिकालस्य चैतत् सर्वं प्रकीर्तितम्॥**

**कोटिकोटिसहस्राणि परार्ध इति कीर्त्यते।  
परार्धद्विगुणञ्चापि परमाहुर्मनीषिणः।  
एवमष्टादशैतानि स्थानानि गणना विधौ।  
संख्यातस्तु परो ब्रह्मा तस्यार्धन्तु परार्धता।  
संख्येयञ्चाप्यसंख्येयं सततञ्चापि तान्त्रिकम्।  
संख्येयं संख्यया दृष्टम्अपरार्धाद्विभाव्यते।  
राशौ दृष्टेन संख्यास्ति तदसंख्यस्य लक्षणम्॥**

**वायुपुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. III.***

**अथ प्राथमिकस्येह यः कालस्तदहः स्मृतम्।  
सर्गस्य तादृशीरात्रिः प्राकृतस्य समासतः।  
दिवा सृष्टिं विकुरुते रजन्यां प्रलयं विभुः।  
औपचारिकमस्यैतदहोरात्रं न विद्यते।  
पितामहस्याथ परः परार्धद्वयसम्मितः।  
दिवा सृष्टन्तु यत्सर्वंनिशि नश्यति चास्य तत्।  
भूर्भुवस्वर्महस्तत्र नश्यते चोर्ध्वतो न च।  
रात्रौ चैकार्णवे ब्रह्मा नष्टे स्थावरजङ्गमे।  
सुष्वापाम्भसि यस्तस्मान्नारायण इति स्मृतः॥**

**लिङ्गपुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. IV.***

**शतमाहुः परिवृढं सहस्रं परिपत्मकम्।  
विज्ञेयमयुतं तस्मान्नियुतं प्रयुतं ततः।  
अर्बुदं न्यर्बुदं चैव खर्बुदश्चततः स्मृतम्।**

**खर्वञ्चैव निखर्वश्च शङ्कुःपद्मं तथैव च।  
समुद्रमन्त्यं मध्यञ्च परार्धञ्च परं ततः।  
एवमष्टादशैतानि स्थानानि गणना विधौ।  
शतादीनि विजानीयात् सांञ्जतानि महर्षिभिः।  
कल्पसंख्या प्रवृत्तस्य परार्धोब्रह्मणः स्मृतः।  
तावच्छेषोपि कालोस्य तस्यान्ते प्रतितिष्ठते।  
पर एवपरार्धश्च संख्यातस्संख्यया मया।  
यस्मादस्य परं वीर्यं परमायुः परं तपः।  
परा शक्तिःपरो धर्मः परा विद्या परा धृतिः।  
परं ब्रह्म परं ज्ञानं परमैश्वर्यमेव च।  
तस्मात्परतरं भूतं ब्रह्मणो यन्नविद्यते।  
परे स्थितो ह्येष परः सर्वार्थेषु ततः परम्।  
संख्यातस्तु परो ब्रह्मा तस्यार्धस्य परार्धता।  
संख्येयञ्चाप्यसंख्येयं सततञ्चापि तान्त्रिकम्।  
संख्येयं संख्यया दृष्टम्अपरार्धाद्विभाष्यते।  
राशौ दृष्टेन संख्यास्ति तदसंख्यस्य लक्षणम्।  
आनन्त्यं सिकताद्येषु हृष्टं चान्यं त्वलक्षणम्।  
ईश्वरैस्तत्प्रसंख्यानं शुद्धत्वाद्दिव्यदृष्टिभिः।  
एवं ज्ञानप्रतिष्ठत्वात्सर्वं ब्रह्मानुपश्यति॥**

**ब्रह्माण्डपुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. V.***

**शक्तयः सर्वभावानामचिन्त्य ज्ञानगोचराः।  
यत्ततो ब्रह्मणस्तास्तु सर्गाद्या भावशक्तयः।  
उत्पन्नः प्रोच्यते विद्वान्नित्य एवोपचारतः।  
निजेन स्वस्वमानेन आयुर्वर्षशतं स्मृतम्।  
तत्पराख्यं परार्धञ्चतदर्धं परिकीर्तितम्॥**

**पद्मपुराणम्॥**

**स्थानात् स्थानं शतगुणमेकैकं गण्यते द्विजाः।

**परार्धे द्विगुणं यत्तु प्राकृतस्सलयो द्विजाः।  
तदाऽव्यक्ते खिलं व्यक्तं सहेतौ लयमेति वैI  
द्विपरार्धात्मकः कालः कथितो यो मया द्विजाः।  
तदहस्तस्य विप्रेन्द्रा विष्णारीशस्य कथ्यते।

नैवाहस्तस्य च निशा नित्यस्य परमात्मनः।  
उपचारात्तथाप्येतत्तस्येशस्य तु कथ्यते।  
इत्येष मुनिशार्दूलाः कथितः प्राकृतो लयः॥**

**ब्रह्मपुराणम्॥**

***Quotation. No. I.***

 "When the three gunas maintain their equilibrium, itis called Prakriti-laya or dissolution of Prakriti; and it ishere described as the night of Bramha. His day refers tothe divine creation here narrated. In reality, he has neithernight nor day. The annihilation of the material world isspoken of as Pratisanchara or re-absorption back into Prakriti. The destruction from the Mahat to the gross elements is called Pratisarga. Final and complete destructionor involution is secured only through gnana. The elaboratedescriptions given in the religious texts refer to the Varaha-kalya. Several such Kalpas pertaining to Vishnu, Rudraand Bramha are also mentioned in the Puranas by the Rishisin their treatment of Time. In the Satwic Kalpas, theglories of Vishnu are predominant, in the Rajasic, Bramha'sand in the Tamasic, Rudra's. The current Varaha-kalpa isSatwic".

 It is plainly stated here that the division of time intothe days and nights of Bramha, alludes simply to his glories.The Prathisarga or secondary creation here mentioned refersdirectly to the involutionary processes by the annihilation ofmateriality.

**महदाद्यं विशेषान्तं यदा संयाति संक्षयम्।  
प्राकृतः प्रतिसर्गोयं प्रोच्यते कालचिनतकैः॥**

 The term refers to one of the five requirements of a Puranahardly understood by the Pandit.

**सर्गश्च प्रतिसर्गश्च वंशो मन्वन्तराणि च।  
वंशानुचरितं चैव पुराणं पञ्चलक्षणम्॥**

 Under the present state of ignorance, one need not evenbe astonished to hear some Pandits explaining Sarga andPratisarga as Chapters and Sections in a Purana. Thecurrent interpretation of Pratisarga as applying to materialcreation is therefore not only varying from truth, but diametrically opposed to it. However willingly and respectfully we may view the modern opinions, it is absolutelyhopeless to obtain even an atom of useful and correct information from them regarding the contents of our sacred texts.

***Q. No. II.***

 "The creation described refers to his day and the dissolution to his night. Understand that he has neither nightnor day. They are so described in a complementary stylefor conveying the instruction to the religious public. Athousand Kalpas make 1 Abda of Bramha ; 8,000 Abdas,1 Yuga; 1,000 Yugas, 1 Savana; 6,000 Savanas representhis longivity. Koti into Koti into one thousand make oneParardha. Two Parardhas make one Parom. The seventeenth figure in the Arithmetical notation known as Parardhais mentioned as representing half the age of Bramha. Thehighest Arithmetical figure is here given only in accordancewith the Puranic method of description. A Parardha should therefore be properly interpreted as Aparardha or no Parardha, meaning infinity thereby".

 It is clearly explained here that a Paradha is the seventeenth and the highest figure in the Arithmetical Notationby multiples of one hundred, and that its application to theage of Bramha is in accordance with the Puranic formula.It is also stated as in the previous quotation that the daysand nights of Bramha are mere complementary descriptions.It is naturally feared that these facts would prove startlingnews to our enlightened interpreters.

***Q. No. III.***

 "The creation by Bramha during the day and the dissolution in the night are only described in a complementarystyle. His age is specified as extending to two Parardhas. In thenight, when everything is covered by the ocean, Bramhasleeps in the waters, and then he is known as Narayana”.

 This is a repetition of the facts already explained in thepreceding quotations. No Crìtic need now ingeniously devisespecious apologies for his sweeping remarks constantly made,as to the existence of contradictory statements in the religious texts. He has hardly seen for himself any statementsin their true light to enable him to judge of their contradictions or conformities. His traffic has all along beencarried on with the bankrupt of a Pandit and he could therefore show nothing to his own credit at present. He haspitiably failed in one of the fundamental requirements ofmerchandise, and it is now too late for him to brood over it.We have already noticed in the previous section that Bhuloka is stated to be far above this material earth, and wefind here that the creation and destruction attributed toBramha's work apply only to the first four Lokas, from

Bhu to Mahar and therefore do not include this earthy globe.The ocean in which these four Lokas lie submerged duringthe night of Bramha, does not also form part of any of theoceans, seas or gulfs mentioned in our modern geography.Bramhas' sleeping in the waters of this ocean is explained ashimself being converted into Narayana or Vishnu. This iscertainly an unbecoming statement to the delicate and keenear of the modern interpreters, but there is no help for it asit is so stated in the text. This point however will be explained in detail in the subsequent section on Personalities.

*** Q. No. IV.***

 "Seventeen figures in the Arithmetical Notation, bymultiples of one hundred, are named by the Rishis as follows,Unit, hundred, ten thousand, Ayuta, Prayuta, Arbuda,Nyarbuda, Kharbuda, Kharva, Nikharva, Samku, Padma,Samudra, Antya, Madhya and Parardha.  Parardha is clearly explained here, as the highest figurein the Arithmetical notation by multiples of one hundred,and as denoting infinity in its application to the age of

**गुणेषु क्रियतां यत्नः किमाटोपैःप्रयोजनम्।

*** Q. No. V.***

 "The Saktis or energies of creation &c., in Bramha,denote his innate nature, and are described as originated, only as a matter of complement. They can however beunderstood only by Gnana. His one hundred years of age,extending to Parom, and its half representing a Parardhaare only postulated, as a suggestion from man's ownlongivity'.

 The explanations here furnished are too plain andsimple to demand any commentaries. The age of Bramhaand his creations here described are thus religious conceptions, whose real signficance could be understood by theacquirement of Gnana. There is however not the slightestdoubt as to their inapplicability to any historical incidents taking place on the surface of this material earth.

*** Q. No. VI.***

 "In the Arithmetical notation, eighteen places are namedby multiples of one hundred. The two Parardhas together

signify the Prakriti-laya, the involuion or merging of all theVyaktas into the Avyakta. This constitutes the day time ofVishnu, and when the Prakriti itself merges into the Purusha,it is the night of Vishnu. The eternal Vishnu however, has  
neither night nor day. All this is simply stated in a complementary style. In this manner, the involutionary religiousprocesses up to Prakriti-laya are described".

 It is evident from this quotation that the two Parardhasof Bramha combined, complete the Prakriti-laya or the annihilation of finite conceptions. Here, Bramha's jurisdictionends and Vishnu's begins. The merging of Prakriti itselfinto the Purusha, is described as the night of Vishnu.These Puranic narrations in the texts are repeatedly assuredto be complementary descriptions, to avoid chances of misinterpretation.

**इत्येष मुनिशार्दूलाःकथितः प्राकृतो लयः॥**

Has the Critic, Pandit or Theosophist ever looked into theseexplanatory passages before they ventured to convert thecontents of the sacred religious texts into an insignificanthistory of the mortal man? For aught we know, the foreignCritic is sincere in his curiosity to understand the contents ofIndian religious literature. But the microscopic minorityof apish imitators among the educated Hindus are completely wanting in the sincerety and the curiosity of the Critic,when they volunteer to confirm and strengthen the Critic'sviews by their authoritative opinions as Hindus. It ispractically deception and misleading, when such confirmations are based upon entire ignorance of and culpable indifference to the subject. An educated Hindu of this typehas however the least claim to style himself a representativeof the religious and learned Hindus in the land. He isdoubtless responsible for his misleading the foreign patron

and betraying his own sacred religion in false colours to thediscredit of his fellowmen, besides subjecting himself to hisown religious deterioration. It is a pitiable truth that theso-called religious reformers of the modern day are mostly tobe found among this class. It is also a wonder how suchmen shamelessly take a pride in calling themselves benefactors of their countrymen, when they by their ignominious conduct only succeed in displaying their moral andintellectual weakness, religious indifference and want ofcharacter and self-respect. Whatever might be the apparenttemporary benefits acquired personally, the attempt as awhole being entirely a deviation from the right path, isinevitably doomed to fail in the long run, and it would betoo late then, to rue for the mistakes consciously committed.

**यावत्स्वस्थमिदं शरीरमरुजं यावज्जरा दूरतो  
यावच्चेन्द्रियशक्तिरप्रतिहता यावत् क्षयोनायुषः।  
आत्मश्रेयसि तावदेव विदुषा कार्यः प्रयत्नो महान्  
सन्दीप्ते भवने तु कूपखनने प्रत्युद्यमः कीदृशः॥**

** 3**. The above quotations conclusively prove that thewhole affair is a simple rendering of the Infinite in thelanguage of the Finite, the abstract fact in the form of theconcrete Arithmetic for the express purpose of showing theimmensity and magnitude of the object described. TheParardhom is the 17th and the last figure in the Arithmetical Notation reckoned by multiples of one hundred, insteadof ten. Parom means great and Ardhom position. Thus,the highest state of existence to be attained is explained bythe height, the present low, degraded and mortal man has to ascend by strenuous efforts and religious devotion. Thehundred years making up a Bramha's period are clearlystated in Quotaion V, as having been predicted in accordance with the longivity of man himself. This period is divided

into two exact halves consisting of 50 years each. Thecurrent time is represented as the beginning of the latterhalf. The applications of these divisions and variations ofTime could be easily understood when references to the'Personalities' are examined in the subsequent section. Itmay however be noted here that the former half points tothe Gnana and Upasana processes and the latter to the Yogaand Karma processes.

**वेदो ब्रह्मा इति शृतिः II**

The Vedas are represented by Bramah and they prescribethe above two methods conforming to the capacities of manfor the attainment of salvation. Next to Parardhom, theManwantaras and Yugas have to be examined. The day ofBramha which covers all ideas of religious creation and existence is divided into 14 Manwantaras consisting of 1,000Chatur-yugas or cycles of four Yugas, each Manwantara extending to about 71 Chatur-yugas. The interval of timeelapsing between two Manus is called a Manwantara and itcan be better explained while treating of Manus themselves.Besides, the examination of the meanings of Yugas will alsothrow some light upon the calculation of a Manwantara. Asearching enquiry may therefore be first made with regardto the Yugas. The subjoined quotaions are I fear likely tofrighten our self-constituted interpreters out of their wits.

***Quotation. No. 1.***

**सत्वं कृतं रजस्त्रेता द्वापरन्तु रजस्तमौ।  
कलौ तमस्तु विज्ञेयं युगवृत्तवशेन तु।

**हनूमानुवाच।**

**कृतं नाम युगं श्रेष्ठं यत्र धर्मः सनातनः।

न साम ऋग्यजुर्वर्णाः क्रिया नासीच्च मानवी।

त्रेतामपि निबोध त्वं यस्मिन् सत्रं प्रवर्तते।

ततो यज्ञाः प्रवर्तन्ते धर्माश्च विविधाः क्रियाः।  
त्रेतायां भावसङ्कल्पाः क्रियादानफलोपगाः।  
प्रचलन्ति न वै धर्मात्तपोदान परायणाः।

**द्वापरे च युगे धर्मो द्विभागो न प्रवर्तते॥**

**विष्णुर्वैपीततां याति चतुर्धा वेदएव च।

एवं शास्त्रेषु भिन्नेषु बहुधा नीयते क्रिया।  
तपोदानप्रवृत्ता च राजसी भवति प्रजा।  
एकवेदस्य चाज्ञानाद्वेदास्ते बहवः कृताः।  
सत्यस्य चेह विभ्रंशात्सत्ये कश्चिदवस्थितः।  
सत्यात्प्रच्यवमानानां व्याधयो बहवोऽभवन्।  
कामाश्चोपद्रवाश्चैव तदा वै दैवकारिताः।  
यैरर्द्यमाना सुभृशं तपस्तप्यन्ति मानवाः।  
कामकामाःस्वर्गकामा यज्ञांस्तन्वन्ति चापरे।  
एवं द्वापरमासाद्य प्रजाः क्षीयन्त्यधर्मतः।  
पादेनैकेन कौन्तेय धर्मः कलियुगे स्थितः।  
तामसं युगमासाद्य कृष्णो भवति केशवः।  
वेदाचाराः प्रशाम्यन्ति धर्मयज्ञक्रियास्तथा।  
ईतयो व्याधयस्तन्द्री दोषाः क्रोधादयस्तथा।  
उपद्रवाः प्रवर्तन्ते आधयो व्याधयस्तथा।  
युगेष्वावर्तमानेषु धर्मो व्यावर्तते पुनः।  
धर्मे व्यावर्तमाने तु लोको व्यावर्तते पुनः।  
लोके क्षीणे क्षयं यान्ति भावा लोकप्रवर्तकाः।  
युगक्षयकृता धर्माः प्रार्थनानि विकुर्वते॥**

**महाभारतं वनपर्व॥**

**कालो वा कारणं राज्ञो राजा वा कालकारणम्।

**कृतं त्रेता द्वापरश्च कलिश्च भरतर्षभ।

**देवदेवो महादेवः कारणं जगतः परम्।

**शान्तिपर्व।**

***Quotation. No. I.***

 “In & treatinent of the history of the Yugas, Krita isSatwa; Treta is Reja; Dwapara is a combination of Rejaand Tama; and Kali is Tama. In the Krita, there is noaction of any kind, good or bad, all that has to be done inthe Lokas having been already done. There are also nodivisions of castesandAsramas, and no intermixtures".

 The Pundit, in his usual style, is sure to rush in here,with his thoughtless interpretations. If theYugas refer tosome ancient periods in the history of man, as he, the Criticand the Theosophistwould wish to establish, will they tellus how man could exist in the Krita, as described here,without actions of any kind? If again the Critic and Theosophist want to prove the non-existence of castes and Asramas in ancient days like the Krita, will they explain whythe absence of admixture is specially noticed ? The actionsgood or bad, said to have been already accomplished in Krita,are those pertaining to the various religious Lokas, whoselist has been already found to exclude this material earth.

**सकृदेवकृतं सर्व यद्वै लोके कृताकृतम्॥**

 It is therefore certain that neither the transactions of theworldly man, nor the distinctions of Indian castes, nor againthe utility and urgency of destroying them, by interdiningand intermarrying, are here spoken of. Every layman ofordinary common sense can easily infer from every word inthis quotation, that both the current interpretations, andcriticisms, proceed from sheer ignorance of the subject andfrom an unbecoming spirit of unnecessary interference. Thesubsequent quotations are sure to exhibit this fact in strongerlight. The modern methods of explaining the subject for theenlightenment of the religious public are therefore extremelydistressing and ruinous.

**ये संसत्सुविवादिनः परयशः शल्येन शूलाकुलाः  
कुर्वन्ति स्वगुणस्तवेन गुणिनां यत्नात् गुणाच्छादनम्।  
तेषां रोषकषायितोदरदृशां कोपोष्ण निःश्वासिनाम्  
दीप्तारत्नशिखेव कृष्णफणिनां विद्या जनोद्वेगिनी॥**

***Q. No. II.***

 "The wise say that there are four Yugas in the Bharata-varsha and that they are nowhere else. Dhyana and tapasin the Krita; Gnana in the Treta; Yegna in the Dwaparaand Dana alone in the Kali are specified. In the first Krita,Dharma exists, it is manifested in Treta, it is distracted inDwapara and destroyed in Kali".

 The Pandit here is extremely happy to note that noneof the Yugas get out of Bharata-varsha.He preservesthem within the boundaries of his India. The Theosophistof course is prepared to go over this spot for his use of theYugas. The foreign Critic will surely get bewildered here.If Yugas allude to the periods of human history, why shouldother nations outside India be deprived of their benefit? Probably other nations in the world, were never affected by

the trammels of time, in ancient days. Different states ofDharma are stated to be the distinguishing characteristics ofthe Yugas. In the Krita however, this Dharma is not evenmanifested, it remains latent. Is there any modern interpretation available to make this statement intelligible? As times advance, why is this Dharma said to deteriorate anddwindle to nothing especially in these modern days of civilization and progress? Perhaps it is so described in uncivilized times. Will the Pandit at least tell us why Dyana,tapas, gnana and Yegna are uncourteously excluded from  
Kali, when so many of his learned colleagues are found allover India? What is the harm if the present generation inKali take to any of these religious processes, and could the Pandit assure that no one in India is violating this rule?

 My good God ! it is indeed a wonder why no answersare forthcoming for any of these pertinent questions, fromany of the quarters from which we had so much noisehitherto.

**नैर्मल्यं वपुषस्तवास्ति वसतिः पद्माकरे जायते  
मन्दं याहि मनोरमां वद गिरं मौनं न सम्पादय।  
धन्यस्त्वं बकराजहंसपदवीं प्राप्तोसि किं तैर्गुणै-  
र्नीरक्षीरविभागकर्म निपुणाशक्तिः कथं लभ्यते॥**

***Q. No. III.***

 "There are four Yugas in the Bharata-varsha, namely,Krita, Treta, Dwapara and Tishya. The longivity isreckoned as 4,000 years in Krita, 3,000 in Treta and 2,000in Dwapara. In the Tishya, it is uncertain, death occurringsometimes in the womb or soon after birth'.

 Why is the much despised Kali called Tishya heremeaning auspicious or fortunate? In this quotation also, thefour Yugas are mentioned as found only in Bharata-varshaIf, in the current Kali, even the chances of living are so pre-

carious, as described here, why not the Pandit get out of his India to be free from its clutches? Again, does he believe that his forefathers lived for four, three and two thousand years respectively in the three previous Yugas, as described here, and if he does, has he any sort of proof to establish the same? On the other hand, will the Critic or Theosophist accept this description, and if not why? These are surely natural questions arising from the modern interpretation of the passage here quoted. If no reasonable answers are available from any of these so-called interpreters, how are we bound to accept their interpretation, while they invariably bring with them unmerited disrepute to the sacred texts as well as to their venerable authors? The interpretations of these self-made authorities are certainly not more valuable to us than the religious texts, and themselves not so venerable as the ancient Rishis.

**लौकिकानां हि साधूनामर्थं वागनुवर्तते।  
ऋषीणां पुनराद्यानां वाचमर्थोऽनुधावतिII**

***Q. No. IV.***

 "The advent of exaltation is also like the coming in of deterioration. When Dharma is well attained, the Krita Yuga is clearly seen. Goodness is the ruling principle in the Krita, it is lost in the Kashaya or Kali. Time is unchanging like the moon, which when veiled by darkness is Kali and when unveiled is Krita. The inseparable and unknowable Parom-bramhan is the Arthavada or object in view in the Vedas. The approved and valid process for obtaining it, is Tapas, and that is confirmed here. Cessation of Karmas is attained by meritorious virtues, which in themselves are purified by Karmas".

 It is clearly stated here, that the realisation of Bramhan is the chief aim of the teachings in the Vedas, and that the

proper process for it is Tapas. The absence of Tapas isspecified as Kali, Kashaya or confusion. The removal ofthis confusion, Tama or Agnana produces Krita. The important scope and extent of Tapas, and its different stages ofattainment are here established by the division of the Sukshma and religious time into four Yugas. It is repeatedlyassured that these Yugas are not found outside the limits ofBharata-varsha. This is an additional corroboration for thefact that Bharata-varsha refers to the devotional sphere ofreligious Karmas and that the Yugas explain the degrees ofperfection attained therein. The devotional sphere is therefore described as space in the Puranic style and the Yugasas time.

***Q. No. V.***

 "Krita is the greatest of the Yugas, where eternalDharma is complete, having no more to be done. In theKrita, there are no Devas, Danavas, Yekshas, Rakshasas andPannagas; there is no buying no selling; no difference ofVedas and no human action. The Dharma is Sanyasa.Pertaining to this Yuga, there is no disease, no weakness ofthe senses, no laziness, no pride, no prejudice, no fear, nogrief, no quarrel. The highest Bramhan is the ultimateattainment for the Yogis in this Yuga. The Atman is inthe form of Narayana, pure and white, and Atma-yoga isthe distinguishing characteristic of this Yuga. The threegunas are here absent and Dharma has its four quarterscomplete. In the Treta, Vishnu becomes red and a quarterof Dharına is lost. Tapas, Dana, Satya, Yegna, Swadharma and religious Karma remain firm in Treta. In theDwapara half the Dharma is lost and Vishnu becomes brown.On account of the ignorance of the single Veda, it is dividedinto four, some taking to three, some to two or one andsome to none of them. Some fall from Satya or truth and

consequently diseases and misfortunes result. Dharma greatlydeteriorates and Yegnas are performed to obtain Swargaand to satisfy worldly desires. In the Kali, only one quarterof Dharma remains and Vishnu becomes dark. Dharma,Yegna and Achara dwindle to nothing. Diseases, misfortunes, sorrows, anger, laziness &c. arise. As the Yugasrevert, Dharma also reverts with the Lokas. The Lokasappear by meditation and when the Lokas disappear, everything deteriorates and spoils".

 The Yugas are here distinguished by the different degrees of Dharma prevailing. In the Krita it is completelyfinished, nothing more having to be done. It is clearlystated here that in the form of human action there is absolutely nothing in this Yuga, 'क्रियानासीच्च मानवी'IAtma-yoga is said to be the distinguishing characteristic of theKrita Yuga.

**आत्मयोगसमायुक्तो धर्मोऽयं कृतलक्षणः॥**

These are extremely plain and unambiguous statementswhich will not in the least permit of the modern interpretation, as alluding to the historical periods of Hiudu, Mahamaden or European soverigns in India. The Pandit's interpretation here displays his utter ignorance of the subjectand utter lack of common sense. It might perhaps suggest,by the laws of association, the funny slokas in Sanskritknown as Anterlapika.

**का पाण्डुपत्नी गृहभूषणं किं को रामशत्रुः किमगस्त्यजन्म।  
कः सूर्यपुत्रो विपरीतपृच्छा कुन्तीसुतो रावणकुम्भकर्णः॥**

If the Pandit is still anxious to understand the Yugas ashistorical periods, he may have the consolation of knowingthat the Krita Yuga refers to the history of every Yogi

practising Atma-yoga in which all human affairs now worrying the Pandit's brain are entirley annihilated. The practice of the lower forms of Yoga is described as representingthe three remaining Yugas. It is a noteworthy fact herethat the single Veda has to be divided into four by theadvent of Dwapara. Again another important fact noticedin this quotation is that meditation brings on the Lokas andthat when the Lokas are gone everything deteriorates.

**लोके क्षीणे क्षयं यान्ति भावालोकप्रवर्तकाः॥**

Have the modern interpreters any explanation to offer herefor our enlightenment? There is no poetical fancy nor anyexaggeration here. These are the only two expressionsyet known to them to cover their ignorance. They mustconfess here that the description is entirely unmeaning. Itcannot but be so, as the whole subject is misunderstood fromits very commencement. It is also a vain belief that theyhave understood anything before or after this passage. Thosewho understand the real nature of the subject can clearlyunderstand that every line in the text is completely misunderstood at present. Every school boy knows that arithmetic is not geography. The Pandit evidently knows neitherarithmetic nor geography and it is no wonder therefore thathe confounds the two together in his presumptuous attemptto explain an unknown subject.

***Q. No. VI.***

 "You need not foster the least doubt as to whether thenature of time depends upon the character of the Raja, orthe character of the Raja depends upon the nature of time.The nature of time is entirely shaped by the character of theRaja. The four Yugas named Krita, Treta, Dwapara andKali allude to the history of the Raja; in fact, the Raja ishimself the Yuga. When the Raja enforces Denda-niti orjustice completely, it is called Krita the best of the Yugas.

Dharma is unabated and Yoga is safe in Krita. Voice,colour and mind are then highly developed. When three-quarters of justice are enforced, the Treta is originated. Whentwo-quarters of justice are enforced, the Dwapara is originated. When no justice at all is enforced, Kali is originated.Then, there is no Dharma and no safety for Yoga. Thecastes get intermixed. The Raja is actually the creator ofKrita, Treta, Dwapara and Kali. By creating Krita, heobtains the highest heaven and by creating Kali, he obtainsthe deepest hell. By the creation of the other two Yugas,he obtains the proportionate happiness.  Now, let us look into the gist of the whole description.The different Yugas are said to take their names accordingto the amount of Denda-niti or justice enforced by the Raja.The Raja is independent of time, but time is entirely dependent on him. This directly contradicts the modern interpretations of Yugas even as Sthula time. That almost throughout the religious texts Sukshma time is dealt with as alreadyexplained here, is probably a new lesson to these interpreters. Have the Pandit, Critic or Theosophist anything to say against this quotation from the Maha-bharata,which undoubtedly puts them all to complete shame? Wehave already found that there is no human action in theKrita-yuga. If therefore Denda-niti means criminal justicein accordance with the modern interpretation, there is absolutely no relevancy in describing its complete enforcement.

in the Krita Yuga. Either Krita is not Krita, or Dendaniti is not criminal justice. These are then the two horns ofthe dilemma, in which the self-made authorities and Critics have inevitably landed themselves. The pretended knowledge and the assumed competency to interpret or criticise,could not be possibly concealed, when unexpectedly theproper time arrives for their naked exposure.

**कृष्णं वपुर्वहतु चुम्बतुसत्फलानि  
रम्येषु संवसतु चूतवनान्तरेषु।  
पुंस्कोकिलस्य चरितानि करोतु कामम्  
काकः कलध्वनिविधौ स तु काक एव॥**

***Q. Nos. VII & VIII.***

 "The four quarters of Dharma are Gnana, Dhyana,Sama and Dema. Gnana is the knowledge of the Atman.Dhyana is the meditation of Atman. Sama is stability ofmind and Dema is control of the senses. When Dharmaincreases, longivity increases. Dharma in the form of a bull,with its sound four legs roams about protecting the Lokas-Adoration to that holy form !  The four quarters of Dharma are here stated to be thestandards by which the Yugas are determined and they areexplained as consisting of Dyana, Gnana, Sama and Dema.Dharma is generally described as a Vrisha or bull. Vrishaitself means Dharma in the Sanskrit language. Pada inthe same way means one fourth as well as a foot or leg inSanskrit and in the Indian vernaculars. The Pundit feelshighly elated at the opportunities here offered in the description of Dharma. He would have his Dharma in the form

of an actual bull the biggest and fairest obtainable in Indiaand would like to establish that, that is the correct and onlymeaning for the Puranic description. In the same way, hemust establish that the Yugas have their distinguishingfeatures in some concrete form and that they should be confined within the boundaries of India. Time as ordinarilyunderstood by human beings is an abstract idea whichcannot be dealt with as the Pandit handles it. It isclearly stated here that the names of Yugas signify thenature of the work done by the pious and the religious inin the field of Dharma, and the Pandit simply exhibits hisperverse obstinacy and lamentable ignorance in his interpretation of the subject. Gnana, Dhyana, Sama, Dema,truthfulness, control of the senses &c. are not certainly thequalities of time. He is however most anxious to establishthat the venerable authors of the sacred texts are not muchwiser than the wise-acres of his type.

**वीणेवश्रोत्रहीनस्य लोलाक्षीव विचक्षुषः।

** 4.** The words Yuga and Yoga are almost synonymous. To couple, to unite, or join the Jivathma with theParamatma, the lower self with the higher self is the ideapervading all these descriptions. The degrees of perfectionattained in this direction are explained with reference to thedefinite processes prescribed for the purpose. The KritaYuga expresses the stage of completion as the word Kritaclearly denotes. The appellations Kali, Thishya, Kashayaand Thamasa for the last Yuga are equally significant of theentire absence of religious merit. It is called the currentYuga as the instructions in the texts are naturally supposedto be always addressed to the ignorant and irreligious populace in general and are meant for their benefit. The following passages already quoted in Chaper I specifying the first

day of Kali as the date on which Sri Krishna quitted theearth, are indicative also of the loss of belief even in thetheory of the existence of a God consequent on therampantmaterialism prevailing all over the world, apart from theirtechnicalreference.

तदैवेहानुवृत्तो सावधर्मप्रभवः कलिः॥**

**श्रीभागवतम्।**

**यस्मिन् दिने हरिर्यातो दिवं सन्त्यज्य मेदिनीम्।  
तस्मिन्नेवावतीर्णोयं कालकायो बली कलिः॥**

**विष्णुपुराणम्॥**

The main points of distinction in the four Yugas lie in theamount of Dharma prevailing, none being found in Kali.There is no 'Yogakshema' or prosperity for Yoga nor Yogaitself in Kali. It stands aloof from the rest as the worst inthe list and lowest in the scale of religious advancement.Half the quantity of Dharma prevails in Dwapara Yugaand three-fourths in Treta Yugs, as the words Dwapara andTreta themselves signify. Quotation VII clearly enumeratesthe four parts of Dharma as consisting of Gnana, Dhyana,Sama and Dema. Quotation VI, explains that the reckoning of the Yugas entirely depends upon the proportionateenforcement of criminal justice, Denda-niti. In fact thehistory of the Raja is said to be the specification of the Yuga.This is the Puranic method of description. The Raja, as  
stated in the preceding pages, is the Atma or self seated inthe car or body. The horses are the senses, mind the reinsand intellect the charioteer.

**आत्मानं रथिनं विद्धि शरीरं रथमेव तु।  
इन्द्रियाणि हयान्याहुः मनः प्रग्रहमवे च।  
बुद्धिन्तु सारथिं विद्यात्॥**

The Danda-niti or criminal justice requires some explanation. It refers to the Yogic process prescribed for annihilating the external Vasanas. The Danda is the spinal cord with its plexes for meditation, as we have already noticed.

 The most important item in the description determiningthe characteristic differences of the Yugas is the duration oftime detailed for each of them. A careful examination ofthe formulas and a correct calculation in accordance withthem, will, 1 confidently hope easily convince every readerthat the gist of the whole matter is far removed from thecommon interpretations as well as from those attempted bythe help of modern material sciences. The Sukshma andSthula classifications of time should be distinctly kept in the calculation, the former technically applying to the experiences and attainments of the Yogic processes and the latter tothe ordinary reckoning of days, months and years. In therendering of the Sukshma into the Sthula the formulas aregiven in the passages already quoted.

**श्वासैस्तु त्रुटिभिः प्राणो घटिका प्राणषड्ककै।  
अहोरात्रं ततः षष्टि घटिकादिर्विशेषतः॥**

Three breaths make one Prana and six Pranas make oneSukshma Ghatika. Further calculations go by the samenumbers both for Sukshma and Sthula. 60 Sthula-Ghatikasmake 1 Sthula day; similarly 60 Suksma Ghatikas make1 Sukshma day. Again,

**पिङ्गलायाःइडायान्तु प्राणसंक्रमणं मुने।  
तदुत्तरायणं प्रोक्तं मुने वेदान्तवेदिभिः।  
इडायाः पिङ्गलायान्तु प्राणसंक्रमणं मुने।  
दक्षिणायनमित्युक्तं पिङ्गलायामिति श्रुतिः॥**

The passing of breath from right to left, that is inhalingthrough the right nostril and exhaling through the left is

technically known amongst Yogis as Uttarayana, and viceversa as Dekshinayana, both of them together making aSukshma year.

**Further,**

**प्राणापानवशो जीवो ह्यधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रधावति।  
वामदक्षिणमार्गेण चञ्चलत्वान्नदृश्यते।  
हकारेण बहिर्याति सकारेण विशेत् पुनः।  
हंस हंसेत्यमुं मन्त्रं जीवो जपति सर्वदा।  
शतानि षट् दिवारात्रं सहस्राण्येकविंशतिः।  
एतत्संख्यान्वितं मन्त्रं जीवो जपति सर्वदा।  
अजपा नाम गायत्री योगिनां मोक्षदा सदा।  
अस्याः सङ्कल्पमात्रेण नरः पापैः प्रमुच्यते॥**

**ध्यानबिन्दूपनिषत्॥**

 Breath passes alternately through the right and left nostrils,through the force of Prana and Apana, and it repeats theprocess 21,600 times in a day. Meditation on this byYogis is Known as Ajapa-Mantra which is very efficaciousfor the destruction of sins. Taking the three above passages together, the question regarding the length of periodgiven for Kali Kuga namely; 1, 200 Divine years including200 years of Sandhi or 4,32,000 hunan years, may be easilyworked out.

3 x 6 = 18 Swasas make 1 Sukshma Ghatika.  
18 × 60 = 1030 Swasas make 1 Sukshma day.

 A Sthula day consists of 21600 Swasas probably calculatedfrom the normal condition observed in sleep. At othertimes, although respiration is an involuntary action itsnatural speed and duration will be constantly altered bychanges of external as well as internal conditions. Theproportion for conversion of a Sukshma day, month or yearinto a Sthula day, month or year is therefore 21600 ÷ 1080 = 20.

that is 1 to 20, is the proportion. Uttarayana and Dekshinayana together is one year and is tantamount to 1 Swasa,which is made up of both. The year here is Sukshma andit is therefore 20 Sthula years. 21,600 Swasas thereforemake up 432,000 Sthula years, which is exactly the numbergiven for the duration of Kali Yuga. We thus clearly seethat the purport of the whole affair is the Yogic account ofa single day of man. The doubling, trebling and quadrupling of this period for Dwapara, Treta and Krita Yugas,are consequent on the regulation of breaths by the processesprescribed in the Yoga-sastras with which we are not directly concerned at present. For instance, to obtain the numberof years given for Dwapara namely 864,000; a single Sthuladay whose account is practically the gist of the matter,being always a constant factor, the proportion in the rendering of the Sukshma to the Sthula, will have to be doubledby a corresponding reduction in the number of Swasas or breaths making up a Sukshma Ghatika. Instead of 18Swasas comprising a Sukshina Ghatika they should be reducedto 9, then the proportion will be*21,600*= 40.9 × 60 TheSthula years per day's account, will then amount to 21,600 x 40= 864,000. Similarly, the necessary reduction of Swasas byYogic processes will give the figures for Treta and KritaYuagas. We thus clearly see that the figures given in thetexts are mathematically exact and not approximations, orexaggerations or even poetical fancies. It is however sufficient for our present purpose to know what a Yuga means,at least what it does not mean. The mere knowledge of itwill remove a good deal of misconception and further consequent errors, created by the ignorant people as well as bythe so-called scientific expositors like the Theosophists. We

have already seen how the latter are completely ignorant ofthe true significance of the geographical descriptions.Equally ignorant are they with regard to the question of timespecified. Their calling to aid geological discoveries in theelucidation of our sacred literature is more a mockery thananything else. Madam Blavadski's explanation in her"Secret Doctrines", of the duration of Dwapara Yuga namely864,000 years, as nearly approaching the earliest date discovered by modern Geology, is perhaps accepted by herdisciples and some others as a eulogistic observation in favorof Hindu Religion. What then about the duration of theTreta and Krita Yugas? We have perhaps to wait untilanother Geological discovery is available. What if the durations given for each of the four Yugas are pronounced to bediscovered immediately by Geology or any other materialsciences? The Yugas mentioned in our religious texts applyonly to Bharata Varsha (vide Q. 2) and not to the Theosophical India nor to any other locality outside the same onthe surface of this earthy sphere. Taking even the Theosophical interpretation (which is but a borrowing in toto fromthe local Pandits) of Bharata varsha as representing India,and the Yugas as referring to the ordinary calculation oftime, it must logically lead to the ridiculous but unavoidable  
conclusion, that there is no 'Time' in America and perhapsno 'space' in Europe, both being outside Bharata-varsha. Itis high time that those who are really interested in our hoaryand sacred religion either religiously or even scientifically,should soon get over this deplorable ignorance and open theireyes. It is indeed a shame that we should have deterioratedto this depth to allow ourselves to be treated in this childishfashion both by our ignorant Pandits and the misleadingforeigners. It is certainly too late in these boasted days ofcivilization to console ourselves by excuses like want of time

or means, when side by side with us, the enlightened foreigners seek useful and valuable information in the interest ofscience from all corners of the world at the cost of immensewealth and convenience and even at the risk of personal life.It is utterly useless to be simply proud of our ancient civilization and religious supremacy.Standing still in the daysof progress, is positive retrogression and there is not theslightest doubt that we have fallen down thousands ofdegrees in our religious sphere.

श्रोतॄणां हृदयेष्व बुद्धिरधिका ज्ञानं गतं चारणे।  
गाथा गीतविनोदवाक्यरचना युक्त्या जगद्रञ्जितम्  
ज्योतिर्वैद्यकशास्त्रसारमखिलं क्षुद्रेषु जातं कलौ॥**

 **5.** The Manus and Manwantaras are matters ofvital importance in our Religion. They refer to certain definitePsychological and Physiological principles advantageouslyutilized in the religious practices prescribed. The subject isparticularly technical and perhaps peculiar to the Hindureligion. The facts expressed by the enumeration of the 14 Manus and of the durations of time intervening betweeneach of them are closely connected with the description ofthe Yugas and deal with scientific and technical matters, adetailed description of which is not possible to be attemptedhere. References will however have to be made occasionallywhere the necessary and available informations may be furnished. Regulation of breath called Prana-yama is the chiefprocess prescribed for Yoga. But it has to be supplementedby meditation accompanied by Manthras to make it effective.

**मरुदभ्यसनं सर्वे मनोयुक्तं समभ्यसेत्॥**

A scientific treatment of the physiology of sound styledSiksha is well-known to every student of Sanskrit Grammar,as forming an important portion of the subject. But it has

seldom been studied as a practical science, nor its specialapplication to the religious literature carefully noticed.Siksha has already been explained in Chapter II as one ofthe six Vedangas. It is thus one of the necessary items tobe first understood in the correct elucidation of religiousfacts and formulas. The natural relation or associationbetween thought and sound or language, the fact of theirinseparable coexistence and the consequent effects of theirmutual actions are all minutely and scientifically treated and,practically utilized for the practice of Yoga and religiousdevotion.

 A science like the physiology of sound may perhapssound strange to a modern scientist, but nevertheless it isone of the oldest one known to our ancients and its possibility itself cannot be deniedwithout a proper enquiry. TheManthras are all composed in strict adherance to the principlesof this science. They are not valued for their meaning asgenerally supposed. The various Sahasranamas or thousandnames in praise of Vishnu or other Gods are not all of themrecognised as fit to be repeated as Manthras. Besides, thereare several single letters which ordinarily convey no meaning except a peculiar sound and do not permit of translationin any language but are particularly recognised as Manthraslike Hrim, Klim &c. Thus, the idea of translating theManthras in any language is a useless and unscientific task in as much as they lose their significance and effects even in aparaphrase in the Sanskrit language itself. It is but awell-known fact, that every poetical composition in anylanguage is not necessarily suited to be sung in every tunein music, unless the laws of composition for such purposesare strictly adhered to.

 The word Manu ordinarily means mental faculty orthought as well as a Manthra. No great change is made

from this common interpretation, in its application in thetexts. But it is used in a somewhat restricted sense according to the requirements of the technical subject. The following quotations are subjoined with the hope of corroboratingthe interpretation here given, and I dare say it would beprofitless to criticise it as new or farfetched, without readingthe passages quoted, or to condemn them all, as unauthenticinterpolations. The texts containing these passages aresufficiently recognised as genuine for our present purposeand the passages themselves have not yet been marked outby modern critics and proclaimed as interpolations. Theonly probability is that they have not been properly noticedor understood in a searching or sympathetic spirit.

स वाक्सिद्धिमवाप्नोति सरस्वत्याः प्रसादतः।  
वेदशास्त्रपुराणानां स्वयं कर्ता भविष्यति॥**

**योगशिखोपनिषत्॥**

***Q. No. XI.***

**विराजमसृजद्विष्णुः सोसृजत्पुरुषं विराट्।  
पुरुषं तं सनुं विद्यात्तस्य मन्वन्तरं स्मृतम्।  
द्वितीयं मानसस्यैतन्मनोरन्तरमुच्यते।**

**स वैराजः प्रजासर्गं ससर्ज पुरुषः प्रभुः।  
नारायणविसर्गस्य प्रजास्तस्याप्ययोनिजाः।  
युगे युगे भवन्त्येते पुनर्दक्षादयो नृपाः।  
पुनश्चैव निरुध्यन्ते विद्वांस्तत्र न मुह्यति।  
ज्येष्ठं कानिष्ठमप्येषां पूर्वं नासी द्विजोत्तमाः।  
तप एव गरीयोभूत्प्रभावश्चैव कारणम्॥**

**ब्रह्मपुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. XII.***

**सवै स्वायंभुवः पूर्वं पुरुषो मनुरुच्यते।  
विराजमसृजत् ब्रह्मा सोभवत्पुरुषो विराट्।  
सम्रान्मानसरूपात्तु वैराजस्तु मनुः स्मृतः।  
स वैराजः प्रजासर्गः ससर्गे पुरुषो मनुः।  
वैराजात्पुरुषाद्वीराच्छतरूपा व्यजायत।  
प्रियव्रतोत्तानपादौ पुत्रौ तु पुत्रवतां वरौ।  
कन्ये द्वे च महाभागे याभ्यां जाताःप्रजास्त्विमाः।  
देवी नाम्ना तथा कूतिः प्रसूतिश्चैव ते शुभे।  
स्वायम्भुवः प्रसूतिन्तु दक्षाय व्यसृजत् प्रभुः।  
प्राणो दक्षस्तु विज्ञेयः सङ्कल्पो मनुरुच्यते।  
स्रष्टुकामःप्रजा ब्रह्मा चिन्तयामास दुःखितः।  
तस्य चिन्तयमानस्य प्रादुर्भूतः कुमारकः।  
दिव्यगन्धः सुधापेक्षी दिव्यां श्रुतिमुदीरयन्।  
अशब्दस्पर्शरूपां ताम्अगन्धां रसवर्जिताम्।  
श्रुतिं ह्युदीरयन् देवो यामविन्दच्चतुर्मुखः।  
स ओंकारे भवेद्वेदः अक्षरं वै महेश्वरः।  
चतुर्मुखमुखात्तस्मादजायन्त चतुर्दश।  
नानावर्णा स्वरादिव्यम्आद्यन्तच्चतदक्षरम्।  
तस्मात् त्रिषष्टिवर्णा वै अकारप्रभवा स्मृताः।  
अकाररूप आदौ तु स्थितः स प्रथमस्वरः।**

**ततस्तेभ्यःस्वरेभ्यस्तु चतुर्दश महामुखाः।  
मनवः सम्प्रसूयन्ते दिव्या मन्वन्तरे स्वराः।  
मुखात्तु प्रथमात्तस्य मनुः स्वायम्भुव स्मृतः।  
अकारस्तु स विज्ञेयः श्वेतवर्णः स्वयंभुवः।  
द्वितीयात्तु मुखात्तस्य आकारो वै मुखः स्मृतः।  
नाम्ना स्वारोचिषो नाम वर्णः पाण्डुर उच्यते।  
तृतीयात्तु मुखात्तस्य इकारो यजुषां वरः।  
यजुर्मयः स चादित्यो यजुर्वेदो यतः स्मृतः।  
ईकारःस मनुर्ज्ञेयो रक्तवर्णः प्रतापवान्।  
ततः क्षत्रं प्रवर्तेत तस्माद्रक्तस्तु क्षत्रियः।  
चतुर्थात्तु मुखात्तस्य ईकारःस्वर उच्यते।  
वर्णतस्तु स्मृतः ताम्रः स मनुः तामसः स्मृतः।  
पञ्चमात् तु मुखात्तस्य उकारो नाम जायते।  
पीतको वर्णतश्चैव मनुश्चापि चरिष्णवः।  
ततः षष्ठान्मुखात्तस्य ऊकारः कपिलः स्मृतः।  
वरिष्ठश्च ततः षष्ठोविजयःस महातपाः।  
सप्तमात् तु मुखात्तस्य ततो वैवस्वतो मनुः।  
ऋकार स्वरस्तत्र वर्णतः कृष्ण उच्यते।  
अष्टमात् तु मुखात्तस्य ऋकारः श्यामवर्णतः।  
श्यामाक्षर सवर्णश्च ततः सावर्णिरुच्यते।  
मुखात् तु नवमात्तस्य ऌकारो नवमः स्मृतः।  
धूम्रो वै वर्णतश्चापि धूम्रश्च मनुरुच्यते।  
दशमात् तु मुखात्तस्य ऌकारः प्रभुरुच्यते।  
समश्चैव सवर्णश्च बभौ सावर्णिको मनुः।  
मुखादेकादशात्तस्य एकारो मनुरुच्यते।  
पिशङ्गो वर्णतश्चैव पिशङ्गो मनुरुच्यते।  
द्वादशात्तु मुखात्तस्य ऐकारो नाम उच्यते।  
पिशङ्गो भस्मवर्णाभः पिशङ्गो मनुरुच्यते।  
त्रयोदशान्मुखात्तस्य ओकारो वर्ण उच्यते।**

**पञ्चवर्णसमायुक्त ओकारो वर्ण उत्तमः।  
चतुर्दशमुखात्तस्य औकारो वर्ण उच्यते।  
कर्बुरो वर्णतश्चैव मनुः सावर्णिरुच्यते।  
इत्येते मनवश्चैव स्वरा वर्णाश्च कल्पतः।  
विज्ञेया हि यथा तत्वं स्वरतो वर्णतस्तथा।  
परस्परसवर्णाश्च स्वरा यस्माताद्वृताहि वै।  
तस्मात्तेषां सवर्णत्वादन्वयस्तु प्रकीर्तितः॥**

                          **वायुपुराणम्॥**

*    **Q. No. XIII.***

**परात्परतरात्तस्मा शिवाच्चैतन्यलक्षणात्।  
स्वशक्ति सहिता देव द्विजाज्योतिर्मयः परः।  
शब्दः सूक्ष्मः स्वभावेन प्रादुरासीदखण्डितः।  
स शब्दः पुनराधारे प्राणिनामास्तिकोत्तमाः।  
पिण्डीभूततया भाति तप्तजाम्बूनदप्रभः।  
स पुनर्ब्रह्मनाड्यातु प्रविश्य हृदयाम्बुजम्।  
विभक्तः सूक्ष्मरूपेण भाति वह्निप्रभः स्वतः।  
ब्रह्मरन्ध्रंपुनस्साक्षाछिवस्य स्थानमुत्तमम्।  
पिण्डीभूततया प्राप्य प्रकाशानन्दलक्षणे।  
तत्र सन्निहिते शम्भौ विश्रान्ति लभते स्वतः।  
आधारे परशक्तेस्तु स्थाने शब्दः प्रकाशितः।  
परमेकाक्षरं साक्षात् भवत्यत्यन्तशोभनम्।  
आज्ञा संस्थान्महास्थानादूर्ध्वं यत् स्थानमुत्तमम्।  
तत्रस्थोयं द्विजाः शब्दः सूक्ष्मैकाक्षरतामियात्।  
तृतीये परमाधारे पूरके पुण्यभाजने।  
एकाकारत्वमाप्नोति स्वभावेनाक्षरद्वयम्।  
अयमाद्यः परो मन्त्रः सुप्रसिद्धः स्वभावितः।  
मननत्राणरूपत्वान्मन्त्र इत्यभिशब्दितः।  
मातृका परमा देवि मन्त्रमाता महेश्वरी।  
अस्मादाद्यान्महामन्त्रादाविर्भूता स्वभावतः।**

**अधोमुखी भवेदेका एका ऊर्ध्वमुखी भवेत्।  
तस्माच्छ्रीमातृका शुद्धा चाद्यमन्त्रात्मिकी भवेत्।  
आद्योयं परमो मन्त्रः सुप्रसिद्धोपि सुव्रताः।  
सर्वेषामादिभूतस्य शिवस्य परमात्मनः।  
स्वप्रकाशस्वरूपस्य वाचकोयं परो मनुः।  
अपदं पदमापन्नं पदञ्चाप्यपदं भवेत्।  
पदापदविभागञ्चयः पश्यति स पश्यति।  
पदस्थस्य जिता मन्त्रा भवेयुः पण्डितोत्तमाः।  
पदाभ्यासपराणान्तु न किञ्चिदपि दुर्लभम्।  
अंश एकः पदस्यायमुपकाराय देहिनाम्।  
भवेत् षोडशधा पूर्वं पञ्चधा च द्विधा पुनः।  
पदस्यांशोऽपरः पूर्वो द्वात्रिंशत् भेदमाप्नुयात्।  
त्रयस्त्रिंशत् पुनर्भेदं तथैव द्विविधं भवेत्।  
एवं लोकोपकाराय पदं बहुविधं भवेत्।  
स्थूला सूक्ष्मा सुसूक्ष्मा च त्रिविधा मातृकेश्वरी।  
सा देवी शक्तिसम्भिन्ना शिवस्यामित तेजसः।  
बुध्वा मन्त्रजपं कुर्यादेवं मन्त्रस्य वैभवम्।  
परापरविभागेन प्रणवस्तु द्विधा मतः।  
परः परतरं ब्रह्म प्रज्ञानन्दादि लक्षणम्।  
प्रकर्षेण नवं यस्मात्परं ब्रह्म स्वभावतः।  
अपरः प्रणवः साक्षाछब्दरूपः सुनिर्मलः।  
प्रकर्षेण नवत्वस्य हेतुत्वात्प्रणवः स्मृतः।  
परमप्रणवप्राप्ति हेतुत्वात्प्रणवोथ वा।  
आकाशादि पदार्थानां ये शब्दा वाचका भुवि।  
विना तानखिलान् शब्दान् लोक ओमिति भाषते।  
सर्वावभासकत्वेन ब्रह्मणा सदृशः स्मृतः॥**

**            **  **स्कान्दपुराणं सूतसंहिता॥**

***Q. No. XIV.***

**अकारादि क्षकारान्ता एकपञ्चादशक्षराः।  
एते वर्णाः प्रशस्यन्ते कामितार्थ प्रदायकाः।**

**तेभ्यः समुद्भवं नाम रूपभेदं तथांशकम्।  
तत्वमन्त्रादि भेदञ्चअधिदैवफलं तथा।  
स्थूलसूक्ष्माकृतिञ्चैव जीवोपाधिविभेदकम्।  
शिवतत्वे परे सूक्ष्मे बिन्दुरूपन्तु जायते।  
बिन्दोर्नादस्समुत्पन्नो नादान्ते शक्तिजायते।  
शक्तेस्तु जायते शब्दः शब्दाज्जायेत वाग्भवम्।  
वाग्भवाच्च कला जाताः कलाभ्यो विकलास्तथा।  
तस्माद्वै वाचको मन्त्रः मन्त्रस्तैरेव भिद्यते।  
एतत्सृष्टिक्रमं प्रोक्तं तेषां लक्षणमुच्यते।  
बिन्दुरूपा परा शक्तिः नादश्चैवादिरुच्यते।  
शक्तिरिछेति विज्ञेया शब्दो ज्ञानमिहोच्यते।  
वाग्भवं स्यात् क्रियाशक्तिःकला वै षोडशस्वराः।  
इच्छाशक्तिश्च विद्या च तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः।  
ज्ञानं चैव प्रतिष्ठा च तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः।  
निवृत्तिस्यात् क्रियाशक्तिः तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः।  
प्रकृतिस्सप्तवर्णानि विकृतिस्तु नवार्णकम्।  
कला मात्रा स्वरा जीवा प्रकृतिर्विकृतिस्तथा।  
प्राणा आत्मा च देही च कलाःपर्यायवाचकाः।  
ककारादिक्षकारान्ताः वर्णाश्च विकलाः स्मृताः।  
देहोपाधिशरीरञ्च क्षेत्राधारस्तनुस्तथा।  
व्यञ्जनं विकला शक्तिः बिन्दुपर्यायवाचकाः।  
अकारादित्रयो व्योम ईकारदित्रयोनिलः।  
ऋकारादीनि वर्णानि तेषामग्निरिति स्मृतः।  
एकारादित्रयोह्यापः औकारादित्रयो मही।  
प्रकृतिस्तत्वबीजं स्यात् विकृतिर्मूर्तिरुच्यते।  
प्रभावं विकलाः प्रोक्ताः इत्येवं त्रिविधाभवेत्।  
प्रकृतिर्हृस्वमित्युक्तं विकृतिः दीर्घमुच्यते।  
एकमात्रो भवेध्रस्वः द्विमात्रो दीर्घ उच्यते  
व्यज्ञनं त्वर्द्धमात्रं स्यात् इत्येतल्लक्षणं भवेत्।**

**कला जीवमितिख्यातं सकलं देहमुच्यते।  
कलाश्च विकलाश्चैव देहिदेहमिति स्मृतम्।  
स्थूलं शब्दमिति प्रोक्तं सूक्ष्मं चिन्तामयं भवेत्।  
चिन्तया रहितं यत्तु तत् परं परिकीर्तितम्।  
मननं सर्वपक्षेषु त्राणं संसारसागरात्।  
मननत्राणधर्मित्वान्मन्त्रमित्यभिधीयते।  
यथादरःस्वनाम्ना तु जनस्सन्निहितो भवेत्।  
तथा मन्त्रप्रयोगेण तत्र सन्निहितश्शिवः॥**

**प्रणवं सर्ववेदाख्यं सर्वदेवमयं विदुः।  
सर्वेषाञ्चैव मन्त्राणां प्रणवः प्राण उच्यते।  
प्रणवं सर्ववर्णानां शिवबीजमिति स्मृतम्।  
बिन्दुनादप्रकारेण प्रणवाकृतिरीरिता॥**

**                     वातूलशुद्धागमम्॥**

***Q. No. XV.***

 चक्रवाच्यानि षट्पद्मानि।शब्दसृष्टिसूक्ष्मरूपशालिनी त्रिपुरसुन्दरी सूक्ष्मरूपवत्वप्रवृत्तिं निमित्तकपरापदवाच्या। सैवमातितरति कशयति इति मातृका।तस्याञ्च विश्वसिसृक्षोत्पद्यते। सैव च पश्यन्त्याख्यामातृका।तदवयवाश्च वामादयोष्टौशक्तयः। सैव नाति सूक्ष्मापरावत् नाति स्थूलावैखरीवत् अतो मध्यमाख्या मातृका।अविकृतशून्यस्पर्शनात् अध्वनि बिन्दुशक्तिबीजाक्षराख्यं नादनवकं मूलाधारादिषट्केनादेनादान्ते ब्रह्मरन्ध्रे च स्थितम्। नवर्भिर्नादैः अकचटतपयशल्लाख्यवर्गनवकवती वैखर्याख्या मातृका जाता। वै निश्चयेन स्पष्टतरत्वात् खंकर्णविवरवर्ति नभोरूपश्रोत्रेन्द्रियं रातिगच्छति।शुद्धस्य शिवस्य शुद्धायाः शक्तेर्वा जंगत्कारणत्वं तत्र तत्रोच्यमानं शिवशक्ति रूपस्योभयात् मन एव बोध्यं। तत्रप्रकाशस्तु अक्रारस्वरूपः। तद्वाच्यश्च।

स्फुरता तु हकाररूपा। तद्वाच्या च। तावेतावकारहकारौ परा रूपौ सूक्ष्मतमौ। परादि सृष्टिमूलभूतस्य बीजस्थानीयस्य बिन्दुविशेषस्य तु व्यक्ताव्यक्तविलक्षणौ वाचकौ। तस्यापि जनकस्य परब्रह्मणस्तु केवलमव्यक्तायवशून्यस्वरूपौ वाचकौ॥

**अहमित्येकमद्वैतं यत्प्रकाशात्मविभ्रमः।  
अकारस्सर्ववर्णाभ्यःप्रकाशः परमः शिवः।  
हकारोन्त्यःकला रूपो विमर्शाख्यः प्रकीर्तितः।  
अनयोस्सामरस्यं यत् परस्मिन्नहमिस्फुटम्।  
शून्याकाराद्विसर्गान्तात् बिन्दुप्रस्पन्दसंविदः॥**

 शून्याकारः शून्यमात्रस्वरूपः - यो विसर्गान्तः षोडशस्वरान्त्यः तस्मात् बिन्दुविशेष उत्पन्न इति तदर्थः। विसर्गस्याव्यक्तहकारतुल्यत्वेनाकारस्यापि तत्र सत्वेन षोडशस्वरकीर्तनं प्रकृतम्। तेनाकारहकारावेव शून्याकारी कीर्तितौ वेदितव्यौ ॥

**वरिवस्यारहस्यम्॥**
