**                    श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. XVIII.***

**क्रिया कर्मेज्य कर्तॄणामर्थं मन्त्रो वदत्यथ।  
मननात्त्राणनान्मन्त्रस्सर्ववाच्यस्य वाचकः॥**

**                     रामपूर्वतापिन्युपनिषत्॥**

*  **Quotation. No. I.***

 "The practice of Yoga should be accompanied by a Manthra or utterance of a vowel sound, also by the meditation of the Bramhan beyond the reach of sound, and identifying it with the self''.

 Three concomitant factors are here specified, the regulation of breath, utterance of a Manthra and meditation. The vowel sound in the Manthra is meant for the purpose of concentrating the flow of mind towards sound, name or Nama. The meditations prescribed are for the purpose of concentrating the mental flow towards objectivity, Rupa. According to our philosophy the whole cosmology of man consists only of nama and rupa.

*** Q. No. II.***

 "The mind is set up by the intellect to express the name of an object hit upon by the intellect, which in itself is worked up by Atma. The Agni, fire or life principle in the body sets up the breath in motion, being itself acted upon by mind. A deep sound or low tone called Mandra, is then produced by the agitation of breath in the chest. The Anuswara M and Visarga ha &c., are not completely independent sounds. The accent known as Anudatta is produced in the heart, Udatha in the head, Swarita under the ear and Prachaya in the whole face".

 This gives the fundamental physiological principles of producing sounds by man. The accents refer to the directions of sound. We will see as we proceed with the quotations, how these principles are utilized for the formation of Manthras.

 ***Q. No. III.***

 "Every sound or Nama refers to some object and every object is known by some sound or name. If the significance of a stipulated sound or Nama is known, a small sound could be found to apply to a large area of objectivity. The name and its object are the modifications of Prakriti which is the glory of Siva and his consort. The glory alluding to sound or Nama is of three varieties, namely, the Sthula which is

audible, the Sukshma which is only mentally known and the Para which is beyond the cognisance of mind".

 The coexistence of Nama and Rupa, sound and its object, is here explained, also the three states in which a sound could exist.

 ***Q. No. IV.***

 "The name Manu and the characteristic of Manu, are mentioned in the texts with some object, and they refer to Vishnu in some form".

 The origin of Manu as well as the significance of the name are already beginning to differ from the Pandit's conceptions and he must be prepared to hear stranger things soon about the Manus, which will make him sick to think of our sacred literature.

* **Q. No. V.***

 "Samgna, Rajni, Prabha and Chaya are the four wives of Surya or the sun. Manu,in whose family all the kings and rulers originated, is the son of Surya by Samgna".

 Here Samgna clearly means the intellect, and the names of the other three wives are equally significant. Surya or sun represents the Atma. These terms shall be explained more fully in the next section on Personality. In the meantime, it is enough to note that the Pandit's literal interpretation of Manu being the son of the sun, would naturally render the origin of the so-called earthly rulers here specified, unintelligible to ordinary human beings. It would be very uncharitable on his part to expect the rest of mankind to he furnished with unhinged brains like himself and his illustrious colleagues.

 ***Q. No. VI.***

 "The first six Manus, namely, Swayombhuva, Swarochisha, Uttama, Tamasa, Ryvata and Chakshusha have

passed over. The seventh and the present Manu is Vyvaswata, the son of the sun. In the first Dwapara-yuga of thisManwantara, the first Manu, Swayambhuva himself held the post of Vyasa. In the twenty-fifth Dwapara, Krishnadwypayana, son of Parasara, became Vyasa. The future seven Manus are Savaranas or of the same caste of Vyvaswata, named, Savarna, Deksha-Savarna, Bramha-Savarna-Dharma, Rudra-Savarna, Rowchya and Bhowtya".

 These fourteen Manus will be explained in the subsequent quotations. But it is believed that the Pandit and Critic have no more explanations to offer here than a mere paraphrase in some indistinct style. The text however is simple enough to understand the language, and does not demand the help of the Pandit on that score. But the Pandit is of course quite indifferent to the purport of its contents, and it would certainly be an infringement upon his established rights to worry him with questions on such silly matters.

 ***Q No. VII.***

 "The future should be ascertained from the past. and both from the present. The Manwantaras should be determined by this method. The basis for Manwantaras consists of the Sapta-rishis, Devas, Pitris and Manus and in their midst are the Prajas. The Rishis, Devas, Pitris and Manus ascend and descend accompanied by Manthras. They are destroyed at the end of a Manwantara and created at the end of the destruction. The Devas are the sons of Rishis and Pitris the sons of Devas. That the Rishis themselves are the sons of Devas, is settled in the Sastras. The four Manus named Swarochisha, Uttama, Thamasa and Ryvata belong to the family of Priyavrata. The Manwantaras of Chakshusha the sixth and Vyvaswata the seventh Manus are declining.

From their time, creation is by union. The previous creations are by thought, sight and touch".

 The quotations are surely becoming more and more vexatious. This gives the best opportunity for all the different varieties of modern interpreters to join together dropping their individual opinions, and to march out clearing the field altogether. None of them could find definite points for the exercise of their ingenuity here. There is no exaggeration, no poetical fancy. Everything here is irrelevant and incoherent as long as the subject is not studied.Every line in the quotation must be confessed as unintelligible to the modern learned interpreters. The Devas are said to be the sons of Rishis and Rishis the sons of Devas This paradox is not even allowed to be questioned. The Sastras have so settled. Could the Pandit or Critic tell us what the description means? The Rishis, Devas, Pitris and Manus ascend and descend with Manthras, in the Manwantaras. Will the Pandit enlighten us with some vague idea at least of all these statements? Creation in the previous Manwantaras is said to have been conducted by thought, sight and touch. Does the local Pandit at least understand the process? Modern creation is said to be by union. Here of course all the modern interpreters are in their own atmosphere. This is the only portion in the quotation they approve of as correct and clearly intelligible. They are so happy to find after all, the very thing sought for in these texts all this time. And these are our modern religious authorities.

**कतिचिदुद्धतनिर्भरमत्सराः कतिचिदात्मवचः स्तुतिशालिनः।  
अहहकेऽपि निरक्षरकुक्षयस्तदिह सम्प्रति कम्प्रति मे श्रमः॥**

*  **Q. No. VIII.***

 "The woman named Sata-rupa, or of hundred forms, is known as Savitri the wife of Bramha, she is the mother of

the seven Rishis named Pulastya and others, of Deksha and other Prejapatis and of Swayambhuva and other Manus".

 Here, we have the parentage of the Rishis, Manus and Prajapathis traced to Bramha and Savitri.Gayatri or Savitri clearly represents the famous Manthra well-known to the Hindus. Our venerable Pandit well-versed in the sacred Manthras can now clearly understand that the fourteen Manus born of Savitri reigned in Oudh and Delhi in olden days with all the pomp and splendour of an Emperor. He knows Manthras producing kingdoms and rulers of. kingdoms in India. It is indeed a pity, he yet knows no Manthra which will furnish him with common sense. He could ere this have easily found out by a little thought in his sober moments, that for the said purpose, this very Gayatri is prescribed in our ancient religion.

**गायकं त्रायते यस्मात् गायत्रीत्युच्यते हि सा॥**

 ***Q. No. IX.***

 "In the science called Siksha, the vowels are treated as more important than the consonants. The consonants are like gems strung in the thread of vowels. The vowels overpower the consonants like a powerful monarch appropriating the kingdom of a weak monarch".

 The use of this quotation will soon be explained.

* **Q. No. X.***

 "The Bramhan has three kinds of body, namely, Sthula, Sukshma and Para.The Virat is Sthula known as Pancha-Brahman. Hiranyagarbha is Sukshma, called Nada or sound made of three Bija letters.Para is the unknowable Parom-Bramhan, whose attributes are, Sat, Chit, Ananda and Satya. The eternal Nada is known as Sabda-Bramhan. From the Sakti residing in the Muladhar in the form of Bindu, a Sukshma sound originates, known as Pasyanti, by

which the Yogis see everything. The same sound passing to the heart makes a thundering noise, and it is known as Madhyama. When this is combined with the vowels known as Prana, it is called Vykhari. It then expresses itself as the various letters of the alphabet, from A to Ksha. From these letters, words are produced; from words sentences originate. All Manthras are made of sentences, also the Vedas, Sastras, Puranas,languages, musical compositions &c. The force of breath slowly acting upon the life principle, produces this Vykhari sound. This Sakti or power residing in the heart of all is called Saraswati. When the Yogi perceives her in his Atma, he obtains the power of producing Vedas, Sastras and Puranas of his own accord".

 This quotation explains the highest imaginable form of Bramhan and the corresponding idea of the purest sound by which it may be named. This is an important matter in our religious literature, without a clear knowledge of which there would be endless confusion in the interpretation of the texts. Three forms are here postulated for the formless Bramhan known as Virat, Hiranyagarbha and Parom. The Parom is entirely formless and represents the true condition. The Virat or Sthula philosophically understood consists of name and form alone, that is Nama and Rupa. Hiranya-garbha is described as the Sukshma form, practically meaning the mere meditation of the Bramhan without a form. It represents the purest idea of Bramhan the human intellect is capable of grasping. Having virtually eliminated all possible forms in this grand conception of Bramhan, its name or Nama alone now remains. An appropriate name has now to be given to this most abstract idea. The very first and simplest sound uttered by man can alone properly apply to this conception of Sukshma-Bramhan. In fact, such a name or sound is explained here as its only characteristic mark and hence it is named Sabda-Bramhan.

**हिरण्यगर्भं सूक्ष्मन्तुनादं बीजत्रयात्मकम्।  
अक्षरं परमोनादःशब्दब्रह्मेति कथ्यते॥**

We have just seen in quotation No. 2 that the very first and the purest sound produced in the human system is known as Mandra and this very sound is certainly the fittest nomenclature for the Bramhan under reference.

**मारुतस्तूरसिचरन् मन्द्रं जनयतिस्वरम्॥**

The subject will be explained more fully later on. If the Pandit has eyes and the willingness to use them, he could observe here that Bramha or Hiranyagarbha described as the father of the Rishis, Manus, Devas and Pitris has no form and that he is known as Sabda-Bramhan. His children specified here could therefore naturally possess no forms and they should represent some further evolutions of Bramha in the sphere of sounds or Namas constituting the essential ingredients of the religious and sacred Manthras. If the Pandit is prepared to digest these facts with repenting tears, he is likely to find ere long, that the hitherto unintelligible passages overflow with serious and important religious instructions.

**पुस्तकेषु च नाधीतं नाधीतं गुरुसन्निधौ।  
न शोभन्ते सभामध्ये हंसमध्ये बको यथा॥**

*** Q. No. XI.***

 "Vishnu created Virat and he created Purusha called Manu to whom Manwantara belongs. Manu is the second stage from Manasa, known as Manwantara. Manu created the Prejas and in the creation by Vishnu, no one is born from the womb of the mother. Deksha and other kings appear periodically in the Yugas and disappear in the same manner. There is no difference observed among themselves as elders or youngsters. Their positions depend upon the

amount of Tapas acquired. No wise man is therefore puzzled at their appearance or disappearance".

 The origin of Manus is here stated as the second stage from Manasa. The Manu is also mentioned as the production of Virat. We have already found that Manasa represents the twenty-fifth Tatwom. It is therefore certain that the term Manu also refers to one of the lower Tatwoms. The general standard by which the importance of Deksha and other periodical kings should be judged, is also said to be, the quantity of Tapas specified. As usual, the Pandit has absolutely nothing to enlighten us here. We may therefore very well proceed without waiting for his help. It would be a great boon if he only refrains from throwing filth on our way.

***Q. No. XII.***

 "Bramha created Virat. From the Manasa, Vyraja known as Samraud originated, called Manu.The first Purusha named Swayambhuva, is known as Manu.This Manu created the Prajas. A daughter named Sata-rupa, two sons named Priyavrata and Uttanapada and again two daughters named Akuti and Presuti were born from him. He gave Presuti in marriage to Deksha. Here Deksharepresents Prana and Manu represents Samkalpa. Bramha desirous of creating Prajas meditated sorrowfully. Immediately Kumara of divine scent originated, uttering the divine Sruti, unknowable by the senses. The Veda then originated from Om. From its 14 faces,14 vowels originated also 33 consonants. Then from these vowels 14 Manus originated constituting the divine vowels of the Manwantaras. The first vowel A originated from the first of the 14 faces and is named Swayambhuva Manu. Similarly from the remaining 13 faces, 13 vowels originated with the names of the remaining Manus. They are of white, red, black and other varieties

of colours. In this manner, the vowels, consonants and Manus originated. Thevowels in themselves being of the same caste or family, the Anwaya or Vamsa of the Manus is thereby signified".

 A good deal of technicalities is here clearly explained. The significance of Manu and Deksha-Prejapati is pointed out in the plainest terms.

**प्राणो दक्षस्तु विज्ञेयः सङ्कल्पो मनुरुच्यते॥**

Deksha represents Prana or the Life Principle and Manu denotes Samkalpa, mental resolution or determination. The Pandit need not here shed his false tears for the deaths of his anthropological Manus and Dekshas. He has never loved or respected ther, and even when he comes to know that they are still alive, he is not going to be faithful to them.The 14 Manus are said to allude to the 14 vowel sounds originating from Bramha's 14 faces. The vowels being of the same family, the idea is expressed as the Manu's family or Vamsanucharita in the Puranas.

**परस्परसवर्णाश्च स्वरायस्माद्वृता हि वै।  
तस्मात्तेषां स वर्णत्वादन्वयस्तु प्रकीर्तितः॥**

The Manwantara noticed in the previous quotation similarly refers to the continuity of the vowel sounds specified.

**द्वितीयं मानसस्यैतन्मनोरन्तरमुच्यते॥**

Concerning these two terms, namely, Manwantara and Vamsanu-charita, used in the Puranas and Itihasas, we can now easily perceive the extreme absurdity in the modern interpretation as referring to, the Geological periods of this mother-earth or the historical periods of its inhabitants. The significance of the 14 vowel sounds said to be produced from the faces of Bramha shall soon be understood by going

through the succeeding quotations. The modern interpreters in general are likely to be excited at the sight of these strange quotations. But could they with a vengeance condemn the whole as later interpolations? If so, will they kindly condescend to tell us for what purpose they were interpolated, when and by whom? They will certainly be compelled to lay the blame on the indigenous Pandit but his complete innocence in this matter could be easily proved by his own ignorance of the passages. No foreigner or stranger to the Sanskrit language could be pitched upon either. The theory of supposed interpolation therefore is but a frivolous attack upon the sacred literature and does not deserve to be noticed. Its frequent application however, naturally creates a strong suspicion against its motive and propriety. Those who claim to be recognised as civilized,ought to be more careful in the use of this weak but shameful weapon, in future.

 ***Q. No. XIII.***

 "From Siva, the ultimate and pure intelligence, an unbroken perpetual sound of great. brightness has naturally emanated with the Sakti. That very sound shines brightly in the Muladhar all creatures. It then passes through the Bramha-nadi to the heart and becomes distinct as Sukshma. The same unbroken sound reaches the Bramharendra or brain, the brightest and blissful seat of Siva, and becomes tranquil by His proximity. In the Adhara, the seat of Sakti, the sound represents a single happy letter.In the centre above Aagna, the single letter becomes Sukshma. In the third centre called Pooraka two letters become one.This is the first natural and well-known Manthra. It is called a Manthra because it saves one meditating upon it. The goddess of letters has therefore naturally originated from this first Manthra. The direction of one letter here is

upwards and of the other is downwards. This first Manthra is therefore the significant word denoting the ever brilliant Siva and is the greatest Manu or Manthra. Thus the Apada or inexpressible becomes Pada or expressible and the latter again merges in the former. To know this is great knowledge. He who grasps the Pada obtains control over the Manthras and nothing is unattainable for him. For the benefit of mankind a portion of this Pada divides itself into 16, 5, 2, 32, or 33 &c. The Goddess of letters has three aspects, the Sthula, Sukshma and Susukshma being the development from the Sakti itself. Every Manthra should be uttered with a knowledge of this dignity of it. Pranava is of two sorts, the Para and Apara. The Para is the Para-Bramhan itself and is called Pranava being ever new. The Apara is in the form of the purest sound and is also called Pranava, because it serves as the medium for attaining the Para-Bramhan. The letter Om represents the totality of everything in the Universe, without the individual names of objects, and it therefore denotes Bramha".

 The religious technicalities of the varieties of sounds constituting the holy Manthras, as well as the philosophical and physiological origins of such sounds, are detailed in this quotation. We cannot here afford to go into the details of the Manthra-Sastra which is a great science in itself. It would be enough to note here, that the Manus undoubtedly allude to such Manthras, and that their apparent history deals with the actual explanation of their varieties and stages prescribed for devotional progress, accompanied by meditation upon the glories of God specified by their corresponding Manthras. We might also notice in this connection, especially for the purpose of satisfying the curiosity of our readers, that the creation by union mentioned in quotation 7 refers to the joining of single sounds or letters to consti-

tute Manthras. It never denotes the process of animal creation as absurdly and shamelessly explained by the modern interpreters. The mutual parentage of the Rishis, Devas and Pitris, paradoxically described in the same quotation, will shortly be explained in the next section on Personalities,exposing the complete ignorance of our existing religious authorities.

***Q. No. XIV.***

 "There are 51 letters in all from. A to Ksha, by which the Manthras are composed, which allude to the forms and Tatwas prescribed for religious meditation. From Sivatatwa Bindu originates. From Bindu, Nada originates at the end of which Sakti originates. From Sakti, Sabda; from Sabda, Vakbhava; from it Kala and from which again Vikala originates. With these, Manthras are composed. This is the process of evolution or creation, whose characteristics shall here be explained. Bindu is Para-Sakti and Nada is Adi-Sakti. Sakti is Icha or desire to create, and Sabda is Gnana.Vakbhava means Kriya-Sakti and Kala represents the 16 vowels. The terms Icha, Vidya, Gnana, Pratishta, Nivriti and Kriya are synonymous. Seven vowels are known as Prakriti and nine as Vikriti. Kala, Matra, Swara, Jiva, Prakriti, Vikriti, Prana, Atma and Dehi are synonymous terms alluding to the vowels. The consonants constitute the Bindu and are known by thesynonymous terms, Deha, Upadhi, Sarira, Kshetra, Adhara, Tanu and Vikala. The first 3 vowels denote Akasa; the next 3, air; the next 4, fire; the next 3, water and the last 3, earth. Prakriti represents the Tatwa-bija or the essential letter, and Vikriti denotes the form. Vikala refers to Prabhava, power or efficacy. Prakriti is short and of one Matra, Vikriti is long and of two Matras, and consonant is of half Matra. Kala is the life and Vikala is the body. The

Sthula sound is called Sabda, the Sukshma is mental and Parom is beyond it. The meditation that saves one from worldly miseries is called a Manthra. Siva presents himself before us by the application of a proper Manthra, like one addressed courteously by his proper name. Pranava is the life of all Manthras and is the letter representing Siva among all other letters. The form of Pranava is constituted in accordance with the formulas relating to Bindu and Nada".

 This quotation itself furnishes more details than would be consistent with the scope of this essay. Those who are really interested in this special branch of religious science, could easilyobtain plenty of technical treatises on the subject. For our main purpose here, we have only to understand and remember one or two important facts explained in the quotation. The Manthras are said to be composed of vowels and consonants, the vowels being called Kalas divided into Prakritis and Vikritis, and the consonants being known as Vikalas. Viewed as a mere grammatical classification, the description conveys no meaning, as all the languages in the world are formed by the combinations of vowels and consonants. There must therefore be a technical difference maintained in all such religious matters, the modern ignorance of which naturally gives rise to unpleasant and unnecessary criticisms. First of all a Manthra is distinguished from a verbal expression of an ordinary idea, by its peculiar aptitude for saving a man from worldly miseries by his meditation upon the Tatwa alluded to in the Manthra.

**मननघ्राणधर्मित्वान्मन्त्रमित्यभिधीयते॥**

Secondly, the vowels and consonants used in the composition of a Manthra are called Kalas and Vikalas, only on account of their situation within the Manthra. The terms

Kriya-Sakti, Icha-Sakti, Vidya, Gnana and Pratishta are mentioned in the quotation as synonymous with Nivriti or involutionary process. The letters therefore that go to  
form a Manthra which takes us back to the creator, are alone given the name specified here, namely, Kala, Prakriti, Vikriti and Vikala. The same letters used in any language, for the purpose of communicating common ideas or for expressing abuses, cannot therefore be called by the names here given.

**निवृत्तिस्यात् क्रियाशक्तिः तस्याः पर्यायवाचकाः॥**

There is after all, nothing very strange in the conception of this simple principle, as everything in this world could be used both for good and evil purposes. Another important point to be noticed here, is the formation of the syllable Om called Pranava. It is not the stipulation of any meaningless sound uttered by the ancient Rishis at random. It is clearly stated to be specially composed, conforming to the  
principles relating to Nada and Bindu.

**बिन्दुनादप्रकारेण प्रणवाकृतिरीरिता॥**

It is earnestly hoped that the foregoing general explanations pertaining to the Manus and Manwantaras, will suffice for our respectable readers to form some definite idea of the subject as a whole. It is also anxiously feared that any more of similar explanations might not prove effectual in cowing down the presumptuous Pandit.

**गले पाशस्तीव्रश्चरणयुगले गाढः निगटो  
दृढं स्कन्धे बद्धः शिरसि सृणिपातः खरतरः।  
नरः स्कन्धारूढो बत रमणयोग्येऽपि विषये  
न जानीमोऽत्यर्थं द्विरद वद कस्मात्तव मदः॥**

 ***Q No. XV.***

 "The syllable Om referring to Bramhan viewed aggregately and as made up of individual bodies, is called Sam-

hara and Srishti. Pranavas respectively. It is also distinguished as internal, external or both, as half-matra Pranava or Samhara Pranava and Srishti-Pranava. The internal or Anta-pranava is divided into eight parts, namely, A, U, M, half-matra, Nada, Bindu, Kala and Sakti. The A has ten thousand parts; U, one thousand; M, one hundred, and half-matra, endless parts. Saguna is Virat-pranava; Nirguna is Samhara-pranava, both combined is Utpathi-pranava. The Samhara-pranava is beyond the thirty-six Tatwas and consists of 16 Matras, namely, A,U,M, half matra, Nada, Bindu, Kala, Kalatita, Santi, Santyatita, Unmani, Manonmani, Puri, Madhyama, Pasyanti and Para. Again, the Pranava splits itself into Purusha and Prakriti consisting of 64 Matras and takes the form of Saguna-nirguna consisting of 28 Matras. In this manner, the single Brahma-pranava takes different forms and it is the real basis for everything in the Universe".

 This quotation also is technical enough to be completely Greek to the Pandit and the Critic. The next quotation will be more explanatory, and it may be stated here that the details given in these passages will have to be referred to in future, for explaining many of the passages unintelligible to the modern interpreters.

***Q. No. XVI.***

 "A short sound is of one Matra, long sound two Matras, protracted sound three Matras and a consonant is half-Matra. The smallest atom of time is named Leva. If a number of lotus leaves placed one above the other be pierced through by a sharp needle, the time taken for the needle to pass from one leaf to another is reckoned as a Leva, and it is the smallest unit of time above which is the Mahat unaffected by time and space. 256 Levas inake one Matra and the following is the measurement of the nine Nadas. A Bindu is 128 Levas;

Ardhachandra is 64; Rodhini, 32; Nada, 16; Nadanta, 8; Sakti, 4; Vyapika, 2; Samana, 1 and Unmana 1/2, Levas. The 6 lotuses are the Chakras.Tripura-sundari or the Goddess called Para is the creatress of the Sukshma sound. She shines there and is called Matrika. The desire to create Viswa originates in her and she is then called Pasyanti being made up of 8 Saktis known as Vama &c. Between the Sukshma and Sthula stages, she is called Madhyama, in which state the 9 Nadas specified above extend from Muladhar to Bramha-rendhra in their unmodified condition. In Sthula or audible state called Vykhari, the 9 Nadas develop themselves into the 9. sets of letters in the Alphabet, bėginning with A, Ka, Cha, Ta, Tha, Pa, Ya, Sa and La. The conjunction of the pure Siva and the pure Sakti here described for the origin of this creation detailed, should be understood as alluding to the work of the pure mind. The sounds A and Ha are Sukshma denoting the exposition of the brightness of Bramhan which is the real Ahom. The foremost of all sounds is A, and Ha is the last of the vowels, the former referring to Siva and the latter to its perception. Ha consists of double Bindu and combined with A refers to the totality of the 16 vowels and both the letters signify Sunya or nothingness".

 This quotation is equally technical and more explanatory than the former in its details.

Q. *No. XVII.***

 "I shall tell you the real character of a Manthra.The syllable Om or Pranava, made up of five parts,namely, A, U, M, Bindu and Nada, is the very starting point in the Veda and it is described as the real Manthra by the Vedas.Nada represents the total aggregate idea and the remaining four denote the individual separate ideas."

 The syllable Om is explained here as the real Manthra.

It is also said to contain within itself the total and individual conceptions of existence.

***Q. No. XVII.***

 "A Manthra particularly signifies, the religious Karma, its mode of performance and the specific image or the performer's conception of God."

 The devotee being saved by meditation, it is called a Manthra, and it is the verbal expression of the idea of God.

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698729857Screenshot(34"/>.png)The above quotations on the point at issue are no doubt somewhat tiresome, although the necessary explanations are not yet sufficiently complete. The subject is strictly technical and most important for the purpose ofcomprehen-ding the applicability of the Vedas and Manthras. The temptation therefore to give as full a treatment as possible is great not only on account of the amount of scientific informations imbedded therein, but more on account of the immensity of ignorance, indifference and perversity unfortunately evinced in modern days in its interpretation.

 The inseparable association of thought and word, object and its name being psychologically established, a detailed analysis of their origin and relation is scientifically treated in Siksha, specifying also the physiological locations of sound in the human body. The direct influence of words on thought is thus a scientific fact and not a matter of blind belief. must therefore be generally conceded that if any of the existing religions in the world would recognise the efficacy of prayer, the Manthras in themselves are not useless or superstitious. Taking a more scientific and philosophical view of the subject, the ultimate object to be attained, namely Brahman must logically have its corresponding word or name and this is known as Sabda-Brahman. Of course

it refers only to the highest stage below that of Para-Bramhan but leading to the same.

**शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति॥**

The Manthras are therefore variously composed and classified so as to serve different purposes for advancement in religious merit and to suit the varying capacities and qualifications of man. It is thus clear that every Manthra is not fit to be adopted by everybody without discrimination, the oneprescribed for a Sanyasi is not suited to a family man. This simple fact in modern days is too often misunderstood and criticised as the product of Brahmanical pride consequent on the desire for superiority and exclusiveness. But those who are inclined to admit the efficacy of a Manthra in any manner cannot consistently deny the necessity of considering the fitness of the person who wishes to be benefited by the same. Otherwise, it is like the meddling with the contents of a Laboratory without a knowledge of the fundamental principles of the science. The effort is not only useless but may prove dangerous too. Bluntly ignoring the scientific facts like electricity or other forces will not help, if the apparatus and chemicals in the room are wrongly made use of. Obstinate and silly perversities of this kind are not very rare with regard to the subject in question and they deserve only to be pitied rather than condemned.

**'अनुशोचाम एवान्यान् न भ्रान्तैर्विवदामहे'॥**

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698733256Screenshot(35"/>.png)In this section, we have examined and sifted al most every term used in the texts appearing as descriptions of time, extending from Lava or the minutest portion to Parardhom and Parom the highest figures in the Arithmetical Notation, and have clearly found that none of them have any reference to the ordinary reckoning of time so as to lead us to the belief in their applicability to the periods of histori-

cal incidents as commonly interpreted amongst us. The historical, archeological or geological proofs nowadays offered to establish the irrelevancies and inconsistencies in the Puranic statements, go therefore only to show the ignorance of the contents of our religious literature on the part of their Critics, without meaning anything derogatory to the scientific importance of their professed subjects. No better value or importance shall either be reasonably attached to the misdirected attempts of our native Pandits and Theosophists to explain those facts in a favourable attitude, by ununderstandable and extraneous methods virtually hood winking the public and concealing their own ignorance. We are helplessly compelled to turn round to them and say 'Physician heal thyself'.

**प्रयत्नैरस्तोकैः परिचितकुतर्कप्रकरणाः  
परं वाचो वश्यान् कतिपयपदौघान्विदधतः।  
सभायां वाचाटाः श्रुति कटुरटन्तो घटपटा-  
न्न लज्जन्ते मन्दाः स्वयमपि तु जिहेति विबुधः॥**

**<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698734959Screenshot(36"/>.png)**

**  SECTION III.**

**ON PERSONALITY.**

 It is earnestly hoped that the sacred documents hitherto ransacked must have to a great extent, convinced every reasonable and unbiased reader, of the fact that in the matter of religious evolution as well as involution, detailed in the texts, the gods and other personalities more or less allude to the efficient cause or spiritual agencies, and that the holy centres and the so-called geographical specifications refer to the material causes in general. They are known

as the Nimitha and Upadana Karanas. In the first section of this Chapter, we have examined the technical terms connected with the latter, and the present section has to seek for the significance of terms used to denote the former. The second section on Time, we have just finished stands in the position of a connecting link between the two.

  In this section, a logical classification of Personalities shall be maintained in accordance with their respective importance, for the proper comprehension of the ideas conveyed by each of them.

 We have been noticing all through in this essay, that the ultimate entity is described in our philosophy, by two different names, in accordance with the kind of view taken of it, namely, Para and Apara Brahmans. The latter is known also as Sabda-Bramhan and Purana--Purusha referring to the possibility of its being described by philosophical methods in the Puranas and Itihasas. The former of course is the inconceivable infinite of self-experience or Swanubhuti, regarding which no oral explanations could be ventured, especially of a positive character. It is attained only by negation of all phenominal affairs, and no religion or philosophy can afford to deal with it directly except through the medium of this Sabda Bramhan, whose knowledge itself has to be obtained by the regular methods prescribed for the purpose of getting over worldly desires and other obstacles on the path to onward progress. By reaching the ultimate terminus of this Sabda-Bramhan, man is naturally transported to the highest region called Para-Bramhan, and that is the only way of securing it.

**शब्दब्रह्मणि निष्णातः परं ब्रह्माधिगच्छति॥**

 This intervening territory of Sabda-Bramhan, between God and man is the blissful region of refuge provided for the

emancipation of the fallen man. The strange and insolent effort of the so-called Vedantists of the modern day to ignore this fact by hypocritical pretensions, and their attempt to transcend the limits of Sabda-Bramhan by impossible feats display only their intellectual weakness and moral bankruptcy. Ethics and religion are two inconvenient bug-bears to them obstructing freedom of thought and action. They can afford to jump over these unnecessary restrictions with their superior intellects and establish their rights to go ahead of all ordinary laws and rules. This is one of the worst and most pernicious use of religion and philosophy in the interest of unbridled and detestable conduct. Vedanta as generally understood, denotes the end of the Vedas, that could be reached only by going through the Vedas and by acting up to their ordinancesAs used by its modern professors, Vedanta practically means the end or annihilation of the Vedas altogether. All distinctions of right and wrong, good and bad, east and west, day and night, high and low, are abolished as unphilosophical, for the convenience of beastly self-interest, and universal indifference is preached all over the land as signifying true Vedantism.

**ब्रह्मैवसत्यमखिलं न हि किञ्चिदस्ति  
तस्मान्नमे सखि परावरभेदबुधिः।  
जारे तथा निजवरे सदृशोनुरागो।  
व्यर्थं किमर्थमसतीति कदर्थयन्ति॥**

 <MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1698736461Screenshot(37"/>.png)
Leaving the two Bramhans, namely Para and Apara, as the highest philosophical ideas, we might commence with our enquiry lower down, regarding the Tri-Murthis, the Bramha, Vishnu and Siva, the gods whose functions are so commonly known as creation, preservation and destruction.An examination of their real significance, as could be gathered from the texts direct is likely to prove

practically useful, especially as their relative superiority has constantly been a matter of serious dispute among the ordinary people, having been occasionally dragged for settlement to the courts of law. We may confine ourselves in the beginning to the original and general character of the functions assigned to the Triads, without going into the details of their subsequent transformations known as their respective incarnations. It is earnestly hoped that the following quotations will be of interest in this connection. Several of them are no doubt somewhat lengthy, but the vital importance of the subject prevents their curtailment or omission, in spite of their proving tiresome at times.
