महालक्ष्मीश्च वैकुण्ठे पतिसेवापरायणा।  
स्वर्गे च स्वर्गलक्ष्मीश्च राजलक्ष्मीश्च राजसु।  
गृहे च गृहलक्ष्मीश्च मर्त्यानां गृहिणां तथा।  
सर्वेषु प्राणिद्रव्येषु शोभारूपा मनोहरा।  
शक्तिर्द्वितीया कथिता वेदोक्ता सर्वसम्मता।  
वाक्बुद्धिविद्याज्ञानााधिदेवता परमात्मनः।  
सर्वविद्यास्वरूपा या सा च देवी सरस्वती।  
व्याख्या बोधस्वरूपा च सर्वसन्देहभञ्जिनी।  
देवी तृतीया गदिता श्रीयुक्ता जगदम्बिका।  
माता चतुर्णां वेदानां वेदाङ्गानाञ्च छन्दसाम्।  
सन्ध्यावन्दनमन्त्राणां तन्त्राणाञ्च विचक्षणा।  
पवित्ररूपा सावित्री गायत्री ब्रह्मणः प्रिया।  
ब्रह्मतेजोमयी शक्ति तदधिष्ठातृदेवता।  
देवी चतुर्था कथिता पञ्चमी वर्णयामि ते।  
प्रेमप्राणाधिदेवी या पञ्चप्राणस्वरूपिणी।  
गोलोकवासिनी देवी गोपिवेषविधायिका।  
परमाह्लादरूपा च सन्तोषामर्षरूपिणी।  
वेदानुसारध्यानेन विज्ञेया सा विचक्षणैः।  
कथिता पञ्चमी देवी सा राधा परिकीर्तिता।  
ऐश्वर्यवचनः शक् च तिः पराक्रमवाचकः।**

**तत्स्वरूपा ययोर्दात्री या सा शक्तिःप्रकीर्तिता।  
समृद्धि बुद्धि सम्पत्ति यशसां वचनो भगः।  
तेन शक्तिर्भगवती भगरूपा च सा सदा।  
रा शब्दोचारणाद्भक्तो राति मुक्तिं सुदुर्लभाम्।  
धा शब्दोच्चारणाद्दुर्गे धावत्येव हरेःपदम्।  
रा इत्यादानवचनो वा च निर्वाणवाचकः।  
ततोऽवाप्नोति मुक्तिंच तेन राधा प्रकीर्तिता।  
मङ्गलं मोक्षवचनं चाशब्दो दातृवाचकः।  
सर्वान् मोक्षान् या ददाति सैव स्यात्सर्वमङ्गला।  
हर्षे सस्पदि कल्याणे मङ्गलं परिकीर्तितम्।  
तान् ददाति च सर्वेभ्यःतेन सा सर्वमङ्गला।  
अम्बेति मातृवचनो वन्दने पूजने सदा।  
पूजिता वन्दिता माता जगतां तेन साम्बिका।  
सृष्टौ च विष्णुना सृष्टा वैष्णवी तेन कीर्तिता।  
गौरःपीते च निर्लिप्ते परे ब्रह्मणि निर्मले।  
तस्यात्मनः शक्तिरियं गौरी तेन प्रकीर्तिता।  
गुरुः शम्भुश्चसर्वेषां तस्य शक्तिः प्रिया सती।  
गुरुःकृष्णश्च तन्माया गौरी तेन प्रकीर्तिता।  
तिथिभेदे पर्वभेदे कल्पभेदेन्यभेदके।  
ख्यातौ तेषु च विख्याता पार्वती तेन कीर्तिता।  
महोत्सवविशेषे च पर्वन्निति सुकीर्तिता।  
तस्याधिदेवी या सा च पार्वती परिकीर्तिता।  
सर्वकाले सना प्रोक्ताविस्तृते च तनीति च।  
सर्वत्र सर्वकाले च विद्यमाना सनातनी।  
कृत्तिका ज्ञानवत्यश्च योगिन्यःप्रकृतेः कलाः।  
इमाश्च सर्वसिद्धिज्ञाःपरमैश्वर्यसंयुताः।  
दैत्य नाशार्थवचनो दकारःपरिकीर्तितः।  
उकारो विघ्ननाशार्थंवाचको वेदसम्मतः।  
रेफो रोगघ्नवचनो गश्च पापघ्नवाचकः।  
भयशत्रुघ्नवचनश्चाकारः परिकीर्तितः।**

**स्मृत्युक्तिस्मरणाद्यस्या एते नश्यन्ति निश्चितम्।  
अतो दुर्गा हरेः शक्तिर्हरिणा परिकीर्तिता।  
विपत्तिवाचको दुर्गश्चाकारो नाशवाचकः।  
दुर्गं नश्यति या नित्यं सा दुर्गा परिकीर्तिता।  
शश्च कयाणवचन इकारोत्कृष्टवाचकः।  
समूहवाचकश्चैव वाकारो दातृवाचकः।  
श्रेयस्सङ्घोत्कृष्टदात्री शिवा तेन प्रकीर्तिता।  
अभयो भयनाशोक्तश्चाकारो दातृवाचकः।  
प्रददात्यभयं सद्यः साऽभया परिकीर्तिता।  
राजश्रीवचनो माश्चयाश्च प्रापणवाचकः।  
तां प्रापयति या सद्यः सा माया परिकीर्तिता।  
माश्चमोक्षार्थवचनो याश्च प्रापणवाचकः।  
तं प्रापयति या नित्यं सा माया परिकीर्तिता।  
नारायणार्धाङ्गभूता तेन तुल्या च तेजसा।  
तदा तस्य शरीरस्था तेन नारायणी स्मृता।  
निर्गुणस्य च नित्यस्य वाचकश्च सनातनः।  
सदा नित्या निर्गुणा या कीर्तिता सा सनातनी।  
जयःकल्याणवचनो याकारो दातृवाचकः।  
जयं ददाति या नित्यं सा जया परिकीर्तिता।  
सर्वमङ्गलशब्दश्च सम्पूर्णैश्वर्यवाचकः।  
आकारो दातृवचनस्तद्दात्री सर्वमङ्गला।  
विष्णुभक्तिरहं तेन विष्णुमाया च वैष्वणवी।  
नारायणस्य मायाहं तेन नारायणीस्मृता॥**

**ब्रह्मवैवर्तपुराणम्॥**

***  Q. No. VI.***

**ब्रह्माण्डमूर्ध्नि गायत्री स्तुता वेदैस्तु नित्यशः।  
जननी सर्वविद्यानां गुह्यविद्येति गीयते।  
खेचरा सा विनिर्दिष्टा सर्वप्राणिषु संस्थिता।  
दृश्यादृश्याचला नित्या व्यक्ताव्यक्ता सनातनी।**

**अवर्णा वर्णसंयुक्ता प्रोच्यते बिन्दुमालिनी।  
तां पश्यन् सर्वदा योगी कृतकृत्योऽभिजायते॥**

**श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. VII.***

**संविदेव पराशक्तिर्नेतरा परमार्थतः।  
अतःसंविदितां नित्यं पूजयेन्मुनिसत्तमाः।  
संविद्रूपातिरेकेण यत्किञ्चित् प्रतिभासते।  
स हि संसार आख्यातः सर्वेषामात्मनामपि।  
अतः संसारनाशाय साक्षिणीमात्मरूपणम्।  
आराधयेत्परां शक्ति प्रपञ्चोल्लासवर्जिताम्॥**

**यथा भातेन रूपेण शिव एवेति या मतिः।  
सा शिवा परमा संविन्नापरा न हि संशयः॥**

**स्कान्दपुराणं-सूतसंहिता ॥**

***Q. No. VIII.***

**गोविन्द एव पुरुषो ब्रह्माद्याः स्त्रिय एव च।  
तत एवं स्वभावोऽयं प्रकृतेर्भाव ईश्वरः।  
पुरुषप्रकृती चाद्यौ राधा बृन्दावनेश्वरौ॥**

**शतरूपा च या नारी सावित्री सात्विहोच्यते।  
भार्या सा ब्रह्मणः प्रोक्ता ऋषीणां जननी च सा।  
पुलस्त्याद्यान् मुनीन् सप्त दक्षाद्यांश्च प्रजापतीन्।  
स्वायम्भुवादींश्च मनून् सावित्री समजीजनत्॥**

**इदं जगस्थितं भीष्म गङ्गासिक्तसङ्ख्यया।  
यत् किञ्चित् भवते वृत्तं तत्परं वेद सर्ववित्।  
स्वायंभुवे हतो दैत्यो वैष्णव्या मन्दरे गिरौ।  
महिषाख्योभिभाष्यश्च स च वैवखते पुनः।  
नन्दया निहतो विन्ध्ये महाबलपराक्रमः।  
अथवा ज्ञानशक्तिश्च महिषोऽज्ञानमूर्तिमान्।  
अज्ञानं ज्ञानसाध्यन्तु भवतीह न संशयः।  
मूर्तिपक्षे चेतिहासो मन्मूर्तिःखेन बाध्यते।  
ख्याप्यते वेदवादैस्तु अहंतैर्वेदवादिभिः॥**

**सर्वाक्षरमयं दिव्यं योगपीठमिति स्मृतम्।  
तन्मध्येष्टदलं पत्मं उदयार्कसमप्रभम्।  
तन्मध्ये कर्णिकायान्तु सावित्र्यां शुभदर्शने।  
ईश्वर्या सह देवेशस्तत्रासीनः परः पुमान्।  
विमलोत्कर्षिणी ज्ञाना क्रिया योगा तथैव च।  
प्रह्वी सत्या तथेशाना महिष्यःपरमात्मनः॥**

**पद्मपुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. IX.***

**अनादिनिधनस्याथ जज्ञे नारायणस्य या।  
उरोःसर्वानवद्याङ्गीउर्वश्येकादशी स्मृता।  
मेनस्य मेनका कन्या ब्रह्मणो हृष्टचेतसः।  
सर्वाश्च ब्रह्मवादिन्यो महायोगाश्च ताः स्मृताः॥**

**वायुपुराणम्॥**

***  Quotation. No. I.***

 "Devi concentrated her thoughts and created the big egg of Jegat. She is therefore called Sringara-kala and Kama-kala. Bramha originated from herself, so also Vishnu, Rudra, Marut-ganas, Gandharvas, Apsaras, Kinneras and other musicians all at once. All the enjoyable objects originated. Everything pertaining to Sakti originated, All the varieties of animal life originated. She is Para-Sakti. By the abandonment of the five forms which do not belong to her real form, their basis the real Tatwa remains eternal. The various philosophical canons, 'I am Bramhan,' "Thou art That' &c, represent this Devi of the sixteenth stage, recognised by the Manthras made up of 15 letters and known by various names, such as, Sri-vidya, Maha-tripura-sundari, Balambika, Bekala, Mathengi, Swayomvara-kalyani, Bhuvaneswari, Chamunda, Chanda, Varahi, Tiras karini, Raja-mathengi, Suka-syamala, Leghu-syamala, Aswarudha, Pretyamgira, Dhumavati, Savitri, Saraswati and Bramhananda-kala."

 The Devi here described as the mother of the Triads and of the whole universe is the Satwic Maya which is clearly explained as representing the highest knowledge to be attained by philosophy. The several names here given allude to the shades of difference in the conceptions of the same Devi for different purposes.Devi is stated to be the religious conception as the sixteenth stage called Sri-vidya, meaning clearly the highest and the truest knowledge. No explanations co**u**ld be ventured here regarding the Manthra made up of 15 letters which applies to her, as the science of manthras is in itself a separate and important subject. It has been already noticed to some extent in the previo**u**s section. It may be specially noticed in this connection,for the information of the younger generation of educated Hindus, that there is nothing unphilosophical or unsceintific in the description furnished in this sacred Upanishad, The Devi is not an allegorical or unscientific mythological figure as generally understood, but she represents the ultimate knowledge of the Absolute, a most philosophical, scientific and practical fact, which however demands some effort, thought and devotion for its realisation. The knowledge specified is clearly defined in the religious texts as logically and scientifically as any of the modern scientific terms. The only defects that stand in the way of its understanding are the prevailing indifference and the unwise, unpatriotic and irreverent antipathy of the rising generation. It is however a serious mistake to attribute this tendency to any drawbacks in the modern civilization which doubtless sets one athinking. A sensible exposition of the subject that would amply satisfy the enquiring minds is the real desideratum. It may therefore be assured for the hundredth time in this essay that the texts in themselves are in no way defective but are sufficiently valuable for the present generation and a few generations to come. The

safest and the best suggestion that could be offered under the present state of affairs is to study the original texts oneself praying to this Devi direct to exhibit her real form as explained in the above quotation.

**सत्वादिस्थैरगणितगुणैर्हन्त विश्व प्रसूय  
व्यक्तं धत्ते प्रहसनकरीं या कुमारीति संज्ञाम्।  
मोहध्वान्तप्रसरविरतिर्विश्व मूर्तिः समन्ता-  
दाद्याशक्तिःस्फुरतु मम सा दीपवद्देहगेहे॥**

***Q. No II.***

 "May the goddess Saraswati whose form is the very essence of the Vedanta, protect me. She is the Sakti of Bramhan that is dealt with in the Vedas and Vedangas as the only one. She directs the three Lokas internally by her involutionary work. She is the guiding principle in Rudra, Aditya &c., and she is enjoyed by those who turn their eyes inwards in their involutionary process of work. She is the expanding knowledge divided into eight parts. She is Nirvikalpa and the form of the Bramhan meditating on whom the Yogis deliver themselves from bondage. May the pure and white Saraswati residing in the face of Bramha take rest in my heart''.

 The goddess Saraswati is here described as the ultimate knowledge and form of Brahman and particularly explained as enjoyed by those who turn their eyes inward back to the Bramhan.

**या प्रत्यक् दृष्टिभिर्जीवैः व्यज्यमानानुभूयते॥**

 This turning of the mind towards God from its present materialistic tendency is invariably mentioned in all the descriptions to avoid mistaken notions on this important point. It is after all a simple and plain statement that, south is not north, night is not day, might is not right, wickedness is

not virtue, hypocricy is not devotion, irreligion is not civilization.

*** Q. No. III.***

 "Parvathi, Maheswara's beloved wife is in the form of the highest gnana known as Chit-akasa. She has four Saktis named Santi, Vidya, Pretishta and Nivriti".

 The Pandit cannot discover his anthropology here even with the help of a microscope. The whole of it is religious Psychology of which he has never heard before. The Critic probably never expected to find anything reasonable in the midst of Indian superstitious literature. His Munshi's teachings evidently did not give him an occasion for any such suspicion. He judged the merits of the literature from the enlightenment of his Munshi and was therefore pitiably misled.

***Q. No. IV.***

 "From the Maya-body of Bramha who originated from Avyakta, the eight-handed Gayatri sprang up. In the Swayambhuva-manwantara, she fought with Mahisha-asura in the interest of the Devas as directed by Bramha. She killed him on the mount Mandara, and on another occasion, she killed Chitrasura on the Vindhya mountains, taking the form of Nanda. The purport of the story is that this Devi here represents Gnana-sakti and Mahisha or buffalo denotes ignorance which could be destroyed only by true knowledge. It is the rule in the Itihasas to narrate such abstract matters in concrete forms. When they are explained by the learned in the language of the Vedas, the goddess is described as residing in the heart without form".

 Young school boys who understand the language can easily grasp the meaning of this quotation. It is clearly stated that the forms described in the Itihasas are expressly

explained as representing the formless. If the Pandit therefore dares to contradict the text itself, he must be either a lunatic or a personal enemy to the religion he pretends to profess and is virtually an out-caste. The goddess Gayatri represents the religious knowledge conveyed by the sacred Manthra well-known by that name. We have already noticed in the preceding section that the Manthras not only convey some philosophical ideas, but that their very composition is based upon a science called Siksha or the Physiology of sound. The eight hands of this goddess allude to the eight Prakritis and the eight Sidhis which are the natural results accruing from the proper practice of this Manthra. The Asuras she killed on the mountains named, are significant in the Puranic language. Mahisha or buffalo does not demand an explanation.It represents stupidity in the extreme. Chithrasuraa, meaning variegated colours refers to the knowledge of variety and the ignorance of unity. Mount Mandara signifies dullness or stupidity and Vindhya plainly means obstruction. The story as a whole points to the necessity of destroying ignorance by proper knowledge. The religious knowledge has been defined as commencing only with the determination to involve. The ignorance represented by Mahisha or buffalo covers all kinds of materialities.It is thus evident that all the modern interpretations of the sacred texts as virtually alluding to the phenomenal world, fall within the province of the Great Mahisha-asura, within whose territory and under whose supreme rule, the Pandits and the civilized Hindu gentlemen now reside.It is an open secret that the majority of our modern religious Pretenders care only for one goddess of lucre. All other religious and ethical considerations are entirely subordinate. This is exactly the history of Mahisha's rule here detailed.

**जातिर्यातुरसातलं गुणगणस्तस्याप्यधोगछताम्  
शीलं शैलतटात्पतत्वभिजनस्सन्दह्यतां वह्निना।  
शौर्ये वैरिणि वज्रमाशु निपतत्वर्थोस्तुनः केवलं  
येनैकेनविना गुणास्तृणलवप्रायास्समस्ता अपि॥**

*** Q. No. V.***

 "The term Prakriti is explained as follows in accordance with its root-meaning. In the Vedas Pra means superior or first, and Kriti is creation. Pra again means Satwa, Kri Reja and Ti Tama. Prakriti thus respresents the all-powerful Sakti possessing the three gunas. The Atma divided itself into two, the male on the right side and the female on left which is known as Prakriti. The two stand in the relation of fire and its heat, and the Yogis therefore do not recognise any difference between male and female. In her act of creation, Prakriti is distinguished as of five forms. Durga, the mother of Genesa, is the first form representing the underlying principle of all the vegetable and other lives. Lekshmi is the second form representing the glories observable in heaven and earth. Saraswati is the third form representing the real knowledge that removes all doubts. Savitri or Gayatri, the mother of the Vedas, Sandhya, Manthras and Tanthras, is the fourth form representing the Bramhaic lustre and energy. Radha, residing in Go-loka in the form of a Gopi is the fifth form representing the five vital airs. She is seen by the Yogis by meditation according to the methods prescribed in the Vedas. Sak means glory and Ti is valour. Sakti is the form of both. Bhaga means prosperity and Budhi and Bhagavati is their form. Radha and Sarva-mangala allude to the power of granting liberation. Amba means mother of the Jegat. Being created by Vishnu, she is Vishnavi. Gowri means the Sakti pertaining to the Parvati Gurus or masters, namely Siva and Krishna.

alludes to the Parvas or the holy festive occasions on which she is worshipped. Sanatani means existing without gunas at all times and places. Kritika refers to the Kalas of Prakriti representing the six Yogas. Durga refers to the Sakti of Hari that destroys fear, enemies, diseases and sins.The Sakti that bestows the highest bliss is called Siva. Abhaya refers to the destruction of fear. The Sakti that bestows prosperity and liberation is called Maya and Vishnu-bhakti. Narayani means born from half the body of Narayana. Jeya means granting victory".

 Several names of the Devi are here explained mostly by their root-meanings. They refer to the various stages of religious development in man, each of them being technically important and distinct in its use. It is not therefore enough to explain, like the Pandit that all these terms apply to the Devi. Every technical term in the sciences could otherwise be explained by any ignorant person as simply applying to the sciences. It will be clearly evident here that even single letters in the given names are separated into consonants and vowels and their vedic significance explained. When such detail explanations on doubtful points in the religious literature are not forth-coming from the Pandit, the correct inference is that he knows them not, and not that the texts are silent in the matter.

 ***Q. No. VI.***

 "Gayathri seated above the Bramhanda is described in the Vedas,as the eternal secret Vidya and the mother of all knowledge. She is in every created object and moves about in the sky. She is unseen and yet seen, she is Avyakta and yet Vyakta, she has no letters and yet has them, She is Bindumalini or crowned with Bindu. The Yogi ever seeing her obtains emancipation."

 This is a technical description of Gayatri whose detail explanation cannot be attempted here. It is enough to know that it refers to some serious religious matter that the Pandit is unable to explain at present.

*** Q. No. VII.***

 "Samvit is the real and ulitimate knowledge that Siva is the only reality. All that appears outside this knowledge is verily the Para-sakti the real form of Atma, destitute of the display of the material world. She should therefore be ever worshipped for the purpose of avoiding the miseries of Samsara".

 The Devi is here explained in the plainest terms as referring to the highest philosophical knowledge. Her worship is prescribed for the liberation of man from his bondage. Which of the sects of modern interpreters now stand in need of further information to be convinced of their ignorance and mistake? There are of course several varieties of the modern editions of this Devi,specially manufactured to help on the inclinations to drinks and animal. food. The Devi of aur ancient religion is however clearly explained in the quotation, as having no jurisdiction over this material world.

**आराधयेत्परां शक्तिं प्रपोञ्चोल्लासवर्जिताम्॥**

 ***Q. No. VIII.***

 "Govinda of Brindavana is the only Purusha or male. From Bramha downwards, all the Eswaras being the product of Prakriti fall under females. Savitri of hundred forms is the consort of Bramha and the mother of the seven-rishis, of Prejapatis and of all the Manus. The history of this Jegat is infinite in character like a heap of sand.The wise should therefore understand the reality as beyond it. In the Swayambhuva-manwantara, Mahishasura was killed by

Vyshnavi on the mount Mandara. He was afterwards killed by Nanda on the Vindhya mountains, in the Vyvaswata- manwantara The purport of this story is that Devi represents knowledge and Mahisha denotes ignorance. The Itihasas describe such matters in concrets forms. The wise describe me in the language of the Vedas. The divine Yoga-pittha is known as composed of all the letters.In the centre of it is Savithri, where Eswara with his consort resides. Vimalotkarshini, Gnana, Kriya, Yoga, Prehwi, Satya and Esana are the queens of Eswara".

 From the conception of Bramha downwards,everything is classed under Prakriti and styled feminine. The story of Mahisha is repeated in this quotation also, almost in the same words, and explained in the same manner. Most of the names of Devi here given, such as, Gnana, Kriya, Yoga, Satya &c., are too plain to be misunderstood as referring to beings in human form. The Pandit however would be glad to manufacture concrete forms for every word in the text, as he is unable to conceive anything useful without a tangible form for his artistic eye.

*** Q. No. IX.***

  "From the thigh of Narayana the eternal, Urvasi as the eleventh Apsara originated. Menaka is the daughter of Mena. All these Apsaras preach philosophy and represent Maha-yogas or great Yogas".

 The Apsaras represent different stages of attainment in the practice of Yoga and allude more particularly to the Sidhis or powers resulting therefrom. They are not therefore the common dancing girls in heaven as the Pandit would explain, perhaps somewhat better-looking and better decorated. The religious heaven is certainly not the abode of

débauchery and concubinage which the Pandit is evidently longing for as the summum bonum of his present existence.

**न गम्यो मन्त्राणां न भवति च भैषज्यविषयो  
न चापिप्रध्वंसं व्रजतिविविधैरशान्तिकरणैः।  
भ्रमावेशादःकिमपि विदधत् भङ्गमसकृत्  
स्मरापस्मारोयं भ्रमयति दृशौ घूर्णयति च॥**

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1699188953Screenshot(38"/>.png)It is clearly evident from the above few quotations that the Saktis described refer invariably to the processes of originating as well as fostering Gnana or true knowledge. They represent the latent powers of the Absolute capable of developing, when properly invoked, the necessary faculties in man leading to religious advancement in their respective directions. As stated in quotations 4 and 8 in the most unequivocal terms possible, the descriptions of these Saktis as Goddesses, are in strict conformity with the formulas followed in the Itihasas for their usual representations in a concrete form. The object of worshipping them or virtually practising the required virtues and religious devotion, is certainly the attainment of spiritual knowledge and freedom from bondage, and not the securing of material benefits especially of a kind that will undoubtedly block up the straight path to salvation, and will immensely increase the miseries consequent on avarice and greed. All the prevailing ideas of satisfying mean and selfish desires are therefore entirely out of the question and it is the complete ignorance of this fact that gives rise to most of the mistaken interpretations and ridiculous and abominable practices which generally pass under the garb of religious ceremonies and rituals.

**निष्कामानामेव श्रीविद्यासिद्धिः।  
न कदापि सकामानामिति॥**

**सौभाग्यलक्ष्म्युपनिषत्॥**

  The worship of Sakti is intended for the advancement of those who have relinquished worldly desires and will never prove useful or effective to the worldly inclined.

**लोके व्यवायामिवमद्यसेवा नित्यास्तु जन्तोः न हि तत्र चोदना।  
व्यवस्थितिस्तेषु विवाहयज्ञ सुराग्रहैरासु निवृित्तोरष्टा॥**

**श्रीमद्भागवतम्।**

 The religious texts never treat of the means of satisfying man's desires for women, animal food or intoxicating drinks. They are naturally sought for without special instructions. But the main object of religion is to rescue man from falling a victim to their consequent evils, by checking and reducing his objectionable propensities in that direction.

 It is not difficult to understand from the definitions given in the passages quoted above, that the names of Goddesses, such as, Mula-Prakriti, Maya, Saraswathi, Savitri, Gayatri, Parvathy,Lakshmi, Radha, Durga, Amba, Gowri, Narayani, Samvit, Para-Sakti &c, all refer to the ultimate Sakti not different from Gnana or true knowledge of the Absolute. The knowledge of Bramhan as distinguished from Bramhan itself, although the Sakti is its own, is the idea conveyed in the representations of Goddesses. The functions of the ultimate Sakti comprising creation, preservation and destruction cannot possibly therefore be mistaken for Agnana or ignorance with all its existing paraphernalia, known as the material world and its varying cosmological conceptions as formed by each individual. The Goddesses represented thus clearly point to the latent powers the Absolute which may be profitably invoked for helping on in our march through the path of Gnana to the ultimate goal.

 The sub-saktis of Eswari enumerated in quotation 3 are, Santi,Vidya, Prathishta and Nivriti, Vishnu-maya

is described as the same as Vishnu-bhakti in quotation 5. Urvasi, Menaka &c., are distinctly stated in quotation 9, as the different processes of Yoga; and they are generally described as the free women of the Heavens, as they are accessible to all who court them.

 No clearer passages are needed nor could be obtained to explain the real import of these representations of Goddesses. But the passages above culled out from various texts should be understood as exclusively meant for those who seek for truth with sympathy and interest, and I dare say the original texts themselves were composed only for the benefit of such of them.

**अश्रद्धालोरविश्वासो नोदाहरणमर्हति।  
श्रद्धालुरपि सर्वत्र वैदिकेष्वधिकारतः॥**

**अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति।  
नायं लोकोस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः॥**

<MISSING_FIG href="../../../../../books_images/U-IMG-1699190290Screenshot(39"/>.png)Besides the Tri-murtis and the limited number of Goddesses already noticed, there are innumerable personages whose names commonly occur in the religious texts. No less than 33 crores of Devas are said to inhabit the Swarga-loka with their consorts, rulers, administrators and religious preceptors. They have a sufficiently large number of permanent enemies known as the Asuras. Similarly, a good number of Bramha-Rishis, Deva-Rishis, Raja-Rishis and Pitris as well as their families appear in the descriptions of their respective regions. An examination of their personal characteristics and whereabouts is absolutely necessary to complete the present section. The enumeration and description of the Devas may be first examined.

त्रीच सहस्रेत्यो मिति होवाच। कत्येवदेवा याज्ञवल्क्येति त्रय स्त्रिंशदित्योमिति होवाच। कत्येव देवा याज्ञवल्क्येति षडित्योमिति होवाच। कत्येव देवा याज्ञवल्क्येति त्रय इत्योमिति होवाच। कत्येव देवा याज्ञवल्क्येति द्वावित्योमिति होवाच। कत्येव देवा याज्ञवल्क्येत्यध्यर्ध इत्यो मिति होवाच कल्येव देवा याज्ञवल्क्येत्येक इत्यो मिति होवाच। कतमे ते त्रयश्च त्रीच शता त्रयश्च त्रीच सहस्रेति॥ सहोवाच महिमान एवैषामेते त्रयस्त्रिंशत्वेव देवा इति कतमे ते त्रयस्त्रिंशदित्यष्टौ वसव एकादशरुद्रा द्वादशादित्यास्त एकत्रिंशदिन्द्रश्चैव प्रजातिश्च त्रयस्त्रिंशा इति। कतमे वसव इत्यग्निश्च पृथिवी च वायुश्चान्तरिक्षञ्चादित्यश्चद्यौश्चचन्द्रमाश्च नक्षत्राणि चैते वसव एतेषु हीदं वसु सर्वंहितमिति तस्माद्वसव इति। कतमे रुद्रा इति दशेमे पुरुषे प्राणा आत्मैकादशस्ते यदास्माच्छरीरान्मर्त्यादुत्कामन्त्यथ रोदयन्ति तद्यद्रोदयन्ति तस्माद्रुद्राइति। कतम आदित्या इति द्वादशवै मासाः संवत्सरस्यैत आदित्या एते हीदं सर्वमाददाना यन्ति ते यदिदं सर्वमाददाना यन्ति तस्मादादित्या इति। कतम इन्द्रः कतमः प्रजापतिरिति स्तनयित्नुरेवेन्द्रो यज्ञः प्रजापतिरिति कतमः स्तनयित्नुरित्यशनिरिति कतमो यज्ञ इति पशव इति। कतमे षडित्यग्निश्च पृथिवी च वायुश्चान्तरिक्षं चादित्यश्चद्यौश्चेति षडेते हीदं सर्वं षडिति। कतमे ते त्रयो देवा इतीमएवत्रयोलोका एषु हीमे सर्वे देवा इति कतमौ तौ द्वौ देवावित्यन्नं चैव प्राणश्चेति कतमोऽध्यर्ध इति योयं पवत इति। तदा हुर्यदयमेक इवैव पवतेथ कथमध्यर्ध इति यदस्मिन्निदं सर्वमध्यार्ध्नोत्तेनाध्यर्ध इति कतम एको देव इति प्राणइति सब्रह्म तदित्याचक्षते॥

ततोर्वाक्स्त्रोतसस्ते वै उत्पद्यन्ते सुरासुराः।  
जायन्ते कार्यसिद्धयर्थं मानुषेषु पुनः पुनः॥**

**ब्रह्माण्डपुराणम्॥**

***  Q. No. VII.***

**व्यष्टयस्तु समष्टिभ्यो जायन्ते ब्राह्मणानघाः।  
समष्टिषु विजायन्ते देवताःपूर्वकल्पवत्।  
समष्टिव्यष्टिरूपाणां सृष्टानां पालको हरिः।  
रुद्रस्तेषान्तु संहर्ता द्विजा रूपान्तरेण च।  
या देवतन्तः करणसमष्टौपूर्वकल्पवत्।  
विजाता सा मुनिश्रेष्ठा रुक्मगर्भ इतीरितः।  
जाता प्राणसमष्टौ या स सूत्रात्मसमाह्वयः।  
दिग्वाय्वर्कजलाध्यक्ष पृथिव्याख्यास्तु देवताः।  
जायन्ते क्रमशः श्रोत्रप्रमुखेषु समष्टिषु।  
पादपाण्यादिषु प्राज्ञाः कर्मेन्द्रियसमष्टिषु।  
त्रिविक्रमेन्द्रप्रमुखा जायन्ते देवताः क्रमात्।  
समष्टिषु विजाता या देवतास्ता यथाक्रमम्।  
व्यष्टिभूतेन्द्रियाणान्तु नियन्त्र्यो देवता द्विजाः।  
मारुतस्त्वगधिष्ठाता दिग्देवी कर्णदेवता।  
नेत्राभिमानीसूर्यः स्याज्जिह्वया वरुणस्तथा।  
घ्राणाभिमनिनी देवी पृथिवीति प्रकीर्तिता।  
अग्निर्वागभिमानीस्यादुपस्थस्य प्रजापतिः।  
पायोर्मित्रोभिमान्यात्मा पादस्यापि त्रिविक्रमः।  
इन्द्रो हस्तनियन्ता स्याछिशवःसर्वनियामकः।  
मनोबुद्धिरहङ्कारश्चित्तं चेति चतुर्विधम्।  
स्यादन्तः करणं प्राज्ञाः क्रमात्तेषां हि देवताः।  
चन्द्रो वाचस्पतिर्विप्राः साक्षात्कालाग्निरुद्रकः।  
शिवश्चेति मया प्रोक्ताः साक्षाद्वेदान्तपारगाः॥**

**देवताः सर्वदेहेषु स्थिताः सत्यतपोधनाः।  
सर्वेषां कारणं साक्षात्परतत्वमपि स्थितम्।  
पञ्चभूतात्मके देहे स्थूले षाड्कौशिके सदा।  
पृथिव्यादिक्रमेणैव वर्तन्ते पञ्चदेवताः।  
कार्यं ब्रह्मा महीभागे कार्यं विष्णुर्जलांशके।  
कार्यं रुद्रोग्निभागे च वाय्वंश चेश्वरः परः।  
आकाशांशे शरीरस्य स्थितः साक्षात्सदाशिवः।  
शरीरस्य बहिर्भागे विराडात्मा स्थितः सदा।  
अन्तर्भागे स्वराडात्मा सम्राट् देहस्य मध्यमे।  
ज्ञानेन्द्रियसमाख्येषु श्रोत्रादिषु यथाक्रमात्।  
दिग्वाय्वर्कजलाध्यक्ष भूमिसंज्ञाश्च देवताः।  
कर्मेन्द्रियसमाख्येषु पादपाण्यादिषु क्रमात्।  
त्रिविक्रमेन्द्रवह्न्याख्या देवताश्च प्रजापतिः।  
मित्रसंज्ञश्च वर्तन्ते प्राणे सूत्रात्मसंज्ञितः।  
हिरण्यगर्भो भगवान् अन्तःकरणसंज्ञिते।  
तदवस्थाप्रभेदेषु चन्द्रमा मनसि स्थितः।  
बुद्धौ बृहस्पतिर्विप्राः स्थितः कालाग्निरुद्रकः।  
अहङ्कारे शिवश्चित्ते रोमसु क्षुद्रदेवताः।  
भूतः प्रेतादयः सर्वे देहस्यास्थिषु संस्थिताः।  
पिशाचाराक्षसाः सर्वे स्थिताः स्त्रायुषु सर्वशः।  
मज्जाख्ये पितृगन्धर्वा स्त्वग्मासरुधिरेषु च।  
वर्तन्ते तत्र संसिद्धाःदेवताःसकला द्विजाः।  
त्रिमूर्तीनान्तु यो ब्रह्मा तस्य घोरतनुर्द्विजाः।  
दक्षिणाक्षिणि जन्तूनामन्तर्भागे रविर्बहिः।  
त्रिमूर्तीनान्तु यो ब्रह्मा तस्य शान्ता तनुर्द्विजाः।  
वर्तते वामनेत्रान्तर्भागे बाह्ये निशाकरः।  
त्रिमूर्तीनान्तु यो विष्णुः स कण्ठे वर्तते सदा।  
अन्तः शान्ततनु घरातनुर्बाह्ये द्विजर्षभाः।  
त्रिमूर्तीनान्तु यो रुद्रो हृदये वर्तते सदा।**

**अन्तः शान्ततनु र्घोरातनुर्बाह्ये द्विजर्षभाः।  
सर्वेषां कारणं यत्तद्ब्रह्म सत्यादिलक्षणम्।  
ब्रह्मरन्ध्रे महास्थाने वर्तते सततं द्विजाः।  
चिच्छक्तिःपरमा देहमध्यमे सुप्रतिष्ठिता।  
मायाशक्ति र्ललाटाग्रभागे व्योमाम्बुजादधः।  
नादरूपा पराशक्ति र्ललाटस्य तु मध्यमे।  
भागे बिन्दुमयीशक्तिर्ललाटस्यापरांशके।  
बिन्दुमध्ये तु जीवात्मा सूक्ष्मरूपेण वर्तते।  
हृदये स्थूलरूपेण मध्यमेन तु मध्यमे।  
देवी सरस्वती साक्षाद्ब्रह्मपत्नी सनातनी।  
जिह्वाग्रे वर्तते नित्यं सर्वविद्याप्रदायिनी।  
विष्णुपत्नी महालक्ष्मी वर्ततेऽनाहते सदा।  
रुद्रपत्नी तु रुद्रेण पार्वती सहवर्तते।  
सर्वत्र वर्तते साक्षाच्छिवः साम्बः सनातनः।  
सत्यादिलक्षणःशुद्धः सर्वदेवनमस्कृतः।  
सम्यक्ज्ञानवतां देहे देवताःसकला अमूः।  
प्रत्यगात्मतया भान्ति देवतारूपतोऽपि च।  
वेदमार्गैकनिष्ठानां विशुद्धानान्तु विग्रहे।  
देवतारूपतो भान्ति द्विजा न प्रत्यगात्मना।  
तान्त्रिकाणां शरीरे तु देवताः सकला अमूः।  
वर्तन्ते न प्रकाशन्ते द्विजेन्द्राः शुध्यभावतः।  
यथाजातजनानान्तु शरीरे सर्वदेवताः।  
तिरोभूततया नित्यं वर्तन्ते मुनिसत्तमाः।  
अतश्च भोगमोक्षार्थी शरीरं देवतामयम्।  
स्वकीयं परकीयञ्च पूजयेत्तु विशेषतः।  
देवता रूपतः पश्यन् मुच्यते भवबन्धनात्॥**

**                       स्कान्दपुराणं सूतसंहिता॥**

***Q. No. VIII.***

**द्वौ भूतसर्गोलोकेस्मिन् दैव असुर एव च।  
अभयं सत्वसंशुद्धिर्ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः।**

**दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्चस्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम्।  
अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम्।  
दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्लीरचापलम्।  
तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता।  
भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत।  
दम्भो दर्पोभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च।  
अज्ञानं चाऽभिजातस्य पार्थ सम्पदमासुरीम्।  
दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता॥**

**                        भगवद्गीता॥**

 ***Quotation No. I.***

 "The wise Sakalya asked Yagna-valkya, 'how many Devas are there'? He replied that the Devas allude to the Nivid or the indication of the glories of the Lord of Viswa. Sakalya repeated the question and Yagna-valkya said that the Devas are 33 crores in number, the crores alluding simply to their glories. The correct number 33 is made up of 8 Vasus, 11Rudras, 12 Adityas, Soma and Prejapathi. The Vasus are, fire, earth, air, Akasa, Aditya, sky, moon and the stars. They are called Vasus because they hold all the substance of the world. The Rudras are 10 Pranas or breaths and the Atma, they are so named because they make a noise when they leave this mortal body. The Adityas represent the 12 months in the year; they are so named because they extract everything from this world. Indra is lightning and Prejapathi is Yegna or devotion known also as Pasus. The Devas are classified differently into 6, 3, 2, 11/2 and 1. Fire. earth, air, Akasa, Aditya and sky make up the 6. The three Lokas make up the 3. Annom or Avyakrita and Prana make up the 2. The air that expands everything is Adhyardha or 11/2. The Prana is the single Deva and it is known as Bramhan".

 From the eternal Bramhan,the classification of the Devas is extended to 33 crores. The Devas are said to be the Nivid of the Lord of Viswa, and Nivid means a Vedicin randomconcerning some special glory of the Lord. The description of a Deca is thus clearly some special instruction given to man suited to his receptive capacities, for the purpose of understanding the real nature of the Lord. The Pandit no doubt expects to see in his heaven, some of his favourite Devas in the form of royal personages, and more particularly the Apsaras or heavenly damsels, about whom he is dreaming all his life. He is determined to convert the holy heaven into an earthly brothel.

**मुक्ताफलैः किं मृगपक्षिणां च मिष्टान्नपानं किमु गर्दभानाम्।  
अन्धस्य दीपो बधिरस्य गीतं मूर्खस्य किं धर्मकथाप्रसङ्गः॥**

*** Q. No. II.***

 "The light that blazes in the right eye is called Indra, and that in the left is Virat, Indra's wife.The Devas as a class hate corporeality and they are fond of spirituality. The path leading to their discovery starts from the Akasa in the heart. Several Nadis proceed upwards from this spot and the one named Hita remains in the heart itself. The rest flow in different directions from this body of the Atman".

 The modern pandit is sure to find the whole of this passage Greek to him. Why should the Devas hate materiality ? How is Indra in the right eye and his consort in the left? The Devas represent the senses lighted up with real knowledge. When they follow the Pandit in his desire for material objets, they lose their status and become Asuras. Regarding Indra and his wife we will obtain fuller informtion shortly. Again, several Nadis are said to spread themselves from the Akasa of the heart. How could Nadis or

tubular vessels as the Pandit understands them, originate from the vacuum specified? These Nadis always represent the directions and tendencies of the currents of human thought, which the Pandit evidently does not understand, and he doubtless expects to see them clearly in the post morten examination. Under the present state of his ignorance and uncouth obstinacy, he must be given credit for his wisdom in expecting to see his conceptions of religious items realised only in the dead body.

 ***Q. No. III.***

 "Just as a merchant who takes personal care of his business and understands the real nature of his work, becomes wealthy, the status of Indra is secured. When Indra does not perceive the Atma, the Asuras over-power him. But when Indra perceives the Atma, he destroys the Asuras, obtains mastery over the elements and becomes the great Emperor."

 Indra is here clearly explained as one who secures the knowledge of Atma. When this knowledge is absent, the Asuras over-power him. Victory over the Asuras and sovereignty in heaven, are plainly mentioned as depending upon the real knowledge of the Self.This is certainly not the Pandit's Indra, whom the Pandit expects to please by his unphilosophical, irreligious and out-casting acts of cruelty and immorality under the guise of religious rituals, by virtue of which Indra condescends to procure our venerable Pandit with the best damsels available in heaven, for the satisfaction of his low carnal cravings. If Indra does not serve the Pandit in this important matter, he is not worth the name and position assigned to him. This is exactly the type of the Pandit, we are unfortunately destined to have at present, in our midst, to seek religious instructions from. 'Misery

acquaints a man with strange bed-fellows', said Shakespeare one day, and we are surely in a worse predicament now.

 ***Q. No. IV.***

  "Indh, means lighting up, or creating or perceiving. Indra, thus represents the Prana-vayu, or life principle, which remaining within the body, sets up the five vital airs in motion. He is otherwise known as Kshetregna. He exhibits the glories of the Atman to those who take to religious devotion and practice of Yoga. Indrani is known as his wife seated in the middle of Indra and Varuna".

 Indra, is clearly mentioned here, as a synonym applying to Kshethregna. His Sakti is Indrani. Indra helps only those who take to the worship of Atman. The Pandit therefore cannot hope to please this Indra, as his desire for heavenly damsels is not certainly the worship of Atman here specified. His present devotional spirit however, cannot go without its due reward. The general rule for karmic effects is plainly enunciated in the Bhagavat-Gita.

**यं यं वापि स्मारन्नित्यं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेबरम्।  
तं तमेवेति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः॥**

'He who dies with the thought of the object he has been incessantly meditating upon during his life-time, will attain to it in his next birth. The Pandit has thus the best chance of being born as a menial servant of some notorious and devilish wench, not far from his own nativity. His life-long ambition being exactly in this direction, he is sure to feel highly elated at this happy prediction.

**नो सत्येन मृगाङ्क एव वदनीभूतो न चेन्दीवर  
द्वन्द्वं लोचनतां गतं न कनकैरप्यङ्गयष्टिः कृता।  
किन्त्वेवं कविभिः प्रतारितमनाः तत्वं विजानन्नपि  
त्वङ्मांसास्थिमयं वपुर्मृगदृशां मुग्धोजनस्सेवते॥**

*** Q. No. V.***

 "From the Ahamkara called Vykarika, the creation of the ten senses and also of mind, took place simultaneously. These eleven instruments of perception are known as Vykarika Devas. From the back side of Bramha, the Asuras originated. Asu means Prana or life and those who follow its ways are called Asuras. When Bramha abandoned the form of his body from which he created the Devas, the night came immediately. The Devas having originated from Bramha's face shining, and having been produced out of Bramha's divine and shining body, they are called the Devas. The word Natha refers to a ruler. Indra represents the ruler of the three Lokas and he is the chief deity for worship in every Manwantara. The Indras are the great Rajahs and fathers of all, as they righteously protect the world. The Yekshas, Gendharvas Rakshasas, Pisachas, Uragas, and Danavas allude to the glories of Indra. The division of the four castes and of the four Asramas are based upon the eight stages from Bramha to Pisacha. The eight Sidhis commencing with Anima are their perceptible effects. They represent the unobstructed forms of Prakriti in their regular order".

 This is an important quotation furnishing plenty of technical informations. The ten senses and the mind aredefined as Vykarika Devas. They are called Devas because of their shining brightness and they originated from Bramba's face during his day time. The Asuras originated from his back-side during his night. The Asuras are clearly explained here as alluding to the materialistic tendencie in man.

**असुः प्राणः स्मृतो विप्रास्तज्जन्मानस्ततोऽसुराः॥**

 Again, Indra the chief of the Devas is explained as the righteous ruler of the three Lokas, and Yekshas, Gendharvas

&c., as alluding to his glories. The eight Sthanas or status, the eight Sidhis and the four castes and Asramas are said to be mutually connected and refer therefore to the specified glories of Indra. Indra has been already found to represent Kshetregna or the individual soul of man, and all else stated here, therefore refer to the divine stages attainable by man in his practice of devotion and Tapas as prescribed by the Sastras. The three Lokas ruled over by Indra and protected by him do not therefore include this material world. It is entirely outside the limits of the Lokas of the Devas, and is completely reserved for the Asuras. The Pandit need not be frightened at this news. The Asuras will not drive him out of this world. They are only his yet unrecognised friends and relatives who have great sympathy and love for him. The mankind in general belongs to this Asura creation, born from the back of Bramha during his night. Until man goes round and stands before Bramha, he will be treated as an Asura in our religious literature. When he meets Bramha's face he will be converted into a Deva. This is the substance of the Puranic description quoted above. In this quotation, the necessary clues for the religious division of castes and Asramas are given, as connected with the eight Sidhis and the eight stages or forms of Prakriti.

**वर्णाश्रमाणां धर्मोऽयं देवस्थानेषु कारणम्।  
अष्टावेतानि रूपाणि प्राकृतानि यथाक्रमम्॥**

The real significance of the distinctions pointed out would be found as scientific and practical as any other scientific and useful matter. It may be necessary perhaps to note here that all modern attempts to establish the mere importance of external forme as appear at present, would be unscientific and unauthorised, equally so would be all prejudiced and whimsical efforts to deny their scientific character, without going

into their technical application and without a study of the most serious and useful subject ever brought to light in the eternal interest of mankind. The modera off-hand views expressed by professional Critics against caste and Asramas, without understanding even the definition of the terms, display not only prejudice and indifference, but also a lamentable weakness and a serious defect in the so-called civilization of the current era.

** *Q. No. VI.***

 "The Devas, Asuras, Gendharvas, Yekshas, Rakshasas, Pannagas, Pisachas, cattle, beast, birds and shrubs are the issues of Kasyapa by Dakshayinis or daughters of Deksha, known as the Loka-mathas. As they are all found in the nature of man, these Devas are known as the Manushya-Prakriti, or the various characteristics of human nature. These children of the Loka-mathas inherit the good and bad qualities of their respective mothers. Aditi is noted for Dharma; Diti for power; Surabhi for Tapas; Denu for Maya; Muni for smell; Krodha for religion; Arishta for music; Khasa for cruelty; Kadru for anger; Kroda for purity; Vinata for learning; Thamra for harm; Ira for blessing and Anayu for eating. As all these Devas appear in man in the Manwantaras, and as man is the fit creation for securing Dharma, Artha, Kama and Moksha, he is reckoned as a great being. The Devas and Asuras are again and again born in man as Arwak-srotas or inclined hitherwards".

 The above explains purely the human Psychology, the Devas, Gendharvas &c., alluding to the senses and internal emotions &c. The Loka-mathas clearly represent their respective faculties and the Lokas denote the nervous centres

or seats of these faculties. There is however nothing in this general Puranic description deserving immediate condemnation as unscientific or unphilosophical. If the whole of the technical subject is deeply studied, we are sure to find valuable Psychological facts. But it is enough for our present purpose to know that the Devas, Asuras, Gendharvas &c., allude to human nature under various conditions. The Pandit's mistake and ignorance in the conception of these gods and devils, described in our religious literature, are here sufficiently exposed, and it would be uncharitable to criticise the deluded Critic who depended entirely upon the Pandit in obtaining matter for his operations.

** *Q. No. VII.***

 "Individualities originate from generalities and the Devas originate from the latter. Hari is the protector of both. Hari transformed as Rudra is their destroyer. Hiranyagerbha originated from the totality of the internal organs of the Devas. Similarly, Sutratma originated from the totality of Pranas. From the totality of the five Gnanaindrias, the Devas known as Dic or space, air, sun, water and earth sprang up. From the totality of the five Karmaindrias such as foot, hand &c., the Devas known as Trivikrama, Indra &c., arose. These Devas are the guiding principles of the individual senses, namely, air for touch; space for ear; sun for the eye; Varuna for taste; earth for smell, fire for speech; Prejapati for the generative organ; Mitra for the excretive organ; Trivikrama for the foot; Indra for the hand; and Siva is the general controller. The four internal organs are, Manas, Budhi, Ahamkara and Chitha, presided over by the moon, Brihaspati, Kalagnirudra and Siva respectively. In this material body of man composed of the five elements and six Kosas or sheaths, all

the Devas and the highest Tatwa reside. The five Devas reside in the five elements in the body. Bramha is in the earthy portion, Vishnu in water, Rudra in fire, Eswara in air and Sadasiva in Akasa. Outside the body is Virat, inside is Swarad and in the middle is Samraud. In the ten senses, their respective Devas specified above, reside. Hiranyagerbha is in the internal organs in general, in the hair are the lower orders of Devas; in the bones are Bhutas and Pretas; in the tendons are Pisachas and Rakshasas, in the marrow, Pithris and Gendharvas, in the skin, flesh and blood, the Devas. Bramha's violent portion is insile the right eye and the sun is outside it as the ruling Devas. Bramha's tranquil portion is inside the left eye and the moon is outside it. Vishnu is in the throat, his tranquil portion being inside and the violent portion outside. Similarly Rudra's tranquil portion is inside the heart and the violent portion outside it. The Bramhan, the original source of all is in the Bramharendhra or brain. The Chit-Sakti is in the centre of the body. Mayasakti is at the top of the fore-head. Parasakti or Nada is in the centre of the fore-head. Just below it is Bindu, within which the Jiva-atma or life principle resides in its subtle form. It resides in the heart in its Sthula form, and in the centre of the body in its intermediate form. Saraswati, the wife of Bramha and Goddess of learning is in the tip of the tongue. Lekshmi, Parvati and Rudra are in Aushata or the heart. The eternal Siva is everywhere. In the body of Gnanis, all the Devas are seen in their involutionary attitude and also in the form of Devas here specified. In the body of the merely religious, the Devas are seen but not in their involutionary attitude. In the body of the Tantriks, the Devas exist but are not seen owing to want of purity. In the ordinary people, the Devas remain hidden. The human body is thus filled with Devas

and those who care for happiness and emancipation must ever treat with respect one's own body as well as the bodies of others".

 All the Devas are here localised in the human body and their individual functions are also clearly defined. They are the guides, controllers and protectors of human thought and action. They are said to remain hidden in the body of the ordinary man who has no religious devotion.

**यथाजातजनानान्तु शरीरे सर्वदेवताः।  
तिरोभूततया नित्यं वर्तन्ते मुनिसत्तमाः॥**

In the body of the Tantriks, the Devas exist but do not shine forth owing to want of sufficient purity.

**तान्त्रिकाणां शरीरे तु देवताः सकला अमूः।  
वर्तन्ते न प्रकाशन्ते द्विजेन्द्राः शुद्ध्यभावतः॥**

In the bodies of those who obey the injunctions of the Vedas in their religious devotions, the Devas appear in their true forms but not in their involutionary attitude.

**वेदमार्गैकनिष्ठानां विशुद्धानान्तु विहे।  
देवतारूपतो भान्तिं द्विजा न प्रत्यगात्मना॥**

Again in the body of the Gnani, the Devas shine forth in their true forms and also appear in their involutionary attitude displaying the glories of the soul.

**सम्यक्ज्ञानवतां देहे देवताः सकला अमूः॥  
प्रत्यगात्मतया भान्ति देवतारूपतोऽपि च॥**

Four varieties of human body are here clearly defined and the action of the Devas in each variety is also plainly explained. The first one is the body of the irreligious or entirely worldly. All the Devas are said to conceal themselves in the body. The Devas are shining entities, and their description as hidden plainly means that all kinds of

religious knowledge and good qualities are absent in the man and that he is worse than a beast. Secondly the body of the Tantrik who is credited only with an inclination to be religious but not with any devotional spirit originating from the respect for the Vedas. Here, the Devas exist but they never shine forth. In the third variety of the body of the religious and devotional, the Devas are said to shine forth. This plainly refers to the most harmless conduct and the loving sympathy of the good man towards his fellow beings. Here too, the Devas do not appear in their pristine purity. Until their direction is turned internally froin the material side, they do not exhibit their full glory. In the body of the Gnani, all the Devas internally shine forth in their true glory, and in relation to the outside world, the Gnani exhibits his most benevolent and sympathetic tendencies. A more detailed description of the Devas and of their actions. is unnecessary in any religious dissertation for their proper comprehension. The facts noticed explain the plain and admitted differences between the good and the bad, the virtuous and the vicious, the religious and the irreligious, the philosophical and the unphilosophical. There is no mystery, no occultism, no humbug, no confusion, no cheating, no pompous display. Everything is simple, reasonable, religious and respectable truth whose real value shall never be destroyed or diminished by the evil work of man or time.

**आयुःकल्लोललोलं कतिपयदिवसस्थायिनी यौवनश्री-  
रर्थाः सङ्कल्पकल्पा घनसमयतटिद्विभ्रमाभोगपूराः।  
कण्ठाश्लेषोपगूढं तदपि च न चिरं यत्प्रियाभिः प्रणीतम्  
ब्रह्मण्यासक्तविता भवत भवभयाम्भोधिपारं तरीतुम्॥**

** *Q. No. VIII.***

 "There are two kinds of creation here, namely, the Dyva and the Asura. Fearlessness, Satwic-purity, steadi-

ness in Gnana and Yoga, harmlessness, truthfulness, resignation and other good qualities are classed under the former; pride, prejudice, egoism, anger, ignorance and other bad qualities are classed under the latter creation. Attachment to the virtuous items leads to emancipation, that to the vicious ones leads to bondage".

 This is a more practical classification of human nature into Dyva and Asura. It does not however make it a hopeless classification of unchangeable existing facts as is generally misunderstood. It includes within it the possibility of converting the Asura into Dyva and of reducing the Dyva into Asura. The affirmation of this possibility is more important here in the real interest of man's welfare,and it would be inexcusable wickedness to ignore it. The Pandit here will discover to his greatest surprise that the Devas and the Asuras have their abodes, within himself, and that he is personally responsible for his choice in serving the one or the other. His very actions which please the Asuras displease the Devas and vice versa. If he thinks that it is better to reign in hell than to serve in heaven, he becomes a Satan and not a human being. From the above enquiries we can clearly understand, that the Asuras in spite of their greater affinity and sympathy with the existing man, deserve to be mercilessly abandoned as treacherous enemies, and that the favour of the Devas is worth seeking with any amount of  
trouble and inconvenience.

**क्षान्तं न क्षमया गृहोचितसुखं त्यक्तं न सन्तोषतः  
सोढा दुःसहशीतवाततपनक्लेशा न तप्तं तपः।  
ध्यातं वित्तमहर्निशं नियमितप्राणैर्नशम्भोः पदम्  
तत्तत्कर्मकृतं यदेव मुनिभिस्तैस्तैः फलैर्वञ्चितम्॥**

 **5. **The passages quoted here referring to the Gods are somewhat simple and explicit. In quotation 1, thirty-

three Devas are enumerated and their multiples by hundreds and thousands making up 33 crores, den te only their glories or the immense varieties of functions each is capable of. A crore or koti ordinarily points to the highest number. In quotation 4, eleven Davas or Vykarikas are mentioned, representing the 10 senses and the mind. The first 3 quotations place the position and status of Indra beyond doubt. He is the same as Kshetregna or Individual soul often noticed in the preceding pages. The Yekshas, Rakshasas, Danavas, Gendharvas mentioned in quotations 4 and 5, refer to the glories of Indra as viewed in different aspects, and virtually represent the characteristic tendencies in man. Quotation 6 locates all of them in the various parts of the human body and refers to the deities presiding over the Vasanas, meaning thereby the respective energies or enforcing laws of the the Eswara, which remain as the bases for the formation and work of the Vasanas. The Vasauas formed being generally good or bad in accordance with the nature of the individual's Karmas, their tendencies are classified as Dyva or sura, leading to salvation and perdition respectively. The enumeration given in quotation 1, from 33 crores downwards reducing the number to one at last, clearly explains the gist of the whole matter, without the least scope for doubt, ambiguity or reasonable possibility of extraneous interpretations. The Dyvi and the Asuri tendencies in man, explained in the last quotation from the Bhagavat-Gita include the Rakshasi according to recognised commentaries. The Asuri refers only to the evil tendencies originating from selfish desires, but the Rakshasi specifies the inclinations to acts of cruelty in man. In quotation 4, we find the root meaning of the word Asura explained. Asu means Prana or life; thus denoting the tendency to seek after material comforts in the interest of the physical body. Besides these

general descriptions of human tendencies, the technical terms used such as, Yekshas, Gendhervas, Pisachas &c., refer to the glories of Indra as already noticed, and are explained clearly at the end of quotation 4, as representing the eight divine stages resulting from Yoga practice. They correspond to the eight Sidhis, such as, Anima, Mahima &c., which bestow control over the eight Prakritis respectively. Thus far the descriptions given are no doubt clear enough. If only the method of treatment of the subject, as followed in the religious literature, is not misunderstood, it is not at all difficult to make out the descriptions given, as exactly pertaining to the Psychological and physiological sciences. The ignorance of this method of treatment so evident in the popular misinterpretations, is nevertheless not so surprising or dangerous as the learned absurdities of the Theosophical elucidations. The attempt of that creed to explain away Eastern religion by Western commentaries favourably or otherwise, is entirely futile and unnecessarily misleading. Seriously considered, their main object as generally propogated, appears to be prima-facie objectionable, especially in a religious light. It is ordinarily supposed that the Theosophists are trying only to pick up the best portions of every existing religion and combine the whole with the most valuable discoveries of modern science for the benefit of all man-kind. It is not however certain whether this would prove useful to the public in any manner, even if it were ever practicable, but at any rate, it might have been wiser and less harmful, if they started a new religion of their own, as it would be liable to stand or fall on its own merits without affecting the others. The process in question doubtless implies, at the very commencement, an undesirable disrespectful and unmeritted insinuation upon the disinterested efforts of the most venerable originators of every religion,

who are naturally and reasonably understood as having been persons of immense wisdom, sympathy aud religious devotion, and are acknowledged as fit and competent mediators between God and man, in the interest of the latter. That their earnest productions called religions should be so freely and so easily taken to contain 99 per cent of worthless stuff and consequently requiring to pick up the remaining valuable portions, if any, from their midst, is, I daresay in itself a sure sign of ignorance, insolence and irreligion. It is extremely doubtful whether a single member could be found in this new creed, fit to come forward boldly as having acquired a thorough and correct knowledge of any one religion, much less of all religions or all sciences even. The process adopted for surveying in one glance all the existingreligions in the world and for extracting their essences as one chemical product, must necessarily remain a divine secret for ever. Nor is it sufficiently intelligible how the results of modern material sciences, could have retrospective effect upon ancient spiritual religions, and why the latter should ever care for or depend upon the help of the former.

 With reference to the Yekshas, Danavas, Rakshasas, Genthervas &c., so clearly explained in soveral of the passages just quoted, it is impossible to pass over without noticing that the description offered in the Theosophical fashion noted below, will unhesitatingly prove how completely it is wrong and how far away it is, from the truth.

 'Sanathana-Dharma' by Mrs. Besant, page 87 Chapter II 'On the Many'.

 "To this brief sketch of the world process it should be added that the early human races preceding the Aryan are often referred to under the names of Danavas and Daityas, huge beings of enormous strength and energy, who carried

on many a struggle with the Devas themselves. The Rakshasas were another race, more brutal in nature, usually malformed, huge, cruel, powerful, cannibals, the terror of milder races. They possessed moreover, many magical secrets of a dark kind, which they used for terrorising and oppressing. All these have long entirely disappeared from the earth".

 I humbly trust that the irrelevancy and the absurdity of the above elucidation are self-evident; and there is no doubt that many or most of the important items in our sacred religion are dealt with in this off-hand and ridiculous manner. The very nature of the commencement of this special and curious kind of work strikes one clearly as an unnecessary, profitless and pernicious effort, inevitably doomed.

**"Begun in folly ended in disgrace  
Fit consummation of an earthly race".**

**आगमैस्सदृशारम्भः।  
आरम्भसदृशोदयः॥**

 **6.** The significance of the Pitris may be enquired into next, as they are often found apparently confounded with the Devas just noticed. They however deserve a closer examination for the reason that they are commonly understood to be directly connected with and sometimes even representing our own departed ancestors. Besides, they are considered to be more in touch with the human race than the Devas or other Gods.

कृत्वा परमकं ब्रह्मा ध्यायन् सर्वेषु रूपकैः।  
तन्मात्रा निर्ययुर्देहाद् धूमवर्णकृतत्विषः।  
तान्दृष्ट्वासहसा ब्रह्मा तिर्यक्संस्थास्ततोन्मुखान्।**

***Q. No. IV.***

**आदिदेवसुतास्तात पितरो देवदेवताः।**  
**तान् यजन्ति च वै लोकाः सदेवानरदानवाः।**

**आप्यायिताश्च ते सर्वे पुनराप्याययन्ति च।**  
**जगत्सदेवगन्धर्वमिति ब्रह्मानुशासनम्।**  
**तान् यजस्व महाभाग श्राद्धैरग्र्यैरतन्द्रितः।**  
**ते ते श्रेयोभिधास्यन्ति सर्वकामफलप्रदाः॥**

**देवानसृजत ब्रह्मा मां यक्षध्वं स चाह तान्।**  
**तमुत्सृज्य ततोत्मानं अयजन्त फलार्थिनः।**  
**ते शप्ता ब्रह्मणा मूढा नष्टसंज्ञा भविष्यथ।**  
**तस्मात्किञ्चिदजानन्तो नष्टसंज्ञाः पितामहम्।**  
**प्रोचुस्तं प्रणताः सर्वे कुरुष्वानुग्रहं हि नः।**  
**इत्युक्तस्तानुवाचेदं प्रायश्चित्तार्थमेव हि॥**

**पुत्रान् स्वान् परिपृछध्वं ततो ज्ञानमवाप्स्यथ।**  
**इत्युक्ता नष्टसंज्ञास्ते पुत्रान् पप्रछुरोजसा।**  
**प्रायश्चित्तार्थतत्वज्ञा लब्धसंज्ञा दिवौकसः।**

**गम्यतां पुत्रका एवं पित्रैरुक्ताश्चते तदा।  
अपि शप्तास्तु ते देवाः पुत्रकामेन वेधसम्।  
पप्रछुः पुत्रैरुक्तास्ते गतास्ते पुत्रका इति।  
ततस्तानब्रवीद्देवायूयं न ब्रह्मवादिनः।  
तस्माद्यदुक्तं युष्माकं तत्तथा न तदन्यथा।  
यूयं शरीरकर्तारो न च ज्ञानप्रदायिनः।  
अन्योन्यं पितरो यूयं भविष्यथ न संशयः।  
देवाश्च पितरश्चैव बुध्यध्वं त्रिदिवौकसः।  
ततस्ते छिन्नसंदेहाःप्रीतिमन्तः परस्परम्।  
बभूवुर्देवान् प्रोचुस्तान् यदुक्तं पुत्रका वयम्।  
तस्माद्भवन्तः पितरो भविष्यथ न संशयः।  
पितॄन् श्राद्धे क्रियाः काश्चित्करिष्यति न संशयः।  
श्राद्धैराप्यायितः सोमो लोकानाप्याययिष्यति।  
समुद्रपर्वतवनं जङ्गमं जङ्गमैर्वृतम्।  
श्राद्धानि पुष्टिकामाश्च ये करिष्यन्ति मानवाः।  
तेभ्यः पुष्टिं प्रजाश्चैव पितरः प्रीणिताः सदा।  
श्राद्धे ये च प्रदास्यन्ति त्रीन् पिण्डान् नामगोत्रतः।  
सर्वत्र वर्तमानास्ते पितरः प्रपितामहान्।  
भावयिष्यन्ति सततं श्राद्धदानेन तर्पिताः।  
इति तद्वचनं सत्यम्अवगम्य दिवौकसः।  
पुत्राश्च पितरश्चैव वयं सर्वे परस्परम्।  
एवं ते पितरो देवा देवाश्च पितरस्तथा।  
अन्योन्यपितरो वै ते देवाश्च पितरश्च ह।  
देवकार्यादपि मुने पितृकार्यं विशिष्यते॥**

**श्रीशिवमहापुराणम्॥**

***Q. No. V.***

**ब्रह्मणः सृजतः पुत्रान् पूर्वे स्वायम्भुवेन्तरे।  
गात्रेभ्यो जज्ञिरे तस्य मनुष्यासुरदेवताः।  
पितृवन्मन्यमानास्तं जज्ञिरे पितरोऽपि च।  
देवासुरमनुष्यांश्च दृष्ट्वाब्रह्माभ्यमन्यत।**

**पितृवन्मन्यमाना वै जज्ञिरेऽस्योपपक्षतः।**  
**मध्वादयःषडृतवः पितृस्तान् परिचक्षते।**  
**ऋतवः पितरो देवा इत्येषा वैदिकी श्रुतिः।**  
**अयज्वानस्तथा तेषामासन्ये गृहमेधिनः।**  
**अभिष्वात्ता स्मृतास्तेवै पितरोऽनाहितामयः।**  
**यज्वानस्तेषु ये त्वासन् पितरः सोमपीथिनः।**  
**स्मृता बर्हिषदस्ते वै पितरस्त्वग्निहोत्रिणः।**  
**ऋतवः पितरो देवाः शास्त्रेस्मिन्निश्चयं गताः।**  
**मधुमाधवौ रसौ ज्ञेयौ शुचिशुकौ च शुष्मिणौ।**  
**नभाश्चैव नभस्यश्च जीवावेतावुदाहृतौ।**  
**इषश्चैव तथोर्जश्च स्वधावन्तावुदाहृतौ।**  
**सहश्चैव सहस्यश्चघोरावेतावुदाहृतौ।**  
**तपाश्चैव तपस्यश्च मन्युमन्तौ तु शैशिरौ।**  
**कालावस्था तु षट्स्वेते मासाख्या वै व्यवस्थिताः।**  
**इमे च ऋतवः प्रोक्ताः चेतनाचेतनेषु वै।**  
**ऋतवोब्रह्मणः पुत्रा विज्ञेयास्तेभिमानिनः।**  
**मासार्धमासस्थानेषु स्थानिनो ऋतवोमताः।**  
**स्थानानां व्यतिरेकेण ज्ञेयाःस्थानाभिमानिनः।**  
**अहोरात्राणि मासाश्च ऋतवश्चायनानि च।**  
**संवत्सराश्च स्थानानि कामाख्या ह्यभिमानिनाम्।**  
**एतेषु स्थानिनो ये तु कालावस्थाव्यवस्थिताः।**  
**तत्सतत्वास्तदात्मानस्तान्वक्ष्यामि निबोधत।**  
**पार्वण्यस्तिथयः संध्याःपक्षा मासार्धसम्मिताः।**  
**निमेषाश्चकलाः काष्ठा मुहुर्ता दिवसाः क्षमाः।**  
**द्वावर्धमासौ मासस्तु द्वौ मासावृतुरुच्यते।**  
**ऋतुत्रयञ्चाप्ययनं द्वेयने दक्षिणोत्तरे।**  
**संवत्सरःसमेतश्च स्थानान्येतानि स्थानिनाम्।**  
**ऋतवस्तु निमेः पुत्रा विज्ञेयास्ते तथैव षट्।**  
**ऋतुपुत्राः स्मृताः पत्र प्रजाःस्वार्तवलक्षणाः।**  
**यस्माश्चैवार्तषेभ्यस्तु जायन्ते स्थाणुजङ्गमाः।**

**आर्तवाः पितरस्तस्मादृतवश्च पितामहाः।**  
**समेतास्तु प्रसूयन्ते प्रजाश्चैव प्रजापतेः।**  
**तस्मात्स्मृतः प्रजानां वै वत्सरः प्रपितामहः।**  
**स्थानेषु स्थानिनोह्येते स्थानात्मानः प्रकीर्तिताः।**  
**तदाख्यास्तत्सतत्वाश्च तदात्मानश्च ते स्मृताः।**  
**प्रजापतिः स्मृतो यस्तु सतु संवत्सरो मतः।**  
**संवत्सरसुतोह्यग्नि ऋत इत्युच्यते बुधैः।**  
**ऋतात्तु ऋतवो यस्माज्जज्ञिरे ऋतवस्ततः।**  
**मासाः षडर्तवो ज्ञेयास्तेषां पञ्चार्तवाः स्मृताः।**  
**द्विपदां चतुष्पदाञ्चैव पक्षिणां सर्पतामपि।**  
**स्थावराणाञ्च पञ्चानां पुष्पं कालार्तवं स्मृतम्।**  
**ऋतुत्वमार्तवत्वञ्च पितृत्वञ्च प्रकीर्तितम्।**  
**इत्येते पितरो ज्ञेया ऋतवश्चार्तवाश्च ये।**  
**सर्वभूतानि तेभ्यो यदृतुकालाद्विजज्ञिरे।**  
**तस्मादेते हि पितरःआर्तवा इति नः श्रुतम्।**  
**मन्वन्तरेष्विहत्वेते स्थिताःकालाभिमानिनः।**  
**कार्यकारणयुक्तास्तु ऐश्वर्याद्व्याप्य संस्थिताः।**  
**स्थानाभिमानिनो ह्येते तिष्ठन्तीह प्रसङ्गमात्।**  
**अग्निष्वात्ता बर्हिषदःपितरो विविधाः पुनः।**  
**जज्ञे स्वधा पितृभ्यस्तु द्वे कन्ये लोकविश्रुते।**  
**मेना च धारणी चैव याभ्यां धृतमिदं जगत्।**  
**ते उभे ब्रह्मवादिन्यौ योगिन्यौ चैव ते उभे।**  
**पितरस्ते निजे कन्ये धर्मार्थं प्रददुः शुभे।**  
**अभिष्वात्तास्तु ये प्रोक्तास्तेषां मेना तु मानसी।**  
**धारणी मानसी चैव कन्या बर्हिषदां स्मृता।**  
**मेरोस्तां धारणीं नाम पत्न्यर्थं वासृजन् शुभाम्।**  
**पितरस्ते बर्हिषदःस्मृता ये सोमपायिनः।**  
**अभिष्वात्तास्तु तां मेना पत्नी हिमवतो ददुः।**  
**उपहूता स्मृता ये वै तौहित्रान्निबोधत।**  
**मेना हिमवतः पत्नी मैनाकं सा व्यजायत।**

**गङ्गां सरिद्वरां चैव पत्नी या लवणोदधेः।**  
**मैनाकस्यात्मजः क्रौञ्चः क्रौञ्चद्वीपो यतः स्मृतः।**  
**मेरोस्तु धारणी पत्नी दिव्वौषधिसमन्वितम्।**  
**मन्दरं सुषुवे पुत्रं तिस्रः कन्याश्च विश्रुताः।**  
**वेलाञ्च नियतिञ्चैव तृतीयाञ्चायतिं विदुः।**  
**धातुश्चैवायतिः पत्नी विधातुर्नियतिः स्मृता॥**

**अतः पितॄन् प्रवक्ष्यामि मासश्राद्धभुजस्तु ये।**  
**तेषां गतिं सतत्वाञ्च प्राप्तिं श्राद्धस्य चैव हि।**  
**न मृतानां गतिःशक्या ज्ञातुं न पुनरागतिः।**  
**तपसापि प्रसिद्धेन किं पुनर्मांसचक्षुषा।**  
**अनुदेवपितॄनेते पितरो लौकिकाः स्मृताः।**  
**पिता पितामहश्चापि तथा यः प्रपितामहः।**  
**यज्वानो ये तु सोमेन सोमवन्तस्तु ते स्मृताः।**  
**ये यज्वानो हविर्यज्ञे ते वै बर्हिषदः स्मृताः।**  
**अग्निष्वात्ता स्मृतास्तेषां होमिनोऽयाज्ययाजिनः।**  
**तेषान्तु धर्मसाधर्म्यात् स्मृताः सायुज्यगाद्विजैः।**  
**ये चाप्याश्रमधर्माणां प्रस्थानेषु व्यवस्थिताः।**  
**अन्ते तु नावसीदन्ति श्रद्धायुक्तास्तु कर्मसु।**  
**तपसा ब्रह्मचर्येण यज्ञेन प्रजया च वै।**  
**श्राद्धेन विद्यया चैव प्रदानेन च सप्तधा।**  
**कर्मस्वेतेषु ये भुक्ता भवन्त्यादेहपातनात्।**  
**देवैस्तैःपितृभिः सार्धं सूक्ष्मजैः सोमयाजनैः।**  
**स्वर्गतादिविमोदन्ते पितृवत्त उपासते।**  
**तेषां निवापे दत्ते तु तत्कुलीनैश्च बन्धुभिः।**  
**मासश्राद्धभुजस्तृप्तिं लभन्ते सोमलौकिकाः।**  
**एते मनुष्यपितरो मासश्राद्धभुजस्तु ये॥**

**तेभ्योऽपरे तु येप्यन्ये सङ्कीर्णाःकर्मयोनिषु।**  
**भ्रष्टाश्चाश्रमधर्मेभ्यः स्वधास्वाहाविवर्जिताः।**  
**भिन्नदेहा दुरात्मानः प्रेतभूता यमक्षये।**

**स्वकर्मण्यनुशोचन्तो यातनास्थानमागताः।**  
**दीर्घायुषोतिशुष्काश्च श्मश्रुलाश्च विवाससः।**  
**क्षुत्पिपासापरीताश्च विद्रवन्तस्ततस्ततः।**  
**सरित्सरस्तटागानि वापीश्चाप्युपलिप्सवः।**  
**परान्नानि च लिप्सन्तःकाल्यमानास्ततस्ततः।**  
**स्थानेषु पाल्यमानाश्च यातनाश्च पुनःपुनः।**  
**शाल्मले वैतरण्याञ्च असिपत्रवने तथा।**  
**शिलासम्पेषणे चैव पात्यमानः स्वकर्मभिः।**  
**तत्रस्थानां हि तेषां वै दुःखितानामनाशिनाम्।**  
**तेषां लोकान्तरस्थानां बान्धवैर्नामगोत्रतः।**  
**भूमावसव्यं दर्भेषु दत्ताः पिण्डास्त्रयस्तु वै।**  
**यान्ति तांस्तर्पयन्ते च प्रेतस्थानेष्वधिष्ठितान्।**  
**अप्राप्ता यातनास्थानं प्रभ्रष्टा ये च पञ्चधा।**  
**पश्चाद्ये स्थावरान्ते वै जाता नीचैः स्वकर्मभिः।**  
**नानारूपासु जायन्ते तिर्यग्योनिष्वयो निषु।**  
**यदाहारा भवन्त्येते तासु तास्विह योनिषु।**  
**तस्मिंतस्मिंस्तदाहारे श्राद्धं दत्तं प्रतिष्ठते।**  
**कालेन्यायागतं पात्रे विधिना प्रतिपादितम्।**  
**प्राप्नोत्यन्नं यथा दत्तं जन्तुर्यत्रावतिष्ठते।**  
**यथा गोषु प्रणष्ठासु वत्सो विन्दति मातरम्।**  
**तथा श्राद्धेषु दत्तान्नं मन्त्रः प्रापयते पितॄन्।**  
**एवं ह्यविफलं श्राद्धं श्रद्धादत्तन्तु मन्त्रतः।**  
**तत्तत् कुमारः प्रोवाच पश्यन् दिव्येन चक्षुषा।**  
**गतागतज्ञः प्रेतानां प्राप्तिं श्राद्धस्य तैस्सह।**  
**बाह्लीकाश्चोष्मपाश्चैव दिवाकीर्त्याश्च ते स्मृताः।**  
**कृष्णपक्षस्त्वहस्तेषां शुक्लःस्वप्नाय शर्वरी।**  
**इत्येते पितरो देवा देवाश्च पितरश्च वै।**  
**ऋत्वार्तवार्धमासास्तु अन्योन्यं पितरः स्मृताः।**  
**इत्येते पितरो देवा मनुष्यपितरश्च ये !**  
**प्रीतेषु तेषु प्रीयन्ते श्राद्धयुक्तेषु कर्मसु॥**

**ब्रह्माण्डपुराणम्॥**

 ***Quotation. No. I.***

 "Bramha concentrated his mind and brought out of it the Tan-mathras or subtle elements. He meditated upon the forms of everything and these elements originated from his body in smoky colour. Bramha saw them seated in the organic world and looking upwards. He said that they shall be the Pitris or fathers of all the Griha-imedhins. Those that looked up were specially named Nandi-mukhas. Bramha also prescribed a path for the Pitris called Dekshinayana".

 The Pitris are here clearly defined as representing the subtle elements, originating from Bramha, seated in the organic world and looking upwards. They are however saidto be the Pitris only of Griha-medhins or intelligent and pure people. The elements in themselves are naturally the fathers, originators or the material cause for all existing things. But the term Pitris is here restricted to their conception as pure and leading upwards, all the material associations leading downwards being entirely eliminated. We will see more of this in the subsequent quotations.

**  *Q. No II.***

 "The subtle elements are known as Tan-mathras, because they remain pure and unmixed. They are also called Aviseshas, because they are not perceptible and are devoid of the three qualities known as Santa, Ghora and Mudha. The creation by the subtle elements is by their intermixture, producing the gross elements known as Visesha and perceptible by the senses, each element possessing its own quality as well as the qualities of the elements preceding. Bramha created the Pitris from both of his sides, at the interval between day and night. Bramba's form in the middle of day and night is thus more glorious, and the Rishis, Devas, Asuras and Manus therefore worship that form with great devotion. The Devas were created in the

day time and the Asuras at night. The day is Satwic, the night is Tamasic and the interval is Sandya when a great light proceeded from Bramha. The Pitris grant the boon of knowledge and are therefore worshipped by Sradhas. The Pitris by their Yoga then please the Soma, the protector of the three Lokas. In the Sradha ceremonies therefore, Yogis should be procured as far as possible, because the strength of the Pitris depends on their Yoga which produces Soma. Here Soma represents the ocean of Akasa which is the basis for all the elements and the Devas. All the Lowkik water proceeds from this Akasic Soma which supports the universe. This is the real fact. The six seasons of the year called Ritus are explained in the Sastras as Pitris and Devas. Among the Pitris, the Agni-hotris or worshippers of fire are known as Berhishads, those who do not so worship are Agnishwathas and those who perform Somayegna are Somapithis".

 The Pitris have been already explained as representing the subtle elements. Yoga is here said to be their distinguishing feature. They are created at Sandhya or between the day and night of Bramha which refer to the creations of Devas and Asuras. This Puranic narration distinctly explains the significance of the Pitris. The creation of the Pitris thus points out the transition stage from the Asuri to the Dyvi nature, from materiality to the religious and philosophical. The Yoga pertaining to Tan-mathras and leading to the higher states of philosophical meditation is here enunciated. By satisfying the Pitris, Soma is said to be pleased. The technical Soma is an entirely misunderstood and highly abused term, among the Sanskrit Pandits and the so-called Vydiks at present. The Yegnas or devotional acts misinterpreted as prescribing the killing of sheep and drinking of liquor, originate chiefly from the ignorance of the meaning

of the term Soma. We have noticed its real significance already in several places and it is here defined particularly in connection with the very Sradha ceremonies, leaving no scope for misunderstanding.

**पितॄणां हि बलं योगो योगात् सोमः प्रवर्तते।  
आकाशाम्भोनिधेर्योसौ सोम इत्यभिधीयते।  
आधारः सर्वभूतानां देवानाममृताकरः।  
सर्वलौकिकमन्भो वै यत् सोमान्नभसः स्मृतम्।  
सोमाधारं जगत्सर्वं एतत्तथ्यं प्रकीर्तितम्॥**

Soma here represents the Chit-Akasa, a stage superior to the Tan-mathras or Pitris, alluding to a perfectly pure, devotional and tranquil state of mind. This Soma can never be pleased by acts of cruelty or ignorance, actuated by avarice, greed, hatred and all other associates of the modern interpretation of Yeguss. यज्ञो वै विष्णुः \। Devotion to Vishnu or Vishnu himself is Yegna according to the Vedas. This sacred religious precept has now unfortunately deteriorated so far as to signify the abominable ceremonies of a butcher and a drunkard.

**यूपान् छित्वा पशून् हत्वा कृत्वा रुधिरकर्दमम्।  
यद्येवं गम्यते स्वर्गे नरके केन गम्यते॥**

** *Q. No. III.***

 "In the heavens, there are seven classes of Pitris, three of them are formless, but four of them have forms. The formless classes belong to the Virat, they are worshipped by the Devas and are known as Vyrajas. The class of Pitris who secure liberation only at the end of Bramha's day owing to their incomplete Yoga, has & mind-born daughter named Mena, the wife of Himavat. Minaka is his son and Krowncha his son, from whom the name Krowncha-dwipa originated. Mens gave birth to three daughters, all Yoginis, named Uma, Ekaparna and Aparna, married to Rudra,

Bhrigu and Jygishavya respectively. The Lokas of the Pitris are called Somapatha, or the path to Soma. The Pitris named Agnishwathas and Yejwanas, the sons of Maricha or light, reside in these Lokas, and they are worshipped by the Devas. A similar class of Pitris belonging to the same family, sons of Angira called Havishmanthas, reside in the Sun They are very kind and loving towards their devotees. The chief among them is the Sun. The Sradha ceremony is of three kinds, Nithya or daily, Nymithika or occasional, and Kamya or optional. Among the Bramhins, when the father dies, the sons should perform the Sradha known as Ekodhishta, extending to ten days, at the end of which, the deceased attains to the position of a fourth class Pitri, and afterwards obtains immortality among the three classes of Pitris. The Vedas say that the father takes the form of Vasus, the grandfather that of Rudras and the great-grand-father, that of Adityas".

 We could easily see from this quotation that the varieties of Pitris enumerated, allude to certain religious and philosophical facts, and that the Sradha ceremonies prescribed are meant for taking the deceased ancestors to the positions åssigned to the Pitris. We shall soon see more of this in detail.

**  *Q. No. IV.***

 "The Pitris are the sons of the original Devas, and they are adored by the Devas, Dana vas, men, Yekshas, Rakshasas, Gendharvas, Kinnaras and Mahoragas. When the Pitris are pleased, they please all by bestowing blessings; therefore Bramha ordered all people to perform Sradhas to the Pitris. When the Devas were created by Bramha, theywere asked to worship him. Disobeying this order, the Devas looked after their own interest. They were therefore cursed by Bramha to become ignorant. Then they begged

for pardon. Bramha asked them to go to Pitris and get enlightened. The Devas did accordingly and when they left the Pitris, the latter addressed the Devas as sons. The Devas returned and informed Bramha of all this, and Bramha replied that the Devas are not bestowers of Gnana but only of rebirths and that they shall therefore be reckoned as sons of the Pitris. Thus the Pitris and the Devas became mutually sons and fathers. When the Pitris are pleased by Sradhas, Soma is pleased and Soma pleases the Lokas. The Pitris being everywhere, in the ocean, in the hills, in the movable and in the immovable, wherever the three balls of rice are offered at the Sradha, saying the name and gotra of the deceased ancestors, the Pitris grant their blessings. The Pitris sholud be worshipped invariably before the Devas"

 The paradox in the mutual parentage of the Devas and the Pitris shall be explained shortly. But we must not fail to notice that the Pandit is acquainted with the cake and the bread alone in the Sradhas here described. The Soma perhaps makes up the necessary drink. The gift of a few coins at the end will perfectly complete the Sradha ceremony.

** *Q. No. V.***

 "In the Swayambhuva Manwantara, Devas, Asuras and men originated from the body of Bramha. From both his sides, the Pitris originated who respected Bramha as their father. The Vedas and Sastras say that the Rithus or the six seasons in the year are the Devas and Pitris. The Pitris are of three classes, Agnishwathas, Somapithis and Berhishadas. The Rithus are six in number each consisting of two months, named, Sisira, Vasanta, Grishma, Varsha, Sarad and Hima. They are known as the sons of Nimi. They signify the guiding and controlling power of Bramh a in conducting the seasons and not the seasons them–

selves. They are so named as they are recognised only by the working of these seasons. Nimisha, kala, kashta, Muhurta, day, night and month are divisions of time. Two months make one Rithu, three Rithus one Ayana and two Ayanas one year. The sons of Rithus are the five Arthavas referring to the productive seasons of all created things. They are known as Pitris or fathers and the year as grand-father and Prejapathi. The terms used refer only to the power of conducting the seasons. Agni or fire, the son of Samvatsara is called Rita. From Rita, the Ritavas originated and from them the five Arthavas. There are different kinds of Pitris like the Agnishwathas and Berhishadas. Two daughters, both Yoginis and philosophers, named Mena and Dharani were born from the minds of Agnishwathas and Berhishadas respectively. Mena married Himavat and gave birth to Mynaka as well as Ganga the wife of the ocean. Krowncha is the son of Mynaka from whom Krowncha-dwipa took its naine. Dharani married Meru and brought forth Mandara and three daughters named, Vela, Niyati and Ayati. Ayati married Dhata and Niyati, Vidhata. I shall next narrate to you the Pitris to whom monthly sradhas are offered. They are known as Anu-deva-pitris. It is difficult to know even with great tapas the conditions of the deceased, more so with human eyes. By a mere analogical correspondence in the karmas of the religious people, they are also styled after death, Agnishwathas, Somapas and Berhishadas, but they are not the real Pitris signified by the terms. Those who lead a very honourable life until their death, practising the prescribed devotional acts, join the Pitris and the Devas in heaven, and they are propitiated by monthly Sradhas like the real Pitris. But for those who were wicked and irreligious all their life, and now keep running about as Pretas in the Hell undergoing punishment, three balls of rice should be placed on the ground over the Derbha grass.

There are others who have taken after death, the bodies of lower animals or of vegetables. The rice offered in the Sradha reaches them in the special forins of their food by the force of Manthra as a calf naturally finds out its cow. This is assure 1 by the Rishi named Sanat-kumara who is gifted with divine eyes. These Pitris are known as Bahlikas, Ushiapas and Divakirtis. The dark fortnight is their day-time and the bright fortnight their night. Thus, the Pitris, the Devas, Rithus, Arthavas, half-months and months are mutually considered Pitris. When the Pitris, the Devas and Manushya-pitris are pleased by Sradhas, they bestow all blessings on man".

 The various classifications of the Pitris here furnished are po doubt highly technical and philosophical. The Pandit will of course reduce the whole description to the history of his deceased ancestors whose life is distinctly stated to be different from that of the real Pitris. The Pitris are said to have their children and grand-children. Mena and Dharani are their mind-born daughters, and Vela, Niyati, Ayati,. Uma, Ekaparna, Aparna aud Ganga are grand-daughters. The mountains named Mynaka, Mindara and Krowncha are grand and great grand-children. How could deceased ancestors produce daughters and how these daughters again bring forth mountains, rivers and girls? If the description on the whole is meaningless, why should the Pandit attempt to explain it ?
