 The technical terms used in the quotation are explained in the same. The modern interpreters might erase some of

these lines as they are very vexing indeed. But how do they feel confident that their unauthorised, unqualified and unreasonable misinterpretations are exceedingly pleasing to others? No doubt they judge everything by their own standard, but forget that they will be judged at one time by better standards.

**ये के विचित्ररसशालिषु सत्कवीनां सूक्तेषु कर्णपथगामिषु नाद्रियन्ते।  
ते मालतीपरिमलेष्वपि कन्दलत्सु नासापुटंकरतलेन पिदध्युरेव॥**

 **10.** The descriptions of Rishis as found in the passages quoted above, disclose plainer, simpler and less complicated facts as compared with those enquired into, in the preceding paras, and we are consequently in a position to understand them without much thought and trouble.

 The Rishis clearly represent certain definite conditions of intellectual development in man to be attained by Yoga and Sankhya practices. The significance of almost all the names may be invariably traced by referring to their derivations. it is easy to discover that none of the denote the proper names of any specific individuals, but point to some advanced stages of human conduct leading on to the ultimate goal. The large number of Rishis differing in character indicate the various halting places provided for, in the progressive path of religious devotion. Every one of them therefore deserves and demands due respect and consideration, if only the object of running out the prescribed course completely, is ever aimed at. The different classifications of Rishis furnished in the quotations should be correctly understood for the proper comprehension and practice of the ordained courses of action in our sacred religion without a knowledge of which they are apt to be treated as profitless and superstitious. Every Manthra or religious prayer has its particular Rishi recognised, clearly showing how the stage

of attainment of the devotee is distinctly marked and a suitable Manthra is provided for his benefit. There is thus not the slightest doubt as to the important part played by these Rishis throughout our religious ordinances, and it costs no effort to discover that invariably all the valuable and religious instructions conveyed in the texts are in the names of some specific Rishis. The names of the Instructors thus particularised are not therefore meaningless or purposeless. A very valuable clue is by this means furnished at the very commencement, for the correct interpretations of the contents of the instructions, and for noticing the intellectual, moral and religious status of the persons to whom they are intended. Quotation 7 classifies two sets of Sapta-Rishis or seven Rishis said to have been born from the mind of Bramha; referring directly to the seven Prakritis or material causes of creation. The two sets are distinguished from each other by the nature of their work, one pertaining to Nivriti, Sankhya or Gnana-Yoga; and the other to Pravriti or Karma-Yoga. The seven Rishis dealing with the former are, Sana, Sanatsujata, Sanaka; Sanadana, Sanat-kumara, Kapila and Sanatana; those dealing with the latter are, Marichi, Angira, Atri, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kretu and Vasishta, and adding Swayambhuva-Manu, the latter set makes up the eight Prakritis. The vital distinction between Karma-yoga and Gnana-yoga as well as their practical applications in detail are ingeniously explained by this classification.

 In our philosophical analysis, we have already seen that the cosmological conception of the Universe resolves itself into seven Prakritis. Each of these Prakritis is here taken into consideration and utilized in two different ways for purposes of religious advancement. The Pravriti-marga or Karma-yoga deals with the Prakritis by cognising the energy of Eswara inherent in their respective functions in

the evolution of the religions universe, and meditates upon the unthwarted display of each Prakriti as the glories of the Almighty exhibited through them. The Nivriti-marga or Gnana-yoga, on the other hand simply notices the work of the Prakritis but passes on to the real goal beyond, leaving them as comparatively unimportant in consideration of the transient nature of the phenomenal existence as a whole. The processess for correctly understanding the scope and extent of each of the Prakritis, and for obtaining control over each of them with a view to pass over, one after another, are doubtless matters of practical and religious importance. It might perhaps be necessary to be reminded of the real significance of Prakriti and of its evolution and involution of the religious universe, lest the readers go astray even at the present stage of this essay. Let it be told again and again that Prakriti alludes to the Satwic Maya and not to Avidya, and that the evolution and involution of the universe here noticed are the work of the former explained as the glories of God. The evolution and involution of the material world with all its miseries and disappointments belong to the functions of Avidya, and they display no doubt, the glories of the wickedness and stupidity of the individual man, which the religious texts do not recognise either in the Karma-yoga or Gnana-yoga, in the Pravriti-marga or Nivrti-marga prescribed for devotional practices. The meditation of a God or Goddess in some material form prescribed for the lower grades of practice cannot be substituted by the meditation of the form of a whore for religious purposes. The Pandit always forgets this fact and imagines he is extremely religious in his own favourite meditations.

**द्रष्टव्येषु किमुत्तमं मृगदृशां प्रेमप्रसन्नं मुखम्  
घ्रातव्येषु च किं तदास्यपवनश्श्राव्येषु किन्तद्वचः।**

**किं खाद्येषु तदोष्टपल्लवरसः स्पृश्येषु किं तद्वपु-  
ध्येयं किं नवयौवनं सहृदयैस्सर्वत्र तद्विभ्रमः॥**

 The derivative meaning of the word Rishi is clearly explained in quotation **1** as pointing to the capability of approaching or taking near to the Bramhan step by step. The gradual progress on the prescribed path of religious practice is marked distinctly at every specific stage, by giving suitable appellations to the Rishis concerned. In the same quotation we find full and significant definitions furnished for the following names.  
  1. Rishi,       2. Parama-Rishi,  3. Atma-Rishi;  
  4. Maha-Rishi;   5.Satya-Rishi;    6. Sruta-Rishi;  
  7.Bramha-Rishi;  8.Deva-Rishi;    9. Raja-Rishi;  
  10. Rishikas and  11. Rishi-putras.

We find again that six Rishis already enumerated are classed under Prajapathis; namely, Marichi, Kretu, Athri, Pulastya, Pulaha and Vasishta. In quotation 3 we find that three more names are added namely Bhrigu, Angira and Narada, thus making the number of Prajapathis into 9. They are dercribed in quotation 1, as follows.

**लोकसन्तानकरा स्तैरिमा वर्द्धिता प्रजाः।  
एतद्वंशसमुद्भूताः स्थानकालाभिमानिनः॥**

Quotation 2 speaks of them thus.

 **साधकाः ग्रहमेधिनः॥**

 They are said to be the progenitors of the families in the Lokas and skilful adepts in family-life. Slightly equivocal descriptions of this kind occasionally might mislead the reader who has no idea of what is being narrated. For such mistakes, it is not proper to lay the blame on the venerable authors of these texts, as it is the privilege of no reader of books to pick up a single line or two and to criticise or inisinterpret the whole in his own way, utterly disregarding

the portions before and after. The Lokas have been already found on examination to be different from this earthy sphere, and the subjects, Prajas and families here mentioned, musttherefore represent something equally different. Quotation 10 clearly defines Prajapathi as the Heart and Praja as Prana.

**“एष प्रजापतिर्यत् हृदयं एतत् ब्रह्मैतत्सर्वे तदेतत्र्यक्षरं हृदयामिति॥"  
“पिता माता प्रजैत एव मन एव पिता वाङ्माता प्राणःप्रजा"**

 The Lokas thus refer to the several Prakritis identical with the corresponding Rishis themselves; and the families or Prajas originated in them denote the respective effects produced on the intellect of the devotee by the meditation of these Lokas and their working as the glories of God. Thus far the functions of one set of Sapta-Rishis and of the six or nine Prajapathis are explained. The remaining Sapta-Rishis deal solely with Gnana-yoga without special meditations on these Lokas and their workings.

 Our quotations on the subject in question, furnish however, still further varieties of classification and they deserve careful examination.

 The origin of three elasses of Rishis is detailed in quotation **1.** The Bramha-Rishis came first. From them the second set styled Deva-Rishis originated. From the Deva-Rishis again the third set known as Raja-Rishis originated. Those who take us or lead us to the Bramhan direct aredefined as Bramha-Rishis, and those leading to the Devas are Deva-Rishis; and the rulers who lead and guide their subjects by pleasing them are styled Raja-Rishis. The last set alone demands some explanation. But any doubts with regard to their definitions will be cleared when we examine their whereabouts. The Bramha-Rishis are said to inhabit

the Brainha-loka, the Deva. Rishis, the Deva-loka and the Raja -Rishis the Indra-loka.

**ब्रह्मलोकप्रतिष्ठास्तु स्मृता ब्रह्मर्षयो मताः।  
देवलोकप्रतिष्ठाश्च ज्ञेया देवर्षयः शुभाः।  
इन्द्रलोकप्रतिष्ठास्तु सर्वे राजर्षयो मताः॥**

It is indeed surpsising to note that no Rishi has his residence in any of the modern towns or even forests situated on the surface of our mother earth.

 The above classification is said to be based upon their caste, their Tapas and the nature of the Manthras attributed to them.

**अभिजात्या च तपसा मन्त्रव्याहरणैस्तथा।  
एवं ब्रह्मर्षयः प्रोक्ता दिव्या राजर्षयस्तु ये।  
सप्तैते सप्तभिश्चैव गुणैःसप्तर्षयः स्मृताः॥**

What is meant by their caste is clearly explained in quotation 5. They are divided into the five following castes and are said to represent the knowledge of Avyakta, Mahat, Ahamkara, Bhuta and Indriya.

 1. Avyakta-Atma: 2. Mahanta-Atma; 3. Ahomkara-Atma; 4. Bhuta-Atma and 5. Indriya-Atma respectively.

**अव्यक्तात्मा महान्तात्माहङ्कारात्मा तथैव च।  
भूतात्मा चेन्द्रियात्मा च तेषां तज्ञानमुच्यते।  
इत्येवमृषिजात्यस्तु पञ्चधा नाम विश्रुताः॥**

It would certainly be a pity still to doubt the significance of the Rishis and equally a hopeless task to furnish further explanations. The Lokas specified, represent the respective stages attributed to the Rishis and the Sastras pertaining to those Lokas are instructions for attaining them. All these are said to be the productions of the Rishis themselves, in quotation 7.

**लोकान् सञ्चिन्त्य मनसा ततः शास्त्रं प्रचक्रिरे॥**

 The Lokas are identical with the psychological matters specified and are simply so describe for the purpose of making them easily understandable to the ordinary people. But unfortunately they are entirely misun lorstood and the object aimed at is frustrated completely in modern days.

 'लोक्यत इतिलोकः। ब्रह्मैवलोको ब्रह्मलोकः॥ब्रह्मणः पुरं ब्रह्मपुरमिति तदुपलब्धिस्थानं विद्याधिकारिशरीरमुच्यते॥

 न तस्य प्राणा उत्क्रामन्त्यत्रैव समवलीयन्ते। ब्रह्मैव सन् ब्रह्माप्येति॥

 "Lokya refers to reality. Bramha-loka is Bramha itself. Bramha-pura means the region or situation in which Bramha is attained, and this alludes to the qualifiel body of the Yogi. Attaining Bramhan is becoming Bramhan".

 Nothing could be more plainly explained in any human language. But the Pandit discards every human language as he has secured a different one for himself. In his language, everything in his universe is material.

**द्वैतमेव हि सर्वत्र प्रवदन्ति हि केचन।  
न ते मनुष्याः कीटाश्च पतङ्गाश्च घटा हि ते॥**

 From the enquiry so far regarding the significance of the terms conncetel with different forms of Rishis, the philosophical applications are simple and clear; and they do not of course demand any mysterious explanations to understand them in their proper light. This portion of philosophy, as a subject, stripped of its religious references to the point in question, is the common property of all civilized nations, and we have therefore the right to appeal to the philosophers all over the world for its safety, without being meddled with, by illogical and unphilosophical processes. On the pretext of religion, neither our Pandit nor the Theosophist has the privilege of interfering with God-given Intellect and wisdom in man, of ancient or modern

times. Any infringement in this direction could only be treated as an unreasonable and unsuthorisei attack upon Human Reason itself.

 The religious utilization of the philosophical principles in this connection, could be perceived to rest on a scientific basis, provided the philosophy underlying, is properly understood. The Pandit's ignorant interpretations without the knowledge of this philosophy are totally misleadingand the foreign alditions not even independently of the texts, are stranger still. The Theosophists freely quote pissages from Vayu, Vishnu, Padma and other Puranas and base their inferences on thom for their peculiar ideas, entirely new to our religious sphere, such as, spiritual ares and Physical arcs, Astral phantoms and Prototypes, Primaries and doubles &c. That the Rakshasas are the Atlantians belonging to the submerged races, that Varahà-Avatar is an antediluvian lacustrine auimal and that Americans and Europeans belong to the present 5th root-race, and similar theories promulgated in the Secret Doctrine, are certainly astonishing interpretations of our ancient religious texts, and they exhibit no doubt an entirely new method of manufacturing religious absurdities in the commencement of this twentieth century. What strikes one clearly here is that borrowed feathers were hardly needed, if the object were only to shine in this unique fashion.

**झटिति प्रतिवक्तव्यं सभासु विजिगीषुभिः।  
अबद्धं वा सुबद्धं वा कुन्तीपुत्रो विनायकः।  
उच्चैरुच्चरितव्यं यत्किञ्चिदजानतापि पुरुषेण।  
मूर्खा विश्वास्यन्ते विदुषामपि संशयो भवति॥**

 In further proof of the explanations already offered for Rishis in general, a few more terms which possess the appearance of proper names given to individual Rishis may be examined here.

 Quotations 1 and 10 define Vasishta as connected with Prithivi and Vak.

**वसुमध्यात्समुत्पन्नो वसुमान् वसुधाश्रयः।  
वसिष्ठ इति तत्वज्ञैः प्रोच्यते ब्रह्मवादिभिः॥  
वाग्वैवसिष्ठा वसिष्ठः स्वानां भवत्यपि च॥**

Prithivi or earth is here meant to represent the Vedas, the very foundation upon which our sacred religion is built. Vak or word similarly denotes the knowledge of Sruthi or Vedas.

 Quotations 2, 14 and 15 explain Arundhathi, the wife of Vasishta, as referring to the saine Prithivi. She is also defined as representing the tongue and the Goddess Saraswathy.

**पृथिवीविषयं सर्वम्अरुन्धत्यामजायत॥  
अरुन्धत्येव कथिता पुराविद्भिस्सरस्वती॥  
अरुन्धती भवेजिह्वा॥**

 No clearer descriptions are here required to understand the significance of these two terms. The husband of Arundhati here by no mears can act without the help of this particular wife and she has always to depend upon this very husband to maintain her dignity and importance.

 Quotation 6 explains Vyasa as the analyser and commentator of the Vedas exhibiting their true purport; thus referring to that particular faculty.

 Quotation 7 explains Kapila as seated in the sun combined with Vidya aud referring to Sankhya-gnana.

 Quotations 7, 8 and 9 define Sanat-kumara in unequivocal terms, as representing Jiva or individual soul, untainted by worldly filth and remaining as pure as it was while first born as the son of Bramha.

 Quotation 10 describes Angiras as tantamount to Prana. Brahaspathi and Atri are said to be connected with Vak or Vedas and therefore almost synonymous with Vasishta.

 Quotation 11 explains Dettatreya as Eswara who offered himself to Atri as his son, and notes that the Nirukta of this word will furnish complete information.

 Quotation 15 explains three more words, than Arundhati already noticed. Dhruva, Vishnu-pada and Matri-mandala, are described as the end of the nose, the spot between the brows and the two eyes respectively.

 Quotation 13 gives the full history of Markandeya-Rishi. It is plainly stated that the Rishi represents Viveka, distinguishing, analysing Intellect. Yema or death who is said to have attacked him, signifies Ignorance. Yema's noose stands for the absence of philosophical insight; and the fear of Death is caused by the idea of Duality and the absence of the knowledge of Unity. Dekshina-murti or Siva who is said to have saved the Rishi from Death is equally well explained. Dekshina is defined as Semushi or Intellect and the effect of constantly  
developing it in the right direction and extricating all the worldly dross from it is the God Siva himself.

**तुषेण बद्धो व्रीहिस्यात् तुषाभावेन तण्डुलः।  
एवं बद्धस्तथा जीवः कर्मनाशे सदाशिवः।  
पाशबद्धस्तथा जीवःपाशमुक्तस्सदाशिवः॥**

No plainer explanation is needed to understand this subject provided one is gifted with ordinary human reason.

 Mrikanduja or Markandeya can also be known by a reference to its root meaning. Mri to kill and Kandu, itch or filth. The Intellect freed from sinful or evil thoughts and desires, is the idea expressed by the term.

 Quotation 12 gives a detailed description of Suka and Vamadeva, which could on no account be mistaken for any current ideas as to their being two real personages. They are clearly explained as two different paths for the attainment of salvation. Suka-marga is explained as so named on account of its possibility to soar high at once like a bird and it distinctly refers to Sankhya-gnana. Vamadeva means to crawl slowly like an ant, and the Marga or path namedafter him represents the process of obtaining gradual progress,. overcoming the difficulties that intervene by long periods of trouble and effort. This path distinctly refers to the Karma-yoga. The two sets of Sapta-Rishis noticed in this para refer to the same differentiation. The distinction between these two paths of Yogas we have elaborately treated in Chapter II; and it may be observed here that they are not religious processes left to the free option or selection of man, but that they chiefly depend upon his qualifications for practice. As it is a matter of vital importance commonly misunderstood, a few lines from the passage quoted before, may be profitably noted below with a view to remind us of the qualifications insisted upon for their practice.

**स्वसंवेद्यं हि तद्ब्रह्म कुमारी स्त्रीसुखं यथा।  
अयोगी नैव जानाति जात्यन्ध इव वर्णिकान्।  
बहुव्याकुलचित्तानां विचारात्तत्वधीर्न हि।  
योगो मुख्यस्ततस्तेषां धीदर्पस्तेन नश्यति।  
अव्याकुलधियां मोहमात्रेणाच्छादितात्मनाम्।  
सांख्यनामा विचारस्यात् मुख्यो झटितिसिद्धिदः॥**

 Quotation 6 describes Viswamithra as the friend of all, towards whom everything rushes and in whoin everything joins, representing thereby the Reasoning Faculty in man known as Mauana. We have just before seen that Vasishta represents Sruti or Vedas and Manana is the next stage. New

facts learned from the Vedas are thought over for understnading them, and very often doubts arise for their immediate conviction. This idea is generally described as quarrels taking place between the two Rishis, and Vasishta of course triumphing at last over Viswamitra. We seldom hear stories of other Rishis quarrelling in this manner.

 We must however stop with the subject here, as it is neither convenient nor necessary to give an exhaustive treatment of all the Rishis mentioned in the texts. Explanations may be offered wherever new names are introduced in the subsequent portions of this treatise. But it is hoped that the general formulas and explanations already furnished will enable the readers to find out for themselves the real clue to the significance of new names appearing in the religious literature.

 **11.** Before closing this section, I feel it my duty to offer a word of apology to our venerable Pandits and Theosophists for the few unavoidable romarks I was compelled to make against their interpretations of our religious texts. It must anyhow be admitted that I have brought no fresh charges against them now, in behalf of the correct understanding of the important items explained in this little essay. Hinduisın versus Pandit and Theosophy, has virtually been an old case long pending in India, and I have only placed the two in their proper order, the Pandit appearing as the first and the Theosophist as the second. In justice to the earnest work done by the latter, I am strongly of opinion that all the current criticisms against Theosophy are uncharitable to say the least. Theosophy minus Hinduism we have absolutely no right to attack, and even the existing criticisms against its method of interpreting our religion are more or less whimsical and cowardly. It is surely unprofitable, and discourteous on our part to rejoice over its recent

confusions in the Mission. Even supposing that Theosophy leaves India for good, one of these days, there is not the slightest assurance of our countrymen not being ready to swallow any other sophy or ism that might at any future time, make its appearance in the lanl, armed with further modifications and explanations for our holy religion. The most shameful and culpable fact of our own ignorance of the subject, still remains intact, and no hopeful signs of improvement in the near future combined with the necessary zeal and earnestness to make up for the great fall for a few centuries past, are yet clearly visible. In the history of the Religions of the world, we at present really occupy a very unique and pitiable position, the natural result of our own indifference and lethargy. Our Pandit has gradually lost his dignified status, once commanded and gladly recognised in the country, by his deterioration in erudition, general knowledge and even self-respect, and he has virtually dwindled into one of the inutilities of a nation, still lingering by sheer force of existence. No similar charges could however be laid at the door of the Theosophist who is invariably a cultured gentleman, unfortunately misled in his attempt to do some useful work by his mistaken method of procedure. He is certainly amenable to reason aud conviction and is capable of turning to good account. The Pandit on the other hand has clearly washed his hands off everything useful and reasonable and simply stands stubborn in an uncouth fashion. These are bare facts which we could not afford to conceal in the interest of truth.

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

**Summary of the first three Chapters.**

 Part I of this essay has to be concluded by the end of this Chapter, having by this time examined the preparatory

details necessary to enable us to proceed with the main subject conveniently, in a convincing style of treatment. A general survey of what has been hitherto done for this purpose may be useful to keep us reminded of the important facts noticed in these three Chapters, with a view to apply them readily for the correct interpretations of terms and ideas demanding explanations in the subsequent pages forming Part II of this book.

 Chapter I has been set apart almost as an introductory one to explain and prove the absurd and injurious conclusions, both scientific and religious, to which the current interpretations, local and foreign, are unconsciously but inevitably drifting. Apparent geographical descriptions and specifications of time as well as religious personalities treated in our ancient religious literature, have been shown to refer to serious and religious matters, and that their modern interpretations are not only unsatisfactory, but are also so irrelevant and incoherent that they furnish no respectable informations of any kind useful to mankind. We have also noticed in this Chapter that the literature in question is the product of literary giants, apart from its scientific and religious importance, and could not therefore be easily condemned as worthless or explained away in the present careless fashion, without clearly exhibiting one's own ignorance,impertinence, bias or apathy. Sufficient instances have also been cited to show that the current silly method of interpretation as well as the irresponsible undertakings to calumnise are unwarranted and unjustifiable. In the circumstances detailed above, we have seen that a complete and searching enquiry was absolutely necessary to be instituted, in justice to the dignity and usefulness of the subject as well as to the veneration and gratitude due to the ancient sages as compilers of the texts, in which they have bequeathed volumes

of immense wisdom and knowledge for the real benefit of their beloved posterity. Chapter II was thus started to examine as clearly as possible the nature and scope of the varieties of religious literature owned by our countrymen, for ages yet unknown to the modern Historian and Archæologist. We have been able to see on enquiry that the knowledge required for religious perfection is described as twofold, consisting of the Para and Apara Vidyas, of which the former is reckoned as the ultimate knowledge by experience, which could be secured only by virtue of devotional practices specially prescribed in the Apara-vidy. The theoretical and practical portions of the subject have thus been clearly distinguished in the very beginning and the theoretical consisting of texts furnishing full instructions on the subject has been divided into 14 Vidyas, starting with the Vedas themselves. The scope and application of the Puranas and Itihasas falling within this classification have been particularly examined in detail, and we have found that they clearly refer to the treatinent of Sabda-Bramhan, Apara-Bramhan or Purana-Purusha, and its latent energies and glories discovered and utilized by the ancient sages for religious advancement by meditations on their evolutionary and involutionary effects.We have also thereby distinctly understood that the Puranic stories containing apparent descriptions of places, times and personalities as well as of creations, preservations and destructions of worlds such as 14 Lokas, Bramhandas &c, tell tales of far more serious matters than those connected with this evanescent material world and its still more transient and pigmy inhabitants.

 Thus far we have examined the general significance of the subjects and their texts comprising our ancient religious

literature in Section I of this Chapter. It must however be specially noticed here that all the above explanations are entirely based upon original passages selected from authontic texts and that no personal views have been ventured to be foisted on the public, like most of the attempts of modern critics which are often conspicuous by the entire absence of any such authority.

 The next and most important subject dealt with in the remaining portion of this Chapter, Section II, is the Hindu Philosophy as applied specially to our ancient religion. This subject however has taken up more space than was originally expected, consistent with the size and scope of this little essay, on account of its being the very foundation upon which the whole religion with its various grades and stages for practical application, is constructed. There is of course a general and reasonable impression prevailing amongst all intelligent enquirers of Indian affairs, that every national movement in India, Political, social or artistic is based uponsome religious conviction working like an undercurrent. But the further fact, of religious convictions having invariably originated ages ago, from their corresponding and long established philosophical foundations, has unfortunately been now forgotten and it therefore urgently demands its recognition in the permanent interest of our religion as a whole. The existing differences of views and uncertainties as to the details of various matters relating to our religion, accepted as it is in its general scope and function, can be easily and conveniently traced to the ignorance of the fundamental and philosophical principles, and a correct knowledge of the same is hopefully expected to set things aright. An examination of the several important points of philosophy as explained in the religious texts has clearly proved that they are by no means liable to be contradicted oven by the most recent

facts established in Western Philosophy. On the contrary, we have seen that many a new and grand theory of the modern day has been foretold and practically utilized, showing how familiar the ideas were to the ancient sages. In the comparison of Western with Eastern philosophy several important facts new to the former are found enunciated in the latter; and philosophy as a practical subject closely connected with our religion for the tangible attainment of the ultimate goal and summum-bonum of human existence is probably a fact yet altogether u known and undiscovered in the West. Greatly astonishing as this might appear to the Western philosopher and Critic, in spite of the historical and archaeological progress attained in their land,no biased or illogical criticisins put forward even in the strongest terms would be of any avail, as the facts explained in our philosophy are proved by the direct experience of venerable sages whose processes of reasoning and observation in themselves, are not yet uuderstood by the Western nations. The tendency not rarely exhibited in offering criticisms without proper study and earnest enquiry in the required direction, could only meet with ultimate failure, as abuses andsneers which are often the well-known arguments used on such occasions are not acceptable in the discussions of serious philosophical problems. Under the existing circumstances, the most profitable and the most honorable course for the Western philosophers would be to shake hands with the Easterns and put their shoulders together, with the broadest sympathy possible, for the purpose of recovering and resuscitating the lost treasures of humanity at large, viewed as the same creation of the Almighty One. If only the quantity of energy that might be voluntarily wasted for unnecessary criticisms be utilized for this purpose, inuch useful progress might soon be expected. A few simple facts explained in

this Chapter might again be noticed in this connection, lest they be lost amidst the crowd of descriptions under this heading.

 (a) It can be freely noticed, throughout the Upanishads and other texts, that the very style of describing the Bramhan, is highly practical and hopeful. No tinge of pessimism or uncertainty or even indefiniteness is ever attached to it, although they are often mistakenly attributed to the ultimate aim of our philosophy. The following few lines from the various quotations furnished in this Chapter, are worthy of notice.

**दारिद्र्याशा यथा नास्ति सम्पन्नस्य तथा मम।  
ब्रह्मानन्दे निमग्नस्य विषयाशा न तद्भवेत्॥**

**अजकुक्षौ गजो नास्ति ह्यात्मकुक्षौ जगन्न हि॥**

**कीदृक्तर्हीति चेत्पृच्छेदीदृक्ता नास्ति तत्र हि।  
यदनीदृक् अतादृक्चतत्स्वरूपं विनिश्चिनु।  
अक्षाणां विषयस्त्वीदृक् च परोक्षस्तादृगुच्यते।  
विषयी नाक्षविषयःस्वत्वान्नास्य परोक्षता॥**

**शक्येषु बाधितेष्वन्ते शिष्यते यत्तदेव तत्।  
सर्वबाधे न किञ्चिच्चेत् यन्नकिञ्चित्तदेव तत्।  
भाषा एवात्र भिद्यन्ते निर्बाधं तावदस्ति हि॥**

 (b) In the logical analysis of material and efficient causes, the former called Upadana-karana, as explained in the texts, is divided into three classes; Arambha, Parinami and Vivarta, the last being assigned for the explanation of the whole cosmological conception. Vivarta refers to theappearance of a change in the material without an actual change. This is probably a piece of additional information worth the notice of a Western Logician.

**अवस्थान्तरभानन्तु विवर्तोरज्जुसर्पवत्।**

**निरंशेप्यस्त्यसौ व्योम्नि तलमालिन्य कल्पनात्।  
ततो निरंश आनन्दे विवर्तोजगदिष्यताम्॥**

 (c) The evoluion and destruction of the universe cannot be attributed to Nature, nor to Karma in itself, nor again to Eswara alone. A combination of the individual's Karmas and the enforcement of the Karmic law by Eswara who is himself the law-giver, must be accepted as the real cause. This is also an acknowledged theory in the texts and peculiar to Eastern Philosophy.

**न स्वभावाज्जगज्जन्म स्थितिध्वंसा मुनीश्वराः।  
न मया केवलेनापि न च केवलकर्मणा।  
प्राणिनां कर्मपाकेन मया च मुनिसत्तमाः।  
जगतः सम्भवो नाशः स्थितिश्च भवति द्विजाः।  
एवं कर्मानुरूपेण जगज्जन्मादि यन्मया।  
एव स्वभावो विप्रेन्द्राः इति वेदार्थनिर्णयः॥**

 (d) With regard to the vexed question of Free-will and Necessity, a very simple and reasonable solution is offered in the texts and it deserves the attention of those interested in Western Moral Philosophy. The unavoidable dependence on Atma accepts Necessity, but the Free-will of the in lividual is granted for action. Atina here is compared to the sun during the day setting every living being to work which is done according to its own Free-will.

**आत्मचैतन्यमाश्रित्य देहेन्द्रियमनोधियः।  
स्वकीयार्थेषु वर्तन्ते सूर्यालोकं यथा जनाः॥**

 (e) The most important theory in our philosophy, perhaps yet unrecognised in the Western systems, but nevertheless the most valuable one in the interest of our religion is that found clearly mentioned in the texts, explaining the status and function of Reason or Budhi. Our philosophy does not stop with Budhi as the ultimate known factor in

the philosophical analysis, but goes far beyond it. The existence of Jiva and Eswara as higher items distinct from Budhi is philosophically established in all the ancient texts. The Budhistic theories or those that stop with Budhi as the name itself signifies, are therefore rejected on religious as well as philosophical grounds. Budhi in spite of its high rank amidst the senses, is reckoned only as ephemeral as any of them. This is the most vital though a most knotty point of difference ever destined to continue in our philosophy as compared with many other known systems, until Atheisms become Theisms in all of them. The following few lines on the subject will doubtless furnish ample scope for a real philosopher to ponder on.

**बुद्धेरचित्वं संग्राह्यं दृष्टत्वाज्जन्मनाशयोः।  
बुद्धेरन्यश्चिदाभासः प्रवेशश्श्रुतिषु श्रुतः।  
न हि धीभावभावित्वादाभासोस्ति धियः पृथक्।  
इति चेदल्पमेवोक्तं धीरप्येवं स्वदेहतः।  
आत्मा प्रवेशं संङ्कल्प्य प्रविष्ट इति गीयते।  
कथं प्रचिष्टोऽसङ्गश्चेत्सृष्टिर्वास्य कथं वद॥**

 Having explained in Section II of this chapter the necessary philosophical points to estabblish the existence of Bramhan, the practical methods prescribed for attaining to that coveted position are detailed, namely Gnana-yoga and Karmayoga. The results of the practice of these Yogas are known by self-experience, and the consequent bliss and freedom from pain are therefore matters which demand no extraneous proofs. The following will corroborate thestatement here made.

**लोकेस्मिन् द्विविधा निष्ठापुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ।  
ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम्।  
अधिष्ठानं समस्तस्य जगतस्सत्यचिद्धनम्।**

**अहमस्मीति निश्चित्य वीतशोको भवेन्मुनिः।  
स्वशरीरे स्वयं ज्योतिः स्वरूपं सर्वसाक्षिणम्।  
क्षीणदोषाः प्रपश्यन्ति नेतरे मायया वृताः।  
अधिष्ठाने तथा ज्ञाते प्रपञ्चे शून्यतां गते।  
देहस्यापि प्रपञ्चत्वात् प्रारब्धावस्थितिः कुतः।  
विज्ञातब्रह्मतत्वस्य यथा पूर्वे न संसृतिः।  
अस्ति चेन्नसविज्ञातब्रह्मभावो बहिर्मुखः॥**

**तिष्ठत्ययं कथं देहः इति शङ्कावतो जडान्।  
समाधातुं बाह्यदृष्ट्या प्रारब्धं वदति श्रुतिः।  
न तु देहादिसत्यत्वबोधनाय विपश्चिताम्॥**

 Besides the possibility of attaining the ultimate goal, the collateral effects of Yoga called Sidhis are also detailed in this section; and they are also specially noticed as not being generally exhibited by real Yogis, nor even valued by them. Any desire to make use of them when involuntarily secured, will bring about the downfall of the Yogi from his main and legitimate course. Deceiving exhibitions of some of the Sidhis described in the texts, by those who are neither Yogis nor even respectable men, are occasionally heard, and they deserve to be treated only like the work of pretenders and cheats in other lines. Such practices are not only wrong morally, but are also serious sins religiously, having been committed in the name of God. The real Yogi is ever watchful that he is not led away by the superhuman powers he may obtain, as he always understands them as severe and alluring trials in his onward path. The following lines represent the true view of the Yogi with regard to them.

**मोक्षस्य बहवश्शास्त्रे प्रोच्यन्ते प्रतिबन्धकाः।  
अणिमादीच्छया तुल्यः प्रतिबन्धो न कश्चन।  
ब्रह्मद्रोह गुरुद्रोह शिवद्रोहादि पातकम्।  
अन्यच्च पातकं सर्वे सिद्धिरूपेण वर्तते॥**

 The last but not the least important fact noted in this Chapter is the necessity for the combined practice, simultaneously, of three processes prescribed for the attainment of salvation, namely, Vasana-ksheya, Mano-nasa and Vijgnana. Vasana ksheya is the destruction of particular tendencies created in the mind by previous effects of actions. Mano-nasa is controlling the natural and ordinary functions of the mind ever tending to exert itself. Vijgnana is the knowledge of philosophy. They mutually influence each other and should be practised together to be effective. An ignorance of this fact is likely to mislead many and lead to failures in the religious practices. Without the knowledge of philosophy the object aimed at by the prescribed religious ordinances could not be understood and practised with the necessary conviction and earnestness. All unnecessary criticisms against Hindu rituals and ceremonies will certainly vanish, if only the fact that they are so regulated as to serve the objects specified here, is clearly recognised. The following lines on the subject are worth particular attention.

**यावद्विलीनं न मनो न तावद्वासनाक्षयः।  
न क्षीणा वसना यावच्चित्तं तावन्न शाम्यति।  
यावन्न तत्वविज्ञानं तावच्चित्तशमः कुतः।  
यावन्न चित्तोपशमो न तावत्तत्ववेदनम्।  
यावन्नवासनानाशः तावत्तत्वागमः कुतः।  
यावन्नतत्वसम्प्राप्तिःन तावद्वासनाक्षयः।  
वासनाक्षय विज्ञान मनोनाशा महामते।  
समकालं चिराभ्यस्ता भवन्ति फलदा मताः।  
त्रय एवं समं यावन्नाभ्यस्ताश्च पुनः पुनः।  
तावन्न पदसम्प्राप्तिर्भवत्यपि समा शतैः॥**

 Having thus furnished in Chapter II a general outline of, (1) the nature of the religious texts, (2) the philoso-

phical principles and formulas underlying our religion, and (3) the suitable procedure prescribed for the attainment of the highest goal; the Puranas and Itihasas, which act the part of a practical commentary to the Vedas, is examined in chapter III.

इतिहासपुराणाभ्यां वेदं समुपबृंहयेत्॥

 For the sake of clearness and convenience, the subject has been divided into three main and comprehensive headings, Place, Time and Personalities. The general impression being that the Puranas and Itihasas treat of ordinary geography and human history, all possible forms of misconstruing the contents of the texts must fall within the above classification. There are of course two methods for discovering the mistakes in the current interpretations. The first is by admitting the interpretations given and continuing them in the same style to some extent, we soon arrive at irrelevant and absurd conclusions. This is exactly what we have done in Chapter I. The second and more useful method is by enquiring into the correct definitions of terins used in the texts by the collection of available internal evidence aud thus rectifying the mistakes in the interpretations. This too we have done to some extent in Chapter III, and It is hoped that the enquiries already made will suffice for understanding the general purport of the so-called Histories and Geographies contained in the Puranas ant Itihasas. Besides, the scope of the subject of this Essay, namely 'The Permanent History of Bharata-Varsha' as narrated inthe Itihasas known as the Ramayana and the Maha-Bharata, is very limited, and the means secured already for arriving at correct interpretations, will more than ineet the actual requirements.

 The subject of this essay will thus commence with Volume II, Chapter IV and the preceding chapters contairing several original quotations from recognised religious texts will be referred to as authority for all the necessary interpretations.

 It must be acknowledged that a few centuries ago, an elaborate introduction of the sort contained in the first three chapters, would certainly have appeared frivolous and unnecessary, and that it would doubtless be so to a real native Pandit even at the present day. But we are however not in the least prepared to deny the existence of learned Pandits in the land, on the contrary, we most earnestly pray the Almighty to fill the country with such venerable religiousguides. As a matter of fact, we extremely regret that our poor mortal eyes do not at present catch the sight of any of them to help us out of our existing difficulties. It night possibly be that they are hiding themselves to avoid contamination with the modern generation that has left them and has taken to Western civilization. Whatever might be their excuse, the present state of our helplessness, is a stern fact demanding an urgent remedy from whatsoever source possible. A few foreigners themselves were induced to take pity on us some years ago and they have been trying their best to help us, although the result of their labours so far as our religion was concerned, somehow ended in failure. It must here be noticed to the credit or otherwise of the Pandit, that during these years the new foreign creed has been at work in hisown country, he has been equally silent. We could therefore safely hope that the local Pandit will let us alone in our attempt to help ourselves in spite of our evident incapacities. We could gratefully have welcomed the cooperation of the Pandits in the matter, but it is too long since they have altogether forsaken us. In a pitiable condi-

tion of this sort in which none could be found to fall upon for help, we are compelled to make the best of our own resources.

**मातुलस्य बलं माता जामातुर्दुहिता बलम्।  
श्रशुरस्य बलं भार्या स्वयमेवातिथेर्बलम्॥**

 In conclusion, I feel most happy to express my heartfelt thanks and gratefulness for the sympathy and interest already evinced by several of my friends and well-wishers, at whose pressure, I have here ventured to publish the first three chapters as the first volume, the main subject in the essay being dealt with beyond these chapters. The remaining three chapters have yet to be printed and some portions have even to be written hereafter. I have no doubt that the interest now exhibited is more on account of the curiosity in the crude views that have almost tickled their feelings already, than in any excellence of treatment, which the essay never professed to claim from its very commencement. There are no new topics dealt with anywhere within it, and the texts on the whole particularly belong to the oldest period imaginable. It is therefore earnestly hoped that all the serious faults in the book will be kindly over-looked and rectified as far as convenient for the purpose of securing additional enlightenment and for the creation of a sincere scientific interest, particularly to the legitimate heirs to the sacred religious literature.

**गुणायन्ते दोषाः सुजनवदने दुर्जनमुखे  
गुणा दोषायन्ते तदिदमपि नो विस्मयपदम्।  
महामेघःक्षारं पिबति कुरुते वारि मधुरम्  
फणी क्षीरं पीत्वा वमति गरलं दुस्सहतरम्॥**

**पिबन्ति नद्यः स्वयमेव नाम्भः स्वयं न खादन्ति फलानि वृक्षाः।  
नादन्ति सस्यं खलु वारिवाहाःपरोपकाराय सतां विभूतयः॥**
